MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 1.-- Prime Minister J.H. Scullin opened the Labor campaign for the federal election tonight with a speech broadcast throughout Australia.

HAVANA, Dec. 1.--Cane planters in Cuba are somewhat dismayed by the recent statement of Thomas L. Chadbourne, author of the plan for stabilization of the world sugar market, that he will advocate further ...
Communist backers of the National Hunger March that is to be made on Washington at the end of this week announced final plans for the demonstration yesterday and issued statements ...

Frederick Lewis Allen, associate editor of Harper's Magazine, is severely critical of "the Hoover campaign of optimism," which he says refused to face the grim reality of depression, in his informal history of America during the post-war era, ...

The fist formal complaint against the Sunday night benefit performance of Broadway shows for the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund was filed yesterday in the form of a letter addressed to Police Commissioner Mulrooney by Powell Crichton, counsel for the New York Sabbath committee.

Vannie Higgins, the harassed young lobster fisherman who is constantly being accused of large-scale bootlegging operations, was taken into custody yesterday by the Coast Guard, but it turned out finally that it was all for his own good.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1.--Thanksgiving Day marked the end of one of the biggest jobs accomplished in Soviet Russia under American supervision --the construction of the Nijni Novgorod automobile plant and the workers' city handled by the Austin Engineering Company of Cleveland, Ohio.
Football, most wealthy of intercollegiate sports, will share with the unemployed this week to the extent of an even dozen games and one round-robin tournament.

A serious shortage in the wild duck supply in this country and Canada has brought the need for an immediate restoration program to the forefront of discussions among leading game officials and sportsmen at the American Game Conference, and ...

After holding steady for eight weeks, during which period (approximately) loadings of grain and grain products advanced from a level 33 per cent below that of the corresponding week last year to 4 per cent above, the adjusted index of freightcar loadings has declined sharply to ...

DETROIT, Dec. 1.--Lowell R. Bayles of Springfield, Mass., broke the world land plane speed record at the Wayne County Airport this afternoon by averaging 284.7 miles an hour in four flights of 1.8 miles each.

College football attendance, on the basis of nation-wide reports to The Associated Press yesterday, declined generally about 10 per cent for the 1931 season, as compared with last year, despite evidence of its continued great popularity.

MADRID, Dec. 1.--Just 141 days after it was inaugurated, and only nine behind its scheduled date, the Constitutional Cortes of Republican Spain today completed voting on the Constitution, a unique document, containing striking contributions to the world's liberal thought and designed to transform a feudal monarchy into a progressive modern State.

Stocks fluctuated nervously on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, but the trend was downward a good part of the day. Rallying tendencies appeared in the afternoon, following a spell of weakness in the early dealings.

A bit of informal history having to do, more or less, with the manner in which his father, John Bigelow, blocked the plans of Napoleon III to send cruisers to aid the Confederates during the Civil War was told last night by Poultney Bigelow, author, to an audience of 400 in the assembly room of the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1.-- Manager W.F. Chillingworth of the Yale fencing team announced at the annual mass meeting of candidates for the team tonight that a junior varsity combination would be formed this year for the first time.

Alternating periods of weakness and strength on the Stock Exchange seemed yesterday to reflect the changing moods of Wall Street. Most sections of the list were steady at the opening and it looked as if the advance of the previous day was to be extended.

Armed with a report on a survey showing that an average of 123,460 automobile owners park their machines on the streets of Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn all night every night, a delegation of the New York Board of Trade and other civic ...

PRINCETON, N.J., Dec. 1.--Al though desisting from further advocacy of a revision of the coaching system at Princeton University, the columns of The Daily Princetonian, student newspaper, today contained communications from undergraduates ...

BOSTON, Mass., Dec. 1.--In today's issue of The Boston University News interviews with Glenn Warner, head football coach at Stanford, Eddie Casey of Harvard and Major Frank Cavanaugh of Fordham reveal that the trend among the country's ...

A proposal to take the control of banking in this State from the Superintendent of Banks, a political appointee, and to vest it in a commission of eleven members, seven elected by the banking institutions of the State and four appointed by the Governor, has been drawn up by ...

The quarterly dividend on the $6 preferred stock of the Tri-Continental Corporation, against the payment of which a restraining suit is pending, was declared yesterday at the regular meeting of the directors.

Pedaling furiously through a night of almost solid jamming, the famous French Red Devil team of Alfred Letourner and Marvel Guimbretiere maintained a position in the forefront of the fifty-first international six-day bicycle race in Madison ...

May it please your Excellency: A diabolical, fiendish, unnatural crime was committed on the twenty-second day of July, 1916, at the corners of Steuart and Market Streets, in the city of San Francisco.

It would be "regrettable" if Dr. William H. Walker, brother of Mayor Walker, should be found not entitled legally to continue in the position of medical consultant to the Board of Education, said Supreme Court Justice Gavegan yesterday in ...
ALBANY, Dec. 1.--New York City authorities this afternoon pleaded with the State Tax Commission for realty valuations of 100 per cent instead of the tentative rates which the commission has set.

The accounting filed in the Surrogates Court yesterday by the executors of the estate of Harry Payne Whitney, capitalist and sportsman, who died Oct. 26, 1930, leaving property valued at $71,771,303, disclosed that the estate made a profit of $744,529 in a transaction in Canadian ...

OWENSBORO, Ky., Dec. 1 (AP).-- Incensed because of low prices offered them, about 3,000 farmers attending the opening tobacco sale of the season here today broke up the sale after hurling apples at the auctioneers. They then unanimously adopted a resolution not to raise any tobacco next year.

Criticism of the city's 1932 budget was made yesterday in a statement by the City Affairs Committee over the joint signatures of John Haynes Holmes and Rabbi Stephen Wise, chairman and vice chairman respectively of that body.

The city received bids yesterday for street-cleaning equipment and found bargain prices prevailing. It found that by accepting the lowest bids offered it could get 936 specified pieces of motor equipment for the $3,029,000 it is prepared to spend.

Reductions in bottled milk prices in New York City took on the aspect of a price war yesterday when the Sheffield Farms Company, Inc., announced a reduction of two cents a quart in the retail home delivery price of both grade A and grade B milk in the city and vicinity.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 1.--On petition of a creditor and with the consent of the company, Judge Davis of the United States District Court late today appointed two receivers to take charge of and operate the Wabash Railroad with 2,237 miles of trackage.

Despite lack of money, physical handicaps and the loss of the leader, Dr. Alfred Wegener, who perished under tragic circumstances, the members of the German expedition to Greenland have kept up their morale and their eagerness to continue the meteorological and geological observations in the inland ice field of the island continent.
Invitations have been sent out by Mrs. Prescott Slade for the marriage of her daughter, Miss Katherine Slade, to Henry Dennison Babcock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Woodward Babcock.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The net indebtedness of Elizabeth, N.J., on Dec. 31, 1930, was $7,446,870, or $64.76 per capita, as compared with $50.10 in 1929, and $29.37 in 1918, the Department of Commerce announced today.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, national amateur pocket billiard champion, held a lead of 128 to 102 at the end of the first block of the 375-point challenge match with Edward Fagin, Engineers Club, at the New York Elks Club last night.

Charles A. Muche, who is known in West New Brighton, Staten Island, where he is a church member, as a sober and dependable family man, admitted yesterday to Federal Judge John C. Knox that on last Nov. 19 he had stolen a $4,000 gold ingot from the government Assay ...

J.P. Morgan Co. and the National City Company, as fiscal agents, have invited holders of Argentine Government external sinking-fund 6 per cent bonds, due on June 1, 1959, to offer to them until Dec. 31 sufficient bonds to exhaust the sum of ...

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 1.--The fact that no information has been advanced by official circles concerning the report soon to be issued by the investigating committee looking into Cosach, the nitrate and soda combine, ...

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1.--The Yale football squad of twenty-five men who will play in the DartmouthBrown-Holy Cross-Yale round robin tournament in the Bowl on Saturday today was assembled by Head Coach Mal Stevens for its first drill of the week on Anthony Thompson Field.

LONDON, Dec. 1 (AP).--Charlie Chaplin played a court room role today, and didn't like it very well. The comedian, looking the part of complete gravity, gave a performance that failed to impress Judge Tobin. The judge, in fact, was pretty free with his criticism.

The stockholders of the Standard Gas Light Company of the City of New York have been called to take action on Dec. 16 upon a plan to sell all the property, rights, privileges and franchises of the company to the Consolidated Gas Company of New ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1.--The new banking bill with which it is aimed to cure defects in the Federal Reserve and national banking laws so as to minimize the menace of financial depressions will be ready for submission to Congress next week, Senator Walcott, Republican, of Connecticut, said today after a conference with President Hoover at the White House.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 1.--M. John D. Chapman of Greenwich Conn., defeated Mrs. Sara Fown Wadsworth of Pittsburgh, 1 up, the first round of match play of the eleventh annual Carolina golf tornament for women today.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 1.--Two simple though impressive ceremonies--one civil, the other religious--marked today's consecration of Archbishop Thorgom Kouchagian as the Armenian Patriarch of Jerusalem, second ...

The textile trade was sceptical yesterday of reports that the long sought secret of successfully purifying ramie, the oldest and strongest vegetable fiber known, had been developed under the direction of the Universal Fibre Company.
A memorial bust to William Bolitho, columnist and author, was unveiled yesterday afternoon at the Pulitzer School of Journalism of Columbia University.
HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 1.--William J. Hoffman of Lock Haven, Pa., was elected captain of the Dartmouth football team at a meeting of the letter men today.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 1.--A ragged start which handicapped Thundertone, favorite in the Carrollton Purse, feature today at Jefferson Park, was a great disappointment to many who braved unpleasant weather to attend the races, which were run ...

MADRID, Dec. 1.--It is difficult to condense into a few words the outstanding points of the Constitution. It is deliberately free from theoretical or copied systemizations, because the Cortes, freely elected, has ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1.--His slight frame quivering with emotion and his flashing eyes revealing intense feeling, Mayor Walker made a dramatic and moving appeal today when he asked Governor James Rolph Jr. for a full pardon for Tom Mooney.

PARIS, Dec. 1.--The Rev. William Orville Shepard, who was the Methodist Episcopal Bishop of the Mediterranean Area, died last night at the American Hospital in Neuilly, Bishop Shepard was 69 years old. It is understood that the body will be sent to the United States for burial in Chicago.

BILL ALEXANDER of Georgia Tech said: "We played Tulane and Georgia, and, while Tulane defeated Georgia when they met, I consider the teams Fairly even. I haven't seen Tennessee play this year, but it must be a great team on its record."

LONDON, Dec. 1.--American aerial broadcasting apparatus Has been installed in Vickers-Victoria Transport aircraft for experimental use among the natives of Iraq, the British Air Ministry stated today.
PARIS, Dec. 1.--For the first time in a week the twelve peacemakers of the League of Nations Council had something fairly definite to announce tonight on the Sino-Japanese conflict in Manchuria.

TRENTON, N.J., Dec.1.--W. Warren Barbour, influential advocate of the protective tariff and regarded as a wet, was appointed United States Senator by Governor Larson today to succeed the late Dwight W. Morrow.

LONDON, Dec. 1.--Prime Minister MacDonald today made a declaration of British Government policy which brought the dream of a United States of India a little nearer and left the door open for settling disagreements which still are unsolved.

Complaints received by the Actors' Equity Association in regard to the large number of alien players employed in this country have been based on exaggerated estimates, Frank Gilmore, president of Equity, ...

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Dec. 2.-- Fighting between Japanese troops and a cavalry detachment of General Ma Chan-shan's forces broke out today southwest of Hailun, Manchuria, said foreign dispatches from Harbin.

The day of tax-free tickets to boxing contests for charity has passed, it was learned yesterday. Early last month David Burnet, the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, sent out an order to all the collectors in New York State, telling them to allow no exemptions from the Federal tax.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1.--Ralph Greenleaf, ten times world's pocket billiard champion, got away to an impressive start in his first match of the 1931 national championship tournament by outclassing Robert Lindblom of Seattle at Allinger's Academy tonight, 125 to 12.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mex., Dec. 1.-- Baron Long's Victor won the fourth race, offered as the feature on the card at the Agua Caliente track today, defeating Walter H. Dupee's Captain Danger by a length and a half.

MANILA, Dec. 2.--Secret agents of the Philippine Constabulary are urgently insisting on a large reinforcement of the Constabulary forces in the Province of Bulacan, directly north of Manila, believing that a sanguinary outbreak is only a matter of time.

The Columbia University Club's team in Class A maintained its place at the top of the Metropolitan League squash tennis championship race by scoring a decisive victory over the Fraternity Club team last night, 5 to 0.
Columbia's football team approached the peak of its post-season training yesterday at South Field in preparation for the charity tournament to be held at the Yankee Stadium next Wednesday.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--Erwin Rudolph of Cleveland, defending champion, took the lead in the world's pocket billiard championship tonight when he won his second match of the competition, defeating Spencer Livsey of Loe Angeles, 125 to 77, in sixteen innings. Rudolph's high run of 59, Livsey's 26.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 2.--Suit for the appointment of a receiver for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, one of the largest theatrical concerns in the country, was filed today by J. Cookman Boyd, a Baltimore lawyer, who holds 300 of the 2,400,000 shares of outstanding Class A stock.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2.--The latest figures on Soviet steel production show it is running below that of last year and 1929, despite the fact that the control figures, or quota, required an annual total this year which would be almost double last year's.

Collateral loans to member firms of the New York Stock Exchange decreased $66,116,860 in November, or from $796,268,768 on Oct. 31 to $730,151,908 at the end of November. This reduction again brings the loan account to the lowest level shown in the Exchange's public records.
MUKDEN, Manchuria, Dec. 2.-- Small-scale fighting broke out in two places in Manchuria today, according to announcements by Japanese authorities here.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The impact of economic depression might have been lessened by a check on inflation during the recent boom years, Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the National City Bank of New York, testified today before the La Follette subcommittee of the Senate committee on manufactures.
Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were the narrowest in some time and prices, after holding within a 6-point range, ended the day with gains of 2 to 6 points.

Three entire floors of the Hotel Delmonico at 502 Park Avenue leased to the Breakfast Club, Inc., an exclusive resort, where prominent and allegedly convivial New Yorkers are said to gather, may be padlocked for a year as the result of an action begun yesterday by the Federal Government.

The season's first performances of Wagner's "The Flying Dutchman," which was revived last year, and Meyerbeer's "L'Africana" will mark next week, the sixth of the Metropolitan Opera Company's current season.

Forward passing, punting and place-kicking contests, in which more than forty public high school football stars of the city are entered, will be held in conjunction with the Erasmus Hall-Theodore Roosevelt game at Ebbets Field on Saturday.

Directors of the National Automobile Chamber of Commerce, including the heads of several motor car manufacturing companies, yesterday afternoon inspected the exhibits of custom coachwork at the automobile salon being held this week in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The navy building program, which naval committee leaders in both Senate and House are planning to lay before Congress, may call for construction up to the limits fixed by the London treaty, but spread out in a continuous plan over a period of years.

An overproduction of game fish is the object of the Bureau of Fisheries of the Department of Commerce in a program under way to increase the stock in streams throughout the country, Henry O'Malley, commissioner of the bureau, declared yesterday at the American Game Conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A reduction of $4 a ton in the price of Canadian newsprint delivered in New York City, effective Jan. 1, will be announced in a few days, it was learned yesterday from reliable sources. The present price is $57 a ton.
Total gold holdings are now 1,004,928,000 gold marks. The ratio of reserve held against outstanding notes is 25.3 per cent.

A warning against drastic cuts in the navy was voiced yesterday by Admiral Reginald R. Belknap, retired, at the eleventh annual meeting of the Allied Patriotic Societies at the Army and Navy Club. The Admiral declared that although "peace has her victories they do not come the way of the American Navy."

The committee appointed to investigate the charges made by Dr. Ray O. Hall against the Department of Commerce submitted a report yesterday to Secretary Lamont in which it decided that Dr. Hall's charges were not sustained.

With the announcement by the Borden's Farm Products Company late yesterday of a 2-cent reduction in the retail price of bottled milk delivered to homes, meeting a similar cut made Tuesday by the Sheffield Farms Company, New York's "price war" in milk brought the general level of bottled milk prices to the lowest point since 1917.

PARIS, Dec. 2.--Outlining the budget before the Chamber of Deputies Finance Committee today, Deputy Lamoureux predicted that the French budget for 1933 risked the incurring of a deficit of 6,000,000,000 francs under the present system of balancing the budget.

BUDAPEST, Dec. 2.--The contention by a Socialist Deputy that Minister of the Interior Keresztes Fischer could not very well deal with the conspirators, who were arrested Saturday, since he, like they, was a member of a secret Hungarian terrorist society, provoked a noisy scene in Parliament yesterday.

A letter was mailed late yesterday to holders of one-year 5 per cent gold notes due on Dec. 1 of the Arizona Edison Company requesting them to exchange their holdings for an equal principal amount of new two-year ...

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Dec. 2.-- Contract bridge supplanted auction today at the fifth annual tournament of the American Bridge League here. The contract pair championship, with fifty-two pairs competing, got under way this afternoon and the contract team-of-four this evening. These events will continue through Saturday.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Dec, 2.--At the annual meeting of the Women's New Jersey State Golf Association held at the Montclair Golf Club today, it was decided to hold the association's 1932 championship, a three-day medal-play affair which was won last season by Miss Charlotte Glutting, at the Montclair club.

The FederAl Government must bear its part of the burden of unemployment relief, which is now being carried mainly through taxation by local communities and States, declared Dean Wallace B. Donham of the Harvard School of Business Administration yesterday before the Joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment at the Bar Association.

MUNICH, Dec. 2.--Adolf Hitler today issued an order of the day to his followers in which he proclaimed the certainty of their coming victory and warned against "heedless actions" in the lace of provocations from the enemies of National Socialism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The Capone gang, which is rapidly changing its headquarters to Federal prisons, will be minus at least one leader at Leavenworth.

Governor John G. Winant of New Hampshire, at the request of E.K. Hall, who is in charge of the football contests arranged by the committee on mobilization of relief resources, yesterday issued an appeal for strong support for the tourney which will be held in the Yale Bowl on Saturday.

Payment of all awards certified to the Department of Finance by the Board of Assessors has been held up by Controller Berry because of the discovery that some had been certified to property owners who were not entitled to them.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2.--Local and Eastern operators attempted to advance wheat prices early today on the Board of Trade here, but ran into free selling by houses that frequently act for cooperative organizations, and the best that the bulls could do was to force an upturn of 5/8 cent over yesterday's finish.

A recent, decision of the Appellate Division on the workmen's compensation law, under which New York City hospitals had contended that they were forced to spend an estimated $500,000 a year from their charity funds primarily for the benefit of insurance companies, is to be cited before the next Legislature in an attempt to amend the law, it was revealed yesterday.

The break in sterling exchange, which had slashed more than 40 cents off the dollar value of the British pound in eight trading days, was arrested yesterdays. After dropping to a new low of $3.23 in London, the exchange rallied sharply to $3.45 with the opening of the New York market.

Italo Montemezzi's one act opera, "La Notte di Zoraima," the libretto by Mario Ghisalberti, was performed last night for the first time in America in the Metropolitan Opera House. The opera is poor as a libretto and a composition.

Harold Bell Wright, some of whose books have gold more than 2,000,000 copies each, arrived here yesterday on his first visit in four years. He vigorously protested what he termed "the ugly sordidness" of much of modern American realistic literature.

At a hearing before Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey yesterday the Irving Trust Company and Lee Shubert, who had been appointed receivers in equity on Oct. 20 for the Shubert Theatre Corporation, were orderyd to continue to conduct the affairs of the corporation until June 2, with a report to the court on March 5, or sooner if developments require it.

A recital or what she called the "regal and lavish" expenditures of Mickey Walker, former middleweight and welterweight boxing champion, took the greater part of the day yesterday in Brooklyn Federal Court, where Mrs. Margaret Walker is suing to recover $25,160 she says she spent ...

LONDON, Dec. 2.--Peter Llewellyn Davies, publisher, who as a boy inspired Barrie's "Peter Pan," is engaged to harry the Hon. Margaret Hore-Ruthven, one of the popular Ruthven twins, a daughter of Major Gen. Lord Ruthven, Governor of Guernsey. The announcement was made today.
LONDON, Dec. 2.--Viscount Downe, a stanch Conservative with a distinguished military record, died last night at Wykeham Abbey, Yorkshire. He was 59 years old.
The Phelps Dodge Corporation yesterday informed domestic and foreign copper producers that it was ready and willing to put into effect the proposed curtailment agreement.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--Behind closely guarded gates the Pennsylvania varsity squad was put through a spirited workout today in preparation for the Navy game.
AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Dec. 2.--Bay Lad, a 5-year-old son of Gladiator, provided a surprise for the racegoers at Agua Caliente today when he got home just a neck in ...

At Madrid the Founding Fathers will soon be voting upon the Constitution for republican Spain which has been several months in the making. There seems to be no question that the new national charter will receive approval.

The upswing in racing, which has been noticeable particularly in Maryland in the past few months, where attendance and wagering figures exceeded those of 1930, now is reflected on the New York circuit in the shape of entries for forthcoming stake races.

Although thn professional character of the trading on the Stock Exchange has become more and more evident of late, Wall Street found a visible explanation yesterday for the weakness in various groups when the Wabash's receivership was announced.
LONDON, Dec. 2.--The Duke of Manchester sailed from Southampton on the Berengaria today for Havana, via New York, in order to file suit in Cuba for a divorce.

PARIS, Dec. 2.--Serious complications in the settlement of the SinoJapanese dispute over Manchuria were encountered tonight when the Japanese brought forth fresh demands on the settlement of the neutral zone around Chinchow, which has been threatened with attack by the Japanese unless Chinese troops withdraw.
PARIS, Dec. 2 (AP).--Francois Coty, perfume manufacturer, today was ordered to pay $5,200,000 in the next ten years to the former Mme. Coty, who divorced him in 1929.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--President Hoover today approved recommendations contained in seventeen separate reports made to him by the Tariff Commission, in which prevailing import duties on commodities originating abroad were increased in two instances and reduced in five, no change having been proposed by the commission in the remainder.

Henry Morgenthau Jr., State Conservation Commissioner, speaking last night at the annual dinner of the American Game Conference in the Hotel Pennsylvania, revealed that he did not regard the contemplated 1,000,000-acre program as the final step in reforestation efforts by the State.

Photographs which apparently show the breaking down of the atom against the impact of the cosmic ray under certain conditions were exhibited for the first time yesterday by Dr. Robert A. Millikan of the Califoria Institute of Technology, winner ...

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 2 (AP).--Man's arteries now can be photographed with X-rays by a newly discovered process announced to the Radiological Society of North America tonight by Dr. Carlos Heuser of Buenos Aires.
Since his prediction in March, 1930, that within two months "we "are likely to find the country as a "whole enjoying its wonted state of "prosperity," Secretary LAMONT of ...

Gustave Peret of Yoncalla, Ore., who was at the crank of a motion picture camera in Africa when his friend and companion, W.H. Herren of Aberdeen, Wash., was fatally mauled by a wounded lion, returned here yesterday with Mrs. Herren on the Cunard liner Aquitania.

Louis Persinger's violin recital last night in the Town Hall was a distinguished performance. It united two elements not frequently enough assembled on the same stage--the scholarship and intellectual grasp ...

WESTPORT, Mass., Dec. 2 (AP).--A motorboat was showered with machine gun bullets and sank, thirteen men were arrested and 1,200 cases of liquor, which police said were valued at $100,000, were seized, as three branches of the law swept down on alleged rum runners early today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The Navy Department's five-year aviation program was completed during the fiscal year 1931 by the acquisition of the 1,000th airplane authorized by Congress, a full year ahead of schedule, and it was accomplished at a saving of $23,307,150 of the original amount allotted, Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, Chief of Naval Aeronautics, said in his annual report to Secretary Adams, made public today.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 2.-- Yale's line-up against Holy Cross in the round-robin tournament in the Bowl on Saturday was announced tonight as follows by Head Coach Mal Stevens:

In anticipation of the inventory season, steel business has been curtailed in spots, but indications are that the "usual year-end dullness" will be less pronounced because of prospective automobile orders which are likely to be "on the mill books this week or the next," according to the weekly review of Iron Age.
John Hope Doeg, national tennis champion in 1930, received No. 1 ranking for 1931 in the list issued yesterday by the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--The promotion of home ownership through a reduction in cash requirements was suggested by President Hoover tonight in an address which opened the President's conference on home building and home ownership.

Judges of this year's American Institute Children's Fair, which opens this morning at the Museum of Natural History and will continue through Dec. 9, last night reviewed more than 400 exhibits turned in by New York children ranging in ages from 5 to 18 years.

WEST BADEN, Ind., Dec. 2.-- Minor league club owners today formally opened their fight to retire the present officers of their governing body, the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, while the player mart, both major and minor, started to produce business.

A hunting and fishing preserve of about 20,000 acres in the Ramapo Mountain section of northeastern New Jersey would be created and opened to the public next year, Erskine Hewitt, president of the Ringwood Company, 50 Church Street, announced yesterday.

Charlotte M. Fixel, former actress, who is suing to prove that she was the common-law wife of Abraham L. Erlanger so she can share in the theatrical man's estate, was prevented from testifying at the trial of her action in Surrogate's Court yesterday when Surrogate O'Brien held that Section 347 of the civil practice act precluded testimony by a claimant in a will contest.
The Federal Power Commission has an imposing title, but its jurisdiction is at present limited. It has control over power sites on the public lands and along the banks of navigable streams.
The Harvard Club scored a 5-0 victory over the Yale Club in a Class C, Group 2 match of the Metropolitan team championship squash racquets tourney on the loser's court last night.

HAVANA, Dec. 2.--Lou Reichers, who left Newark in the airplane Golden Eagle at 8:04 A.M. today in an attempt to break Captain Frank Hawks's record between New York and Havana, arrived at the General Machado Airport here at 3:05 P.M. His total flying time was 6 hours 41 minutes, thus bettering Captain Hawks's record, set on July 23, by 22 minutes.
Two theatrical performances scheduled for Sunday will go on without police intervention if their earnings are for charity, Commissioner Mulrooney said yesterday.
Dr. William H. Walker, brother of Mayor Walker, was examined yesterday by Jacob Gould Schurman, associate counsel to the Hofstadter legislative committee.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 2.--Mrs. Richard C. Clemson of Middletown, N.Y., defending champion, went to the final in the women's Carolina golf Tournament today when she defeated Mrs. Norman P. Rood of Wilmington, Del., in the semi-finals of the championship division, 1 up.

The field pieces at Fort Jay, which on Monday boomed out the retirement of Major Gen. Hanson E. Ely from the United States Army, sounded the thirteen-gun salute again yesterday morning to greet the new commander of the Second Corps Army Area, Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 2.--Charles M. Fickert, who was prosecutor in San Francisco when Tom Mooney was convicted in the 1916 bombing case, said here today that he still believes Mooney was guilty and should serve his sentence.

The question of creating a national organization to further the efforts now under way to make Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt the Democratic nominee for President next year is expected to be submitted to Mr. Roosevelt at conferences to be held next week at Warm Springs, ...

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2.--Five months of the government's fiscal year ended Nov. 30 with total receipts at $801,798,000 and expenditures of $1,672,331,000, leaving a deficit of $858,743,000, the Treasury Department said today.

With a night of dazzling riding and dangerous spills and with the din of Home 10,000 highly excited fans reverberating through the vast arena, the fifty-first international six-day bicycle race went past the half-way mark last night in Madison Square Garden with fourteen of the original field of fifteen teams awheel.

While attempting to distribute organization literature among 5,000 workmen employed by the Brooklyn Edison Company, a party of nine, including several theological students and two women, led by the Rev. Eliot White, formerly of the staff of Grace Episcopal Church, was attacked by several hundred youths and men yesterday afternoon and roughly handled until the police intervened.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP).--Unemployed marchers nearing the capital with demands upon President Hoover and Congress for unemployment insurance will gain their first impression of Washington from the police.

Miss Margaret Bourke-White, one of America's leading photographers of industrial subjects, who returned Friday from a tour of Soviet Russia, sums up the Russian situation in ten words in her book, "Eyes on Russia," a Simon Schuster publication.
While most business is quiet, it occurs to The American Architect, a magazine with a practical turn, that now is the time to get a new business started--commercial sound control.

LONDON, Dec. 2.--After touching a new low record at $3.25, sterling exchange on New York recovered to $3.38 this afternoon. The improvement in the pound caused much satisfaction in financial circles, and the stock markets again displayed cheerfulnees.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York A.C., eleven times national amateur pocket billiard champion, last night led Edward Fagin of the Engineers' Club by a margin of 91 points at the close of the second block of their challenge match being played at the New York Elks Club. Shoemaker now has a total of 254 to Fagin's 162.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2.--Entrance of the United States into the World Court before the convening of the disarmament conference at Geneva in February received the informal approval of the executive committee of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America at its annual meeting here today.

HANOVER, N.H., Dec. 2.--Dartmouth's football team practiced in subfreezing weather today for the round-robin games at New Haven Saturday.

The fourth in the series of "Evenings Abroad" for the benefit of the Outdoor Cleanliness Association took place last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. Is was called "A Night in Italy."

Strong support by bankers, as well as political backing, was predicted yesterday for the proposal to create a State banking commission, in which banking representation would predominate, to take over the authority of the State Superintendent of Banks. The proposal, made public on Tuesday by the advisory committee of the joint legislative committee on Banks.

LONDON, Dee. 2.--The British Government grappled with its own die-hard extremists in the House of Commons today while Mahatma Gandhi was keeping his pledge to study Prime Minister MacDonald's declaration "once, twice or even thrice" before committing himself.
Joseph Stella, absent since 1928 froze the local exhibition world, has re-entered the picture. A new group of oils is on view until Dec. 19 at the Valentine Gallery.

December real estate trading in Westchester has started with increased activity as compared with the closing days of November, according to transactions in a varied list of properties reported by brokers yesterday.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 2.--The most important and significant series of Catholic festivities ever staged in Mexico began yesterday. It was the official opening of the functions commemorating the 400th anniversary of the reported miraculous appearance of the Virgin Mary at Guadalupe.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Dec. 2.--Mrs. John V.S. Bloodgood, well-known Long Island horsewoman, has resigned as Master of Foxhounds of the Smithtown Hunt, a post which she had held for four years, it was disclosed yesterday.

PARIS, Dec. 9.--One of the first agreements for scientific research to be carried on by the institutions of two different governments has been signed at Paris by the Smithsonian Institution of Washington and the University of Toulouse.

After moving erratically most of yesterday, leading issues on the New York Curb Exchange closed the day with fractional losses. Trading was somewhat more lively than on the preceding day, but was still restricted.

LONDON, Dec. 4.--Mahatma Gandhi went to 10 Downing Street for a farewell call upon Prime Minister MacDonald today. He will leave London tomorrow for Paris. He will be the guest of his French biographer, Romain Rolland, at Villeneuve on Lake Geneva before embarking for Bombay, where he is due to arrive on Dec. 28.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--Russia will not become involved in the Manchurian controversy, because it desires peace above all else in order to develop internally, Boris E. Skvirsky, director of the Soviet Information Bureau, declared today upon returning from a tour months' visit to Russia.

Frederick H. Bedford, the last surviving member of an older generation of the family closely identified with the history of the Standard Oil Company, died suddenly yesterday of heart disease at Doctors Hospital. He was 77 years old and had been retired as a director and vice president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey since 1927.

TOKYO, Dec. 4.--The Chinchow situation is again menacing hopes for a settlement of the Manchurian issue. The League of Nations attaches the greatest importance to the prevention of further military action there, but the Chinese, now...

Lower temperatures and the approach of the holidays have had a stimulating effect upon business in the last week in most parts of the country, according to the reviews of the mercantile agencies. Added to this is a somewhat more optimistic attitude toward future developments, according to R.G. Dun Co.

While business complains of the hampering uncertainty of the antitrust laws, what keeps them on the statute books is the inability of those who oppose them to agree on a substitute, declared Gilbert H. Montague, attorney, yesterday at the second session of the symposium on the anti-trust laws that is being held by the Columbia University Law School.

Two of the strongest teams of the East and South meet in one of the season's most attractive football games today when New York University and the undefeated eleven of the University of Tennessee play at the Yankee Stadium for the benefit of the unemployed of New York and Knoxville. The opening kick-off is scheduled for 1:30.

Solomon Hollander, 27 years old, a suspended patrolman, on receiving a ten-day workhouse sentence in Special Sessions yesterday for roughly handling a woman prisoner in Central Park on Columbus Day, 1930, attempted to seize a pistol from the holster of a mounted patrolman standing in the court-room entrance.
CHICAGO, Dec. 4.--Economy will be rigidly enforced in the 1932 athletic program of the Western conference.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 4.--Charges that Vice President Jose Luis Tejada Sorzano had received graft money from the Standard Oil Company and the Richmond Levering Company, Inc., were heard in a five-hour session of the House of Representatives today. The galleries were crowded.

BERLIN, Dec. 4.--"Private debtsYes! Reparations--No!" will be the slogan of the National Socialists ("Nazis") if they ever gain power in Germany, Adolf Hitler told a gathering of foreign correspondents today...

MANILA, Dec. 4.--The Radical party's anti-Quezon demonstration was considerably more quiet today than had been expected, partly because heavy rains put out the torches of the paraders and dampened their enthusiasm generally.

MADRID, Dec. 4.--The statute to implement the constitutional article providing for divorce in Spain was submitted to the Cortes today by Provisional President Azana and Minister of Justice Fernando de los Rios.

New municipal financing will continue light next week, as issues totaling only $10,927,786 will come up for award. This is one of the smallest totals for a week this year, although fifty-three communities will be in the market with bonds or notes. This week's revised total was $15,115,340. The weekly average for the year to date is $32,989,394.

Seventy students and former students of the New York University College of Engineering and six members of the faculty of the college were initiated last night into Tau Beta Pi Fraternity, a national engineering honor society. The initiations were held at the installation ceremonies...

SANTA BARBARA, Cal., Dec. 4 (AP).--Charles MacVeagh, 71 years old, who was Ambassador to Japan from 1925 to 1929, died at his Winter home in Mission Canyon, near here, late today after a year's illness. He had been there about a month.

New public financing in the United States in the first eleven months of 1931, including issues of bonds, notes and stocks, but excluding domestic and Canadian municipal flotations, amounted to only $2,204,678,000,

Prices moved lower on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday in dull trading, after an opening which gave promise of a moderately strong market. Stock prices fluctuated in a narrow range, with leading utilities weak. The turnover was slightly larger than on the preceding day.

George P. Wiley, the Brooklyn accountant whose body was found in a burning automobile with a bullet through the heart on New City Road, Nyack, N.Y., early Thursday morning, committed suicide, according to detectives, who said last night they had completed their investigation.

WEST BADEN, Ind., Dec. 4.-- Colonel Jake Ruppert, boss of the New York Yankees, put his thumbs in his vest, leaned back in his easy chair and told the world tonight that he was all set to talk baseball on a 1931 business basis with that fellow Babe Ruth.

For the second successive year Notre Dame and Northwestern, the chief banner-bearers of mid-Western college football, capture the lion's share of All-America laurels for the 1931 season in the seventh annual Associated Press consensus.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--P. Hal Sims and Willard S. Karn of the Knickerbocker Whist Club of New York added another championship to their long collection tonight when the final standing in the national contract bridge par tournament for the trophy donated by the Cavendish Club of New York was announced.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Dec. 4.-- Anthony J. Siracusa, Assemblyman, who had been mentioned as one of a group of Republican legislators who had begun canvassing for support last month for a move to repeal the Hobart State prohibition enforcement act, announced today that he would introduce a resolution calling for its repeal at the special session of the Legislature Dec. 14.

Decisions affecting the rights of school teachers on their retirement were handed down by the Appellate Division yesterday. The court ruled that a correction may be made in the prior service certificate of a teacher when an error is discovered even after a year has elapsed.

The Lawrence High School girls' basketball squad will engage in a series of scrimmages next week in preparation for the opening game of its campaign, Mrs. Muriel Barber, coach, announced yesterday. Lawrence is scheduled to inaugurate its season on Friday in an engagement with the Long Beach six on the Lawrence court at Inwood, L.I.

To make his transition from the Yiddish to the English-speaking stage Maurice Schwartz needs nothing more than a suitable play. For he is an excellent actor, capable of something more than a sterile repetition of drawing-room amenities. He has strength, eloquence and magnetism.

As soon as the round-robin football in the Yale Bowl at New Haven is concluded this afternoon the Yale squad will go to Montclair, N.J., to attend the annual party in the nowfamed barn of Nicholas Roberts, banker and Yale graduate of the class of 1901.

Bond prices were pushed lower again yesterday on the Stock Exchange, a long list of issues touching new bottoms for the year and many selling at the lowest prices since their issuance. A few railroad liens rallied in the face of the lower trend in that group.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4.--Pennsylvania and the Naval Academy football teams will meet tomorrow on Franklin Field at 2 o'clock. The game will be the sixteenth of the series.

HAVANA, Dec. 4.--Several prominent members of the Opposition today repudiated the efforts of Dr. Cosme de la Torriente to make peace with President Machado. They declared he did not represent the sentiment of the majority of their forces and at present had no connection with the revolutionary junta still in existence in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4.--An avalanche of bills was taxing the capacity of the House bill room today.

The fifty-first international six-day bicycle race in Madison Square Garden passed into its final day last night with something of the old time atmosphere. For the first time since the grind began the Garden held a crowd of 14,000 fans, whose cheers reverberated through the building.

In anticipation of the approaching Christmas season the Roerich Museum on Riverside Drive has prepared an exhibition of religious art, all of the work by contemporary American artists. The exhibition ovens today and remains until Jan. 4.

Robinson, Engineer-in-Chief of the navy, who, in his annual report, made public today, added, however, that the maintaining of the machinery of vessels had been somewhat complicated during the early part of the year by the limitation placed on cash withdrawals from the treasury.

Grace La Mar, contralto, made her first appearance in recital in New York at the Town Hall yesterday afternoon. BERLIN, Nov. 25.--Two Deputies of the National-Socialist party spent a night recently in the building of the Landtag, the Prussian Dict. NEWTON, N.J., Dec. 12.--The Newton Academy basketball team increased its winning drive to three straight by crushing the Salesian Seminary quintet, 68--20, today. Bonkofski and Buchheit led the offensive with 17 and 13 points, respectively.

Five hundred men and women workers and friends of the thirtythree institutions belonging to the Metropolitan League of Jewish Community Associations will attend the group's dinner on Dec. 20 at the Hotel Commodore. M. Maldwin Fertig, president of the league, announced yesterday.

Landscapes and figure subjects by American painters are on view at the newly opened Schneider Galleries, on Madison Avenue. William Lee-Hankey, Robert Amich, Harry A. Vincent, Bruce Crane and William A. Ranger are among the artists represented in the exhibition.

THE Salzburg Festivals, which are given each season in the Bavarian city whose name has become synonymous with that of Mozart to the music-loving world, will take place next Summer during the period from July 30 to Aug. 31, 1932.

WEIMAR, Nov. 27.--The observances throughout Germany on March 22 of the 100th anniversary of the death of Goethe will have their natural centre here where the poet had his home the greater part of his life.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12.--While several thousand spectators thrilled to two great golf duels, George Von Elm of Los Angeles and Wiffy Cox, tall Brooklyn pro, became finalists of the $7,500 National Match Play Open Championship as the result of impressive semi-final victories today.

Ridder, newspaper publisher, as the result of a property settlement agreement she and Mr. Ridden had signed Friday guaranteeing an annual minimum income of $36,000 for the support of herself and their four children.

WICHITA, Kan., Dec. 12 (AP).-- G.F. Klampfer, 28 years old, was killed here today when a small monoplane of his own design and construction crashed from an altitude of sixty feet during a test flight.

The Jewish Education Association will celebrate the tenth anniversary of its founding tonight at the Hotel Biltmore. Judge Benjamin N. Cardozo of the Court of Appeals, Lieutenant Governor Herbert H. Lehman and Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, are honorary chairmen of the dinner sponsors. Borough President Samuel Levy and Judge Otto A. Rosalsky are honorary vice chairmen. There will be dancing after the dinner.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 8.-- Two years ago James Henry Scullin led the Australian Labor Party to overwhelming victory in the Federal elections. Mr. Scullin became Prime Minister, with forty-seven supporters in the House of Representatives, which comprises seventy-five members. A few days ago the Scullin ministry met defeat by thirty-seven votes to thirty-two.

KINGWOOD, W. Va., Dec. 12 (AP). --Mrs. Evelyn Harader of Clifton Mills, W. Va., so-called "dream slayer" of Cecil Michael, the village postmaster, was convicted of first degree murder tonight. She had said that she was influenced in shooting Michael by "messages" from birds and electric wires and in dreams.

In New York City and all along the Atlantic seaboard yesterday's Spring-like weather resulted in a doffing of Winter overcoats, with the populace wondering if Winter were in hiding or had just decided not to appear this year.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 12.--The Rev. Dr. William J. Egan, chaplain at St. Joseph's Orphanage, Dayton, Ohio, died at the orphanage in that city today. He was 58 years old. He was also professor of English at the University of Dayton.
Travis Brown's field goal in the second quarter was distinctive in several respects. It was the first he ever made and then he just about made it.

OTTAWA, Dec. 10.--More than four million Christmas trees grown in Canada are being shipped to the United States this season to be distributed through retail channels in fifteen States west to Iowa and south to New Orleans. The trees represent 700 carloads, about half originating in the Maritime Provinces and the remainder at various points in Quebec. They vary in size from small trees for table decoration to the proportions suitable for community purposes.

The West Englewood Gun Club will conduct a registered turkey shoot and kickers' handicap next Sunday afternoon, starting at 1:30 o'clock. The shoot is authorized by the Amateur Trapshooting Association.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., Dec. 10.-- Prohibition agents raided a resort here and the celebrators threw a bottle into the stove. The explosion which followed set fire to the building, and while the prohibition agents extinguished the blaze the revelers escaped.

Lorber, founder and president of the National Home for Jewish Children at Denver, announced yesterday at the Hotel Astor that a dinner and dance would be held there on Feb. 22 to celebrate the silver jubilee of the home and help meet a deficit of $50,000 accumulated during the last four years.

THE 1932 season of grand opera at Covent Garden in London may be the last, according to an announcement in The Morning Post of Nov. 24. The chief reason is financial difficulties.
MELTON MOWBRAY, England, Dec. 12.--Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald attended a meet of the Cottesmore hounds today at Burton Lazars, near here.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Dec. 12.--The Exchange Control Board, operating under a decree of President Olaya, will not permit the transfer next week of the next instalment of the service on the Farm Mortgage Bank's outstanding $14,000,000 in bonds which are guaranteed unconditionally by the National Government.

The Handel-Maatschappij H. Albert de Bary Co., N.V., of Amsterdam, affiliated with the Deutsche Bank und Disconto Gesellschaft of Berlin, reported yesterday total assets of 89,375,792 florins as of Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP).--A bill to establish Middlebrook Heights, near Bound Brook, N.J., as a historical Revolutionary Park was introduced today by Representative Eaton of New Jersey. Middlebrook Heights was the site of Washington's Winter quarters in 1777 and on June 14 of that year, the first American flag to be flown by the Continental Army was unfolded there.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 25.-- Straight football in the annual EastWest game here New Year's Day was predicted today by football followers after coaches of both teams admitted there was little possibility of grooming the squads for intricate manoeuvres.

LONDON, Dec. 25.--The joint issuance by Great Britain and France of an invitation to a reparations conference at The Hague came with unexpected swiftness today and marked the culmination of months of effort on the part of the British Government to hasten the reconsideration of Europe's debt tangle.

The presidential yacht Mayflower, recently sold by the Navy Department to private interests, will be rebuilt along her original lines and preserved as a national relic, Henry J. Gielow, Inc., naval architects, of 25 West Forty-third Street, announced yesterday.

With the part-time problem quickly shifting from the elementary to the secondary grades, Board of Education officials are speeding up the construction program of new high schools, it was revealed yesterday.

The Bronx Tigers will play their second home game in four days when they oppose the Philadelphia Arrows in a Canadian-American Hockey League game at the New York Coliseum tonight. Last Wednesday at the Coliseum the uptown skaters met the Boston Bruin Cubs, and lost by the score of 3--2.

Every district inspector in the six divisions of the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings was reassigned to a new district yesterday by Samuel Fassler, Building Superintendent, who said the changes were made "for the good of the service."

Specific and intelligent forecasts of the coming year are probably less easy on this occasion than in many years, perhaps in many decades. That is not because early prediction during this depression period has gone so far astray. There has never been a period of the kind in which it did not do the same.

Week's Retail Trade Favorable. Aided by favorable weather and the spending of some of the money received by consumers as Christmas gifts, stores here experienced a good response to clearance events this week, reports indicated yesterday. Apparel seemed to stand out, as was indicated in a considerable volume of reorders received during the week for many types of garments, including children's wear.

VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- The second annual liquidation of the Creditanstalt's affairs, if not the rehabilitation of the Creditanstalt itself, will be the decisive problem of Austrian economic affairs in 1932. It will be not so much a year of reconstruction as of methodical reduction for those industrial interests in which the national bank is concerned, but which have become definitely unremunerative, must be abandoned to gain means for developing those which still have promise.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Income for American farmers of $6,920,000,000 for 1931 was estimated today in a preliminary survey by the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture. This is 26 per cent below that received by farmers in 1930 and 42 per cent under the receipts in 1929.

Conforming to tradition, the New York Stock Exchange ended the year with a demonstration of strength in both the stock and bond markets, in the bond section the advance continued to the very close of the day, but stocks met a setback in the late mealings and finished with unimporant net changes but with a firm undertone.

Newton D. Baker, who has been mentioned prominently as a candidate for the Democratic nomination for President, reaffirmed yesterday his belief in the League of Nations as an essential instrument for the promotion and preservation of world peace.

Westchester County commuters and others who have been accustomed to park their automobiles free of charge in the station plazas of the New York Central Railroad will have to find a new parking place or pay a fee of 25 cents at six, at least, or the stations as the result of a new policy put into effect yesterday.

In the absence of any appreciable amount of activity in other branches of realty business, renting in Manhattan yesterday maintained to the end of the year its position as a salient feature of the 1931 market. Many of the lessees will take occupancy early in the new year.

Bringing the cover of his roll-top desk down with a bang -- for John J. McGraw is ever an impulsive man -- the white-haired manager of the New York Giants declared yesterday he knew of no better way to start a New Tear than with a vacation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- As Democratic leaders in the House continued their studies today of new sources of revenue and ways to reduce governmental expenditures to balance the budget, Speaker Garner announced that in all probability a tariff bill would be submitted to Congress for action in advance of the measure for additional taxation.

The movement of American manufacturing into Canada, stimulated both by the higher tariff walls erected in that country and also by the discount at which the Dominion's currency is selling in foreign exchange markets, has been the most significant development of the past year for the Dominion, according to Case R. Howard, manager of the foreign department of the Canadian Bank of Commerce.

IN the Department of the Interior during the past year, the conclusion has been borne down upon us that the time has come when the attention of the public should be redirected, in the light of the facts as they exist today, to the conservation of our natural resources.

After holding within a few points of previous closing levels for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange eased in the final dealings and ended at losses of 3 to 9 points on the day. A large selling order in the May delivery in the closing trading of the year Influenced the whole market, ending the list at the bottom.

PINEHURST, N.C., Dec. 31 -- George T. Dunlap Jr. of New York, intercollegiate golf champion, won the midwinter golf tournament today for the sixth time when he conquered Richard Wilson of Southern Pines, recent Georgetown University graduate, by 1 up.

The Heckscher Foundation, of which Mrs. August Heckscher was elected president three weeks ago, soon will put into effect a plan of affiliation with Columbia University, it became known, yesterday. The dental clinic of the foundation will be aided by the university's school of dentistry under the plan which was worked out following some unrevealed dissension which led to the retirement of the foundation's dental staff.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Stars who roamed over the nation's gridirons in spectacular fashion the past season will assemble tomorrow in two sturdy elevens for the seventh East-West game, a football classic played annually in the name of charity.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 31 ((AP)) -- Finland's Olympic skiing team, in charge of Armas Palmroos, leaves Saturday for New York on the Berengaria en route to Lake Placid and the third Winter Olympiad.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 29 -- The Tenth Federal Reserve District "jumped the gun" on business recovery in 1931 with a 25-cent advance in the price of wheat and a 40-cent advance in the price of oil, adding millions of dollars to the purchasing power of the territory, even if all the increment was not retained.

GENEVA, Dec. 31 -- League of Nations officials see no reason to believe the prospects of the commission of inquiry in Manchuria will be seriously affected by the Chinchow developments. Incidentally, they have heard them only meagerly through the press.

Stocks rose in early trading on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday, Bind after hesitation in the later dealings, closed with a series at rallies in a number of active issues, principally in the investment trust field. Trading was brisk, but not on as large a scale as the day before.

Despite the depression, railroad electrification made progress in 1931. The $100,000,000 project of the Pennsylvania Railroad was pushed, with the result that transportation by electricity between New York and Philadelphia is expected to start early in 1932.

Hans Lange, the assistant conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, directed that distinguished body on the occasion of its New Year's Eve concert in Carnegie Hall, in a program well chosen and ably interpreted. Mr. Lange began with Vivaldi's Concerto grosso in A minor, following the edition of Bernardino Molinari.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Banco do Brasil extended a credit today of approximately $20,000,000 to the National Coffee Council to be used in paying for stocks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Hoover, in a message of sympathy to Mrs. Sue Courts Oulahan, widow of Richard V. Oulahan, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died here yesterday, said:

OMAHA, Dec. 28 -- The coming year will bring many changes to the banking system of the West. The outlook clearly points toward continued shrinkage in the member of banks through mergers and suspensions -- some voluntary, others not, with the strong and larger banks surviving and giving a firmer financial base for farm country finances.

DAIREN, Manchuria, Dec. 31 -- Official Japanese circles have long since abandoned any pretense that the military campaign in Manchuria is directed merely at the elimination of banditry. An altogether open attitude reveals a complete determination to eliminate from Manchuria, the last vestiges of any Chinese authority except that set up under Japanese auspices.

HAVANA, Dec. 31 -- Seven political prisoners at Princlpe Castle were badly wounded and about twenty others sustained lesser injuries early this morning in a riot which broke out when some 200 trusties armed with clubs, knives and blackjacks and led by guards attempted to break up a protest meeting being held by the political prisoners in Block 11 against the reported killing of a student named Alpizar by the police several days ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The opinion that the business depression in the United States has largely spent its force and that substantial improvement would have been made by now were it not for recent European financial crises was expressed today by Secretary Lamont in a year-end statement on the business and industrial progress of the nation.

New securities marketed in December, although showing a moderate gain over November, were few and mainly State and municipal bonds. It was the third consecutive month in which no foreign or industrial bond issues were floated and no stock offerings were made.

WILMINGTON, Del., Dec. 31 (AP) -- An injunction suit was filed today in chancery court by Lawrence A. Slaughter of Washington, D.C., against the United Chemicals, Inc., of New York, a holding concern, seeking to have it enjoined from carrying out an exchange of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of the Westvaco Chlorine Products Corporation for its own preferred stock on the basis of one-third share of Westvaco for each share of United Chemicals.

The executives of leading utility and electrical organizations view with gratification what they call the remarkable manner in which these industries have gone through the past two difficult years. They believe that large purchases of equipment by the utility companies and the wages paid by them have been an important factor in keeping other businesses from even worse conditions than they actually experienced.

Federal and city authorities were on guard all over the country last night against what they believe to be a nationwide "Communist or anti-Fascist terrorist plot." Their vigilance was stirred by the delivery yesterday in Chicago, Detroit, Youngstown and Cleveland of six more deadly bombs, similar to the six mailed on Wednesday in Easton, Pa.

DALLAS, Texas, Dec. 29 -- General opinion among business men and bankers throughout the Eleventh Federal Reserve District is that the worst of the depression is past and that for the first six months of 1932 there will be slow but gradual recovery, with a slight increase in the level of commodity prices.

NANKING, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Despite Marshal Chang Hsueh-liang's retreat from Chinchow, China's new National Government was determined to defend that city against the Japanese advance, Eugene Chen, the Foreign Minister, said today.

LA MESA, Cal., Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Right Rev. Anson Rogers Graves, 89 years old, retired Bishop of the Episcopal Church, died at his home here today. He came to Southern California twenty-two years ago after serving as Missionary Bishop of the Platte District in Western Nebraska.
TOKYO, Dec. 31 -- In welcoming 1932, I have many impressions, but first of all I want to step into the new world.

The reorganization managers of the Southern Sugar Company announced yesterday that on and after Jan. 5 cash, first mortgage and collateral trust convertible bonds, Series A, B and C; ten-year convertible income debentures, voting trust certificates for shares of common stock and purchase warrants for United States Sugar Corporation will be ready for delivery to holders of certificates of deposit and participation warrants under provisions of the reorganization plan, dated April 1, 1931.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Dec. 31 -- With colored lights strung between the trees and each table adorned with gladioli, roses and snapdragons, the orange gardens of the Everglades Club presented a picturesque setting tonight for the dinner dance with which the club officially opened its season.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Dec. 30, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,023,000,000, an increase of $58,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $624,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1930.

Leaders of the nation's industries voice confidence in stabilization of business in 1932, in their forecasts for the new year. While exectuives of the large steel, automobile, oil and tire companies see little likelihood of a speedy return to prosperity, they believe that increased efficiency, deflated prices, and the gradual accumulation of demand for goods, have supplied the basis for slow improvement in 1932.
LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Yale clinched the three-game hockey series with the Army today by a 7-0 victory for its second straight triumph at the Lake Placid Club.

An investment trust can fill a useual function in the investment field rovided it avoids "dominating influences of a collateral nature," according to Floyd B. Odlum, president of the Atlas Utilities Corporation, in his first public pronouncement of policy for the trust that he as built from about $20,000,000 to about $85,000,000 through the acquiration of controlling interests in eleven other trusts in the last year.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Dec. 31 -- The woman reported missing from her stateroom on the steamship Providence of the Fall River Line when the boat docked at Fall River, Mass., yesterday was Mrs. Jane Remsen Thompson Schultz, wife of Carl H. Schultz of Sands Point, it was reported by the police here today.

In the death of Richard V. Oulahan, principal Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, American journalism loses one of its most distinguished figures. He managed, in a world of partisanship and personalities to maintain the balanced judgment of a reporter in search of facts.
THE aeronautical year 1931 has been outstanding for its experimentation and for the fulfillment of its development plans, as well as for the successful operating program which was carried out.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- Both France and Germany, it was announced here tonight, have accepted the British proposal that a new conference between Germany and her reparations creditors should be held at Lausanne, beginning Jan. 18. Premier Laval announced France's acceptance after a Cabinet meeting this morning, when the report of the Young Plan advisory committee was again considered.

Despite the fact that new offerings of State and municipal bonds were at a low ebb during the final quarter of 1931 in keeping with the trend of general market bond offerings, the volume of municipal financing for the entire year was but little below the 1930 total.

CHICAGO, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Nine persons, bound for sleeping quarters on a docked ship after attending church services last night, were drowned when the automobile in which they were riding rolled off into water twenty-eight feet deep at the Wisconsin Steel Company slip on the Calumet River.

Although the oil industry did not suffer as much from the general depression in the last year as did other major industries, its experiences were trying, due almost entirely to internal matters, which were brought to a climax by the rapid development of the new East Texas oil area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- President Hoover in extending New Year's greetings to the foreign service declares that 1932 "will bring many problems, but if we at home and abroad maintain our industry, courage and confidence in the principles and institutions which this country exemplifies, we can do much to promote economic recovery and international friendship."

DURING the past year the President's initiative in proposing a year's suspension of Intergovernmental debt payments was the outstanding event in our foreign affairs. Its acceptance by the peoples of the world and its ratification by their Parliaments and governments is a proof of the will of the nations to face together and recognize mutual problems through the present hard times.

THE republics of Latin America, in common with all other nations, are passing through extensive readjustments. Confronted with a severe economic depression and financial crisis, there is noticeable everywhere a desire and determination to effect economies and to balance budgets.

BALBOA, Dec., 31 -- Traffic in the Panama Canal in 1931 dropped to the lowest mark in six years, showing a loss of $4,600,000 in tolls, compared with 1930, and exceeding by only $135,292 the tolls collected in 1925 according to a preliminary report of the Bureau of Statistics today.

Louis (Crooked Neck) Levine, who for years dealt poker chips on the lower east side, came uptown to play Wednesday night. He did pretty well for a stranger to the cloth-covered tables of Broadway. In fact, at 4 o'clock yesterday morning a neat pile of chips showed that he was ahead some $400.

The banking firm of Kuhn, Loeb Co., announced yesterday that Benjamin J. Buttenwieser had become a partner in the firm, as of Jan. 1. Mr. Buttenwieser has been with Kuhn, Loeb Co. since October, 1918 and has held its joint power of attorney since 1928.

The Solemn peals of churchbells were added this morning to the city's innumerable voices that welcomed in the New Year. While Trinity's historic chimes were ringing in 1932 and their tunes being broadcast from Station WJZ, watch night services were in progress in many churches in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The last day of the depression year was observed cheerfully on the Stock Exchange today, most of the securities closing on a firm note. Business will not be resumed until Monday, as the Exchange will be closed on Saturday for redecorating.

The Stock Exchange call money market was steady all day. A rate of 3 1/2 per cent was maintained throughout, with money in good supply at the close, against which, however, demand was light. The 3 1/2 per cent renewal was the highest since Dec. 31 last year.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- Harvard University's sextet tonight captured top honors in the international intercollegiate hockey tournament at the Fair Ground coliseum by beating the Queens team, 3 to 1. The Crimson downed McGill in an overtime battle here Tuesday night.

VIENNA, Dec. 31 -- An improved version of Robert Louis Stevenson's "Suicide Club" was presented tonight in real life at an unusual and pathetic New Year's party when more than a thousand prospective suicides were entertained for the evening by the Beratungsstelle Fur-Lebensmude (the Advisory Centre for Intending Suicides).

The preliminary statement for Dec. 31, 1931, of the Second National, Third National and Fourth National Investors Corporations, affiliated investment trusts of the National Investors Corporation, was made, public after the close of business yesterday.
HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 31 -- Votes so far counted in Finland's referendum on the continuance of prohibition of liquor show a ratio of nearly 3 1/2 to 1 againgt the system.

BOSTON, Dec. 31 (A.P.) -- The Boston Bruins, clicking in their old-times form, tonight gave the Canadians a beating and took second place undisputed in the American group of the National Hockey League. On their previous visit to the Boston Garden, the world's champions were beaten by a 7-1 margin.

Unification of the rapid transit lines of the B.M.T. and Interborough, especially at the $474,500,000 price recommended by the majority of the Transit Commission, should be postponed for at least a year, Transit Commissioner Charles C. Lockwood declared yesterday in a dissenting report made public on the eve of his resignation.

A year ago it was generally believed that the reaction of 1930 was caused by the extravagances of the "boom" of 1928 and 1929. Today the popular explanation for our troubles is that they have been an inevitable aftermath of the war. But belief still exists that we are suffering the penalty of the speculative excesses of two or three years ago.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- According to the annual report of Building Inspector James W. Armstrong of Yonkers, plans for new buildings in that city for 1931 exceeded the previous year by $781,635. This was the biggest gain in Westchester County.

A moratorium on party affiliation is recommended by Mrs. Charles H. Sabin to women opposed to the Eighteenth Amendment, in the event that the party to which they respectively belong should refuse to bow to persuasion and include a repeal plank in its national platform next year.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Dec. 28 -- The textile industry throughout New England during 1931 has been much depressed, as it has been in the South. Although, mills in this territory manufacturing fine goods have pursued a rigid program of curtailment, goods have continued to pile up because of lack of demand and prices have been materially reduced.

Retail food prices as reported by the New York City Department of Public Markets are shown in the list below. These prices represent the best cash-and-carry values found yesterday by agents of the Bureau of Information of the Public Markets Department in medium-priced shops in all the boroughs of the city. All prices are given by the pound unless otherwise noted.

Governor PINCHOT called the Pennsylvania General Assembly in special session. It was to do exactly what he told it and nothing else. He wanted it to spend $120,000,000. It was to levy taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, billboards. It was to raise $35,000,000 by contributions for direct relief, shadowily to be repaid by the issue of "prosperity bonds."

The international grand prize racing cup owned by the Automobile Club of America, the outstanding trophy of its kind in this country, disappeared mysteriously between 2 P.M. Wednesday and 9:30 A.M. yesterday from the club's assembly room where it had stood for many years.

ALBANY, Dec. 31 -- Voicing confidence in the financial standing of the State, Governor Roosevelt wound up the official year in the executive office today with a New Year's mesage to the people in which he emphasized its strong position despite the widespread economic stress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Stamp collectors from all parts of the country gathered here to be among those to obtain the first issue of the George Washington Bicentennial series, which goes on sale tomorrow morning. Expecting the heaviest day's business in the history of commemorative stamp selling, the Postoffice Department completed arrangements today for all stamp windows at the city postoffice to remain open tomorrow from 7:30 A.M. until 6 P.M.

The Goldman Sacha Trading Corporation, which caused a sensation in the investment trust field in 1928 and 1929, and the Atlas Utilities Corporation, which has expanded spectacularly in the past year, have been brought into close association through the acquisition by Atlas of the largest individual stock interest in the former.

THE operations of the Department of Justice during the past year are reflected in the annual report of that department which covers the principal business transacted by the department and its various bureaus and divisions.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Big Bill Tilden said today he believed the United States has little chance of recovering the Davis Cup, emblematic of international tennis supremacy in 1932.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Morgan Jr. are at the Barclay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: If there could be any doubt that Senator Hiram W. Johnson of California does not know what he is talking about, his recent statement that Germany could pay her reparations if each German sacrificed "a beer a day" proves it.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 31 -- The horses racing under the colors of James C. Ellis dominated the Barron Collier Handicap, feature event at Tropical Park today. Leros won easily, finishing three lengths ahead of his stable-mate, the 4-year-old filly Ellice. E.A. Igleheart's Bay Angon was third.

The weather went on a rampage throughout the United States yesterday, the departure of the old year being marked by tornadoes in southern Mississippi, Arkansas and Alabama, a terrific gulf storm in Florida, snow, sleet and rain in fifteen western States between the Canadian border and the Texas Panhandle, Spring-like temperatures in Indiana, sub-freezing temperatures in the East and a slight earthquake along the coast of Washington.
On the last day of the year 218 contributions added $3,995.85 to the fund for the relief of the Neediest Cases and brought it to $267,758.02.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The third of a series of five test cricket matches between Australia and South Africa opened today with Australia dismissed for its first innings with the low total of 198 runs.
