Vincent Richards, seeded No. 1, was among the eight players who gained the quarter-final round yesterday in the opening day's play of the first national indoor professional tennis championship tournament at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory. The quarter-finals and semi-finals are to be played this afternoon and tonight and the final tomorrow afternoon.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The gruff but paternal voice of President von Hindenburg was heard tonight, in his first radio address encouraging and admonishing millions of German men and woman to "see it through" despite sacrifices of the past and those yet to come.
Leaders in European political life and other fields extend their best wishes for the New Year to the American people through The Associated Press of follows:

WILMINGTON, N.C., Dec. 31 (AP) -- Captain J.J. Adkins, for more than sixty years active in coastwise shipping, died last night at the age of 80. In the '80s he commanded a ship outfitted here by Alexander Jones on a filibustering expedition to Cuba to worry the Spaniards.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- The stock trading on the Chicago Stock Exchange during 1931 totaled 34,404,200 shares, it was announced at the close of the market today. This compared with 69,747,500 shares traded during 1930.

Holiday opera-goers filled the Metropolitan last night for a double bill of popular stars, Rosa Ponselle in "La Notte di Zoralma" and Glovanni Martinelli in "Pagliacci." Montemezzi's recent opera was delayed a half-hour for late diners. It brought back Santa Biondo who had been missing at the time of the little Peruvian melodrama's last previous hearing.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The Falls City Stable's Nim the Nymph captured the $700 Pass Christian purse, six-furlong feature of a mediocre card today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Impecunious Chicago balked by a "taxpayers' strike" for four years, stood face to face with possible bankruptcy today as the result of a decision voiding the county tax bills for 1928 and 1929.

Securities newly listed on both the New York Stock Exchange and New York Curb Exchange in December were few and although totals for both institutions were slightly greater than in the previous month they were far below those in December, 1930.

EL PASO, Texas, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Members of Albert B. Fall's family today greeted with ridicule and amusement the assertion of Harry M. Daugherty, United States Attorney General under the late President Warren G. Harding, that Fall was appointed Secretary of the Interior as a result of a forget telegram signed with Daugherty's name.

Although reaction was the rule in the commodity markets throughout the greater part of 1931, there are definite indications at the year-end that the decline has been arrested and that some measure of recovery may be expected during the coming year.

Withdrawals of gold for European accounts, aggregating $3,198,400, were reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The loss to the country's monetary gold stocks was more than offset, however, by a release of $3,351,300 of earmarked gold in New York, and from San Francisco word was received of the arrival of $7,958,000 of gold, of which $7,471,000 came from Japan and $487,000 from Australia.

THE operations of our naval forces during the past year were conducted with the following objects in view: To exercise and train the units of the fleet to the highest state of efficiency and to provide a nucleus for its expansion in case of national emergency; 'to protect American interests in disturbed foreign areas; to assist countries to which United States aid has been extended; and to cultivate friendly relations with foreign peoples.

PARIS, Dec. 31 -- The year ended with the Bourse on a dull depressed note, trading light and prices, on the whole, slightly lower, although the market showed moderate resistance. Realization on yesterday's premature report of the Franco-British debt accord was blamed partly for the weak tone.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- By virtue of victories today in the Winter games at the Lake Placid Club, Dartmouth's team is leading in the race for the President Harding trophy, which the Hanoverians captured last year. Dartmouth's point total is 25.

A crowd of 14,500 persons answered the call of charity last night and almost filled Madison Square Garden to witness New York City's leading college basketball teams take part in full evening of the cage sport.

BERLIN, Dec. 28 -- The revival of Germany in 1932 is recognized as depending primarily on the manner in which the international debt complications are adjusted. On the threshold of the new year the outlook for settlement is considered here to be fairly favorable.
Those Winter malevolences or Washington, D.C., * * * have struck the newspaper world a cruel blow. * * * A foremost Washington correspondent for more than two decades, at 64, is dead.
Friel's Chophouses, Inc., surrendered to Jerome J. Wilson the lease of the buildings at 579-81 Third Avenue and 201-03 East Thirty-eighth Street which was due to expire Dec. 31, 1948.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 -- It is a long-standing tradition of the steel trade that substantial recovery from depression is almost certain to begin either in March or in September and October. In no year of ordinary times has the "second-half peak" approached that of the first half -- perhaps with the technical exception of 1928.

ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands, Dec. 31 -- Governor Paul M. Pearson, who is on the way to the United States, is taking to Washington a resolution from the St. Thomas Harbor Board petitioning Congress to grant to the Virgin Islands permanent exemption from the application of the United States coastwise shipping laws.

The House of Commons is the unusual scene of the volume "Murder in the House of Commons" by Mary Agnes Hamilton, former member of Parliament and biographer of Premier MacDonald, who arrived in this country recently for a lecture tour.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Despite the opposition of four Federal Land Banks, a Senate banking subcommittee today approved a bill to permit postponement of the mortgage installment payments of needy farmer borrowers.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- The traditional report, retrospective and prospective, concerning the state of nations at the beginning of the new year, may best be put for Great Britain on Jan. 1, 1932, in the form of physicians' bulletins relative to the hope of recovery or lack of progress of distinguished patients.

Although there is a general hesitancy among leaders in the banking and insurance world to make specific forecasts for the new year, the statements below are not devoid of hope that the worst of the depression may be behind.

The closing month of 1931 marked the lowest total of bonds called for payment before their maturity dates in the year, aggregating $22,164,500, which compared with $27,600,000 in November and $69,240,000 in December, 1930.

As a result of the less active demand for steel in 1931, unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation declined more than 1,280,000 tons in 1931 to approximately 2,850,000 tons, the lowest level in more than twenty years. This compares with a decrease of 474,000 tons in the corporation's backlog in 1930 and an increase of 308,000 tons in 1929.

Gold withdrawals for foreign account, both by actual shipments, through the Port of New York, and by earmarking, reversed, in December, the movement of gold to this country which started in November following the severe drain on our supplies in October.

FROM the War Department's standpoint it is particularly significant and gratifying that in 1931 there has been no hint of threatened or actual violence, either external or internal in origin, which would indicate a necessity for the direct employment of the army.
HERSHEY, Pa., Dec. 31 -- St. Mary's College of Winona, Minn., defeated the Swarthmore Hockey Club tonight at the Hershey Ice Palace, 3 to 2.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Dec. 31 -- General Jiro Tamon sent his Japanese cavalry down from Kaopangtze to the Taling River, fifteen miles from Chinchow tonight, while the main body of his troops followed for what appeared to be the final drive on China's last Manchurian strong hold.

IN 1931, a year of unparalleled change and uncertainty, prohibition demonstrated the soundness of its foundation. The Eighteenth Amendment continues to be the valid law of the land consistently supported by the legislative, judicial and executive departments of the government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 29 -- Business leaders on the Pacific Coast are confident that any Improvement in national and international conditions will result in an immediate upturn in the West. There are few fundamental disorders, they say, the lumber situation in the Pacific North-west being the most disturbing, but this they attribute to conditions where building trades are inactive.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Dec. 29 -- Leading business men in this section evince marked reluctance to making a forecast for the coming year, not so much because they do not expect better conditions but because the form and the time of improvement are matters of guesswork.

The course of money rates and of Federal Reserve open-market policy developed two principal phases in the past year, corresponding approximately to the first and second semesters. In the first six months the chief factors were of domestic origin, while the world financial crisis that began in June exercised a more important influence in the last six months of the year.

CONGRESS having authorized extensions of the Natural History building of the United States National Museum at an estimated cost of $6,500,000, preliminary plans have been drawn under contract with the Allied Architects of Washington. The enlarged building will extend from Ninth to Twelfth Street, and the space for exhibits, laboratories and storage will be doubled.

Finland has cast out prohibition with an emphasis which the most ardent wets had not ventured to predict. The city vote for repeal of the present law is overwhelming, and it is taken for granted in the press and official circles that no reversal can be effected by the rural vote.
PASADENA, Cal., Dec. 31 -- After light workouts today the University of Southern California and the Tulane elevens went into seclusion for the annual intersectional gridiron combat tomorrow.

Brig. Gen. Henry J. Hatch, commander of the harbor and anti-aircraft defenses of New York Bay, died suddenly last night of an attack of Heart disease while playing solitaire in his apartment in the London Terrace, 470 West Twenty-fourth Street, where he resided with his aide, Lieutenant Stevens, who was with him at the time.
MELBOURNE, Dec. 31 -- Joseph Lyons, leader of the United Australia party, is expected to announce the following new Federal Cabinet tomorrow:

Governor ROOSEVELT is accustomed to work in the spotlight. Since he has become a leading Presidential possibility, in addition to being New York's Chief Executive, he is more a public cynosure than ever. While he is considering the charges filed with him by Judge SEABURY against Sheriff FAKLEY of New York County, many groups will be watching him.

For the seventeenth consecutive Week brokers' loans declined in the week ended on Wednesday to a new low for the year of $591,000,000, according to the statement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decrease of $20,000,000 brought the figure to a point 56.7 per cent below the Sept. 2 figure of $1,366,000,000.

HASTINGS, England, Dec. 31 -- With a clean-cut victory over Sir George Thomas of London, former champion of the British Chess Federation, in the fourth round, Isaac Kashdan, champion of the Manhattan Chess Club of New York, today assumed the lead, in the international masters' tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club in progress at the White Rock Pavilion.

With twenty-three victories and one draw out of twenty-four games, giving them a record of six consecutive match victories over their six rivals, the City College chess players easily won the championship tournament of the Intercollegiate Chess League, the two final rounds of which were contested yesterday at the rooms of the Marshall Chess Club.

TORONTO, Dec. 31 (AP) -- The highflying Toronto Maple Leafs turned back the Montreal Maroons, 3 -- 1, tonight for their seventh victory in their last ten games. They increased their lead in the International group of the National League to five points as the Canadiens of Montreal bowed to Boston.

Cheers for Sagittarius. "Old Moore," a hardy annual of England, whose 1932 Almanack has just been published, cheerfully announces that "the rising sun of prosperity throws Its first shafts of light onto the mountain-tops, dispelling the shadows, and a new day in the world's history begins."

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- In the extraordinary vicissitudes of the past eventful year, Great Britain's trade, both domestic and foreign, has suffered grievously. For the first time in many decades, the country can no longer count upon a credit balance in the year's international payments, visible and invisible, but instead will have to contemplate an adverse net balance reliably estimated as high as u100,000,000.
The outlook for the coming year is promising in the opinion of the presidents of leading commodity exchanges. Their views, in brief, are:

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 29 -- Business leaders in the Southeast are of the opinion that a definite upturn will be noted In the first three months of the new year and that by the end of 1932 conditions will have practically returned to normal. This optimism is expressed by men in every line of trade.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- A peep into a Britisher's life in 1950 was given today by Sir Hugh Allen director of the Royal College of Music. Addressing a conference of the Incorporated Society of Musicians, he predicted the ages of the human race would be roughly divided into three parts -- the old age known as B.C., the more modern age known as A.D. and a future age to be known as "B.B.C."

A deduction in bank clearings, carrying them even lower than in the preceding week, has been reported to R.G. Dun Co. for this week. The total was $4,630,517,000, or 39.8 per cent under that of a year ago.

Demanding that "the present-day contrasts in possession of wealth, comfort and power shall disappear," a New Year's message to its members and friends was issued yesterday by the General Conference of the Religious Society of Friends, asking consideration of the unemployment situation, world peace by disarmament and prohibition law observance.

The shipbuilding industry suffered serious losses in the past year and prospects of improvement are poor, according to the annual report of the National Council of American Shipbuilders, 11 Broadway, which is released for publication today. The start of the new year finds twentyfour sea-going merchant vessels of 254,600 gross tons and eight government vessels of 49,900 displacement tons under construction in privately owned American shipyards, the report shows.

CHICAGO, Dec. 31 -- Avery Brundage, president of the Amateur Athletic Union of the United States, predicted today in a forecast for The Associated Press that the year 1932 undoubtedly will prove to be the greatest year in the history of amateur sport in the United States.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -- There will be no letting down here in efforts to make the new year at least normal. "Whatever business is to be had we are going to make a strong effort to get it," one leading merchant said today. Those who closely study business conditions in this district see some darlc spots but they believe the tide is turning.

PETERSBURG, Va., Dec. 31 -- A writ of habeas corpus was denied today to J.W. Mapoles, editor of The Hopewell News, and he was remanded to the Hopewell jail to serve a thirty-day sentence for contempt of court.

A jury in Judge Freschi's part of General Sessions late yesterday afternoon returned a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree against Joseph Bauman, 20 years old, of 462 West Forty-ninth Street. Baumann shot and killed Carl Munich, 36, in the hold-up of a ciderstube at 405 West Forty-fourth Street last Aug. 6.

In 1930 it was suggested, or hoped, that an "Aristotle, Incorporated" might be created to integrate the truths which are beyond assembling by any individual living mind and would have "staggered even the stout Stagyrite." A million dollars, more or less, was gathered to aid the American Philosophical Society, the oldest of our American societies of such scientific scope, in assuming for the new world the role of ARISTOTLE singleminded in his day.

The book business of the country suffered less than almost any other industry last year and the outlook for the new year must be dominated by optimism, John Macrae, president of E.P. Dutton Co., said yesterday in a review of publishing in 1931.

THANKS to the work and wisdom of our fathers, we were but yesterday a prosperous people, living happily, respecting and observing a just code of laws and enjoying that "domestic tranquillity" which the Constitution sought to insure.
THE following program has been suggested to celebrate the arrival of the New Year:

A list of the leading candidates for the United States Olympic swimming team as compiled by Robert J.H. Kiphuth, American Olympic and Yale University swimming coach, with the aid of other mentors from all parts of the country, received the stamp of approval from the College Swimming Coaches' Association of America at the group's annual meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Business and banking leaders here decline to express opinions as to what a new year is likely to bring forth. An atmosphere of exceptional caution and conservatism is everywhere apparent. The general feeling is that business and finance in this district are so dependent for their trends upon the solution of national and international problems that prophecy at the moment is well-high impossible.
Publication of a folder on emergency food relief and child health by the United States Children's and Home Economics bureaus was announced yesterday.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29 -- While the Fifth Federal Reserve District is regarded as relatively better off than some others, business interests face 1932 with considerable uncertainty. There is some confidence that the worse has been seen, but caution prevents optimistic commitments.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Clifford Alien, former treasurer and chairman of the Independent Labor party, who followed Prime Minister MacDonald in supporting the National Government in Great Britain, received a peerage in King George's New Year's honor list issued tonight at 10 Downing Street.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 28 -- Farmore than usual at a year-end, revival in the farming States during the coming year depends on prices. Large yields alone are not sufficient; but even smaller crops, if they should bring good prices, will stimulate business activities.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- It is felt here that a relatively short cotton crop and a moderate increase in consumption may gradually reduce the immense prospective surplus to manageable proportions and bring about more profitable prices. Large destruction of cotton during the coming year by the boll weevils is not counted on, however, for as the weevils have been scarce in the past season, the hibernation of the insects will naturally be small.

Jan. 2 -- The United States Senate votes $15,000,000 for food loans to farmers, and on Jan. 16 $30,000,000 for modernization of battleships, having already passed. Jan. 14, the House bill carrying $45,000,000 for drought relief.

Declaring that earnings in the oil industry in 1931 were unsatisfactory and will continue so until crude oil production and refinery runs can be held down to market demands, Walter C. Teagle, president of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, in a year-end review of the petroleum industry adds that "a better understanding of the fundamental causes of the industry's position has put into play forces for their ultimate correction."

The performance of the general bond market during 1931, going from relatively high prices at the beginning of the year to its weakest point in December, was not only a source of keen disappointment to investors and investment bankers, but came as a distinct shock to many who never believed that prices could sink so low on issues not actually in default.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- So far as it is possible to forecast events for 1932, it is felt here that the United States is the country in which the evolution of crisis is the most advanced, and in which the deflation process has undoubtedly been most exaggerated. Therefore the first signs of world recovery are expected in America, and it is thought by financial Paris that they may soon be seen.

Featured by the addresses of President Thomas G. Gates of the University of Pennsylvania and other prominent educators and by the report of E.K. Hall, chairman of the football rules committee, the twenty-sixth annual convention of the National Collegiate Athletic Association adjourned last night after re-electing Dr. Charles W. Kennedy of Princeton as president and returning to office most of the other officials of the organization.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Belief is wide spread that the current depression has hit bottom. But the extent of the recovery in 1932 in the Seventh Federal Reserve District is believed to lie largely with three industries: motor, farm equipment and railroad.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 31 -- Winning their matches by identical scores, Mark Hecht of the University of Pennsylvania and E. Ramey Donovan, Fordham University, today earned the right to meet for the national junior indoor tennis title on the courts of the Fifth Regiment Armory tomorrow.

WE are such creatures of habit that hopeful views in times of depression are apt to be as unpopular as pessimistic views in times of apparent prosperity. As a matter of fact, every one knows that disasters come out of clear skies, and calm weather out of storms.

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The determination of the present German Government to maintain the reichsmark on the gold standard is more likely nowadays to find the backing of German theoreticians and of general business judgment.

Construction of the upper part of the Sixth Avenue subway, north of Twenty-ninth Street, is likely to be ordered by June of this year, it was learned yesterday. Completion of the line, which is part of the first half of the city's independent subway system, has been regarded as desirable, as soon as possible, in order that traffic from the Eighth Avenue subway may be routed through the Sixth Avenue line.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Dec. 29 -- Busines leaders are extremely loath to risk predictions as to when business will improve. The feeling prevails that the deflation, although it has gone far, is not complete; that early in the new year a substantial number of businesses will be wound up and that almost every line of industry will be conducted on more conservative lines than ever before.
CHICAGO, Dec. 31 --A confident feeling prevailed today in the wheat pit on the Board of Trade and at no time were the deferred futures below the finish of the previous day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31-- A decline of $2,379,000,000 in the value of the foreign trade of the United States during 1931 as compared with 1930 is reported in a review of the year by Frederick M. Feiker, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce. Exports dropped $1,418,000,000 and Imports $961,000,000.

The charge that Albert B. Fall was appointed Secretary of the Interior as the result of a forged telegram sent to President Harding by Mr. Fall and signed with the name of former Attorney General Harry M. Daugherty is one of the "sensational" disclosures in the book, "The Inside Story of the Harding Tragedy," to be published next month, it was learned yesterday at the home of Thomas Dixon, 867 Riverside Drive.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Dec. 31 -- A week-end of social festivities opened here today, the feature being the annual New Year's Eve ball at the Tuxedo Club. Nearly every resident in the Park is entertaining guests.

Governor Roosevelt, according to information from Albany, regards the letter from Samuel Seabury, counsel of the Hofstadter legislative committee, seeking the removal of Sheriff Thomas M. Farley as the equivalent to formal charges. The Governor probably will call on Sheriff Farley for an answer, it was said yesterday.
All the markets in the United States and abroad will be closed today in observance of New Year's. In this country most of the important exchanges will reopen tomorrow, as will the banks.

As a result of a thorough liquidation of the farmers' mortgaged indebtedness, which has been going on for two years, the Northwest can look forward to years of real sound business, according to Lyman E. Wakefield, president of the First National Bank in Minneapolis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was pleasantly surprised by the number of responsive comments I received after publication of my letter of Dec. 17, referring to the possible dangers in preserving, or in amending as now proposed, our statute against perpetuities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Satisfied that the prices at which many types of bonds frequently sell in the market do not represent their true value, John W. Pole, the Controller of the Currency, is continuing the policy adopted some time ago of having national bank examiners value such bonds at their intrinsic value in appraising assets.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Representative Rainey, Democratic leader of the House, has declared war on "entrenched" wealth, whatever that may be, and the House blunderbusses in both parties, not forgetting the Progressives, whom I did not intend to slight, are hastening to enlist under his banner.
CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Japanese troops were only fifteen miles away from this walled city tonight and the Chinese Army was pouring out in disordered retreat.

PARIS, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Paris is paying its respects to the new year as this is being written. Outwardly there is no evidence of excitement or celebration. From a balcony over a main boulevard one sees uncrowded sidewalks with the people walking along quietly, almost listlessly.

Federal prohibition agents began their annual New Year's Eve celebration with a grand flourish yesterday when they raided the Royal Box at 17 West Fifty-sixth Street. But, though their descent upon this, one of the newest and most elaborate of the night clubs, seemed to presage an unusually busy evening, no other important raid was made.

Cardinal Hayes in a New Year's letter which will be read in all his 452 churches on Sunday attributes his recent designation as Cardinal Protector of the Catholic Near East Welfare Association to the generosity to foreign missions of the laity of the Archdiocese of New York.
HYDERABAD, India, Dec. 31 (AP) -- A struggle of Oriental kings for two Moslem princesses was revealed today as the sons of the Nizam of Hyderabad brought their brides home to a cloistered existence.
LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- Premier MacDonald sounds an optimistic note in his New Year message to Great Britain.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Arrangements were completed today for the funeral of Richard V. Oulahan, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who died of pneumonia yesterday at his Georgetown residence, 1518 Thirty-first Street, Northwest.

BECAUSE of the unsettled conditions in the country generally it has not been my practice since I came into office as Secretary of Labor to make predictions concerning changes which are to come in the general situation of industrial affairs in our land.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 31 -- Isolation and observation for the first time under the microscope of the hitherto invisible germ of infantile paralysis, as well as growth and cultivation of successive generations of the germ outside the animal organism, was reported here today before the annual meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

Vincent Coll, the beer-runner, who was rearrested on charges of robbery and violation of the Sullivan law last Tuesday, following his acquittal of murder in the 107th Street baby killing, left the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday afternoon a free man, after posting $60,000 bail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- The loss suffered by journalism in the death of Richard V. Oulahan was a theme of editorial comment in all the daily newspapers of the capital today.
ST. JOHN'S, N.F., Dec. 31 (Canadian Press) -- According to The Daily News this morning, stipulations made by the Canadian banks in offering funds to the government include the following:

As if to celebrate appropriately the passing of a year of melancholy memories, the bond market advanced spiritedly yesterday and the share market presented a firm front in the face of a steady stream of realizing and tax selling. Grain prices advanced moderately.

Figures made public yesterday by District Attorney Thomas C.T. Crain on the work of his office and General Sessions in 1931 reveal that, since the opening of the Winter term of the court last Oct. 1, the number of prisoners in the Tombs awaiting indictment, trials or sentences had been cut down from 613 to 395.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 31 -- Production of crude petroleum in the United States in November amounted to 72,851,000 barrels, a daily average of 2,428,000 barrels, the Department of Commerce announced today. For the month it was a slight decline from October, although a gain of 71,000 barrels in the daily average output occurred.

Building plans filed in New York City during 1931 totaled approximately $293,000,000, a decline of $57,000,000 over the 1930 total of $350,000,000, according to a survey of figures in the Building Bureaus of the five boroughs yesterday.

PROMOTION of the safety, health and efficiency of labor through legislation is a well-established function of American government, both State and national. That the importance of this function constantly increases is indicated by the more than 500 labor laws enacted in 1931 by Congress and the forty-six State Legislatures.
Sales of several flats and taxpayers were reported in the New Jersey metropolitan area yesterday, in addition to a variety of dwelling deals.

The general slump in trade and securities during 1931 was reflected in sweeping declines in the prices of stocks and bonds listed on the New York Curb Exchange. Recurrent waves of liquidation brought many Curb Exchange securities to the lowest levels in more than ten years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The proposal of Senator Borah with reference to the reduction of salaries of government employes has two sides. It was not until 1927 and 1928 that government workers received salaries which lessened the gibes of carpenters, bricklayers and automobile salesmen at "government paupers."

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- A decided change in spirit was seen in the way in which London celebrated New Year's Eve this year. It was less a case of seeing the old year out than an eagerness on the part of all to welcome in 1932, a year which it is hoped may bring a change in the hard times which have dogged Great Britain, along with the rest of the world.

More than a score of Long Island Sound yachtsmen yesterday began digging about for North Pole raiment to use in the sailing dinghy race scheduled for tomorrow. The affair, first proposed in little more than a jest, caught the fancy of so many skippers that more than one contest may be held, there being more volunteers than boats.
The text of President von Hindenburg's radio address, as heard in rebroadcast here and confirmed by cable from Berlin, follows:

The retirement of six veteran employes under the New York Stock Exchange's pension plan was announced yesterday. They will receive full pay for the unexpired period of sick leaves due them to the amount of a year and a half, and thereafter the regular pension of from 50 to 75 per cent of full salary, depending on length of service.

Window dressing by member banks preparatory to the publication of their year-end statements of condition resulted in a heavily increased demand for Federal Reserve Bank credit in the week ended on Wednesday and was the principal factor governing changes in the position of the Reserve System as reported yesterday.
a scientific trip via Berlin and Leningrad to the Arctic.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- In the view of leading business interests here, prospects for 1932 are regarded with more confidence than a year ago. Many reasons are assigned for this belief. We have passed through two years of the most drastic liquidation in all lines of trade, in agricultural products of every kind, and in stocks and bonds.

Walter Hampden, who recently concluded a road engagement in Barrie's "The Admirable Crichton," will make an extended tour in "Cyrano de Bergerac," in which he first successfully appeared on Broadway eight years ago. As actor-manager Mr. Hampden will begin, bis transcontinental tour in the Edmond Rostand play, adapted by Brian Hooker, on Jan. 30 in Richmond, Va.
New York said good-bye to a cynic last night and welcomed an optimist. Or such was the hope and the expectation.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 31 -- Miss Katharine Winthrop of Boston will defend her national junior girls' indoor tennis championship at the Longwood covered courts on Saturday against Miss Helen Jones of Swampscott, as a result of the semifinal matches today.

Reports from the twelve Federal Reserve districts on the business prospects for the coming year reflect a widespread feeling of confidents among bankers and business men, tempered by a cautious refusal to make specific predictions. For the most part the belief prevails that the major domestic readjustments have been completed and that recovery will be somewhat slow, contingent to a large extent upon the recovery in international affairs.

MOSCOW, Dec. 31 -- In the foreign economic field 1931 has not been too satisfactory a year for the Soviet Union, although it is asserted here that the advantages outweigh the disadvantages, which, furthermore, were caused by circumstances over which the Soviet had no control; namely, the world depression.

Further tributes were paid yesterday by leaders in many fields to the memory of Richard V. Oulahan, chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES, and dean of the corps of correspondents at the national capital. Those tributes follow:

LONDON, Friday, Jan. 1 -- India faced a revival of civil disobedience following the refusal of the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon to discuss with Mahatma Gandhi the recent drastic ordinances for the suppression of violence, according to the London Daily Herald's Bombay correspondent.

A new calendar system, described as "the most important and farreaching reform thus far made" in the procedure of the Supreme Court in New York County, was made the subject of a special announcement yesterday by the law reform committee of the bar association.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Prohibitionists and anti-prohibitionists alike admitted tonight as the returns came in from the country-wide referendum that 1932 was likely to be a wet year for Finland.

EASTON, Pa., Dec. 31 -- Charles V. Weaver, 49 years old, of Easton, explosives expert who was injured yesterday afternoon while trying to open one of the infernal machines mailed at the Easton postoffice, died at 8:02 tonight at the Easton Hospital.

MIAMI. Fla., Jan. 1. -- Mrs. H. De True's Arras, a consistent plater, stepped out of his usual class today to win the New Year's Handicap, feature race at Tropical Park. The racing was held under ideal weather conditions, with the holiday bringing out the largest crowd of the meeting.
JACKSON, Miss., Jan. 1 (AP) -- A tornado and flood waters have combined to strike death, injuries and suffering to two States in the South.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 1. -- Mark Hecht, University of Pennsylvania, retained his national junior indoor tennis championship by defeating E. Ramey Donovan of Fordham University, 7-5, 6-0, 6-4, in the final match on the courts of the Fifth Regiment Armory today.

FOR years John Arnold Heydler, president of the National League, preserved an air of dignified calm. Nothing ruffled or excited him. He was magnificently placid in his easy-going and efficient way. Even through the era of American League supremacy in world's aeries warfare, his attitude was resignation as defined by Henry David Thoreau, calm desperation.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., Jan. 1. -- The New Bedford soccer team defeated the New York Giants today in the first of two games to decide the championship of the American Soccer League for the past year, 8-3.

The debutantes' New Year's dance, an annual subscription entertainment arranged for girls who have been introduced in the course of the season, was held last night in the ballroom of the Pierre under the direction of Mrs. Thomas Webster Edgar and a group of mothers of many debutantes.
All important markets in this country and in Europe were closed for business yesterday. The closing of the New York banks for the legal holiday made the absence of financial transactions complete.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Conscious of sharp scrutiny, Democrats are rehearsing for the prelude to their Presidential campaign.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- An assertion that the Democratic National Committee and its treasurer, James W. Gerard, "are making a sorry spectacle of themselves in attempting to explain why they violated the Federal corrupt practices act," in reporting the payroll of the Democratic National Committee headquarters in New York City in 1928, was made tonight by Representative Will R. Wood, chairman of the Republican Congressional campaign committee.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 1. -- R. C. J. Goode of McGill University won the two-mile snowshoe race, the only event contested today in the Winter games at the Lake Placid Club, in which the President Harding trophy is at stake.

KEARNY, N.J., Jan. 1. -- The first 1932 meeting of the Town Council, held today at the high school auditorium for the second installation of Mayor Arthur H. Jones, became the most riotous session Town Clerk William B. Ross said he had seen in his thirty-one years in office, and ended when many of the 1,600 spectators worked themselves into a furor of denunciation and adjournment seemed the only alternative to a more violent demonstration.

The great progress made by Negroes in America since the Civil War was extolled yesterday by four speakers at a ceremony commemorating the sixty-seventh anniversary of the publication of President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation. The exercises were held at St. Luke's Methodist Episcopal Church under the auspices of the Frederick Douglass Chapter of the John Brown Memorial Association.
NEW YORK. The Ambassador to Italy and Mrs. John W. Garrett will arrive today from Baltimore and will be at the Pierre until they sail for Rome.

HAVANA, Jan. 1. -- The Superior Electoral Tribunal suspended today the reorganization of political parties in the province of Oriente, which in conformity with the electoral code, should begin on Jan. 3, and this action la looked on as tantamount to suspension of reorganization activities throughout the island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- A last-minute effort to put through a naval construction bill at this session of Congress has, been decided on by "adequate navy" men in the Senate and House and on Monday or Tuesday two building programs, one covering a period of ten and the other of fifteen years, will be submitted to the House Committee on Naval Affairs by the Navy Department.

ATLANTIC CITY. N.J., Jan. 1 -- A young woman, identified as Mrs. Mae Blodgett, 25 years old, of 555 West 160th Street, Manhattan, removed her coat, hat and shoes and committed suicide here tonight by walking into the sea near the Steeplechase Pier.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- Germany's forth-coming shipments of 150,000 tons of nitrate of soda to France will be considered payments in kind toward the reparations account. Just how the proceeds, of the sale, amounting to about $500,000 are going to be applied could not be ascertained from the Ministry of Agriculture which thus far has refused to divulge any terms of the nitrate accord signed last Sunday.

A concurrent resolution providing for the continuance of the Hofstadter legislative committee will be introduced at Albany soon after the Legislature convenes next Wednesday by Senator Samuel H. Hofstadter and Assemblyman Hamilton F. Potter, chairman and vice chairman, respectively, of the committee.

Developments in the last year in the nickel industry indicate continued growth of diversity in uses of the metal, which will be appreciated more generally as business returns to normal, according to Robert C. Stanley, president of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd.

Two acts of Puccini's "La Boheme" were broadcast yesterday afternoon from the Metropolitan Opera House, through a nation-wide network of nearly seventy stations of the National Broadcasting Company, and were relayed across the sea by shortwave transmitters.

OTTAWA, Ont., Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- "Judging by the trend of government statistics, Canada enters the new year with a feeling of quiet confidence and optimism which was not apparent at the beginning of 1931." a statement issued by the Department of Trade and Commerce said tonight.

After being held scoreless for two periods, the New York Rangers launched a last-session rush which enabled them to defeat the Detroit Falcons in a National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden last night.

DOVER, Del., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Three receivers were appointed yesterday for the American Commonwealths Power Corporation, large public utility system with executive offices in New York, St. Louis and Grand Rapids, Mich.

To help mothers who are getting money from relief agencies, and also to guide those whose husbands are earning very little, the United States Children's Bureau and the Bureau of Home Economics have issued a joint folder telling how to divide a dollar among various kinds of food.

Unemployment conditions along the waterfront of New York are worse today than they ever have been in the last thirty-six years, the Rev. Dr. Archibald R. Mansfield, superintendent of the Seamen's Church Institute, 25 South Street, said yesterday. During the past year the institute gave relief to more than 7,000 seamen and made nearly 25,000 loans, while providing a home for sailors and protecting them during periods of unemployment.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 1. -- With the moratorium on the foreign debt expiring today and no money in the treasury with which to resume payments, Congress had before it a new provisional budget reducing expenses, a bill to extend the moratorium, and a bill to divert funds collected for the foreign debt.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- In a New Year's statement today Representative Byrne, chairman of the Democratic National Congressional Committee, called attention to his party's victories last year in Gubernatorial and special Congressional elections and asserted that this record warrants confidence that the Democrats will be victorious in the coming Presidential election.

BUFFALO, Jan. 1 -- A proposal that a college student be named by President Hoover as a member of the American delegation to the Geneva disarmament conference next month was made today by Professor Ralph Harlow of Smith College at a session of the quadrennial convention of the Student Volunteer Movement as the delegates endeavored to map a program that would aid in insuring world peace.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 -- Asserting that the authorities had found that there is as much or more drunkenness now as there was before prohibition, Cardinal Dougherty, speaking today at a New Year's reception given for him by sixty societies, called on Catholics of the diocese for a revival of temperance and total abstinence societies.

NIJNI-NOVGOROD, Russia, Jan. 1 (AP) -- Soviet Russia's newest and largest automobile manufacturing plant, reared in record time by American engineers to turn out Ford cars, officially began operation today after ceremonies.

TOKYO, Jan. 1. -- Unrestrained pessimism is the keynote of virtually all the New Year messages given out by Japanese politicians and business men. Nearly all believe that 1932 will be worse than 1931.

The uses of electricity in agriculture, and experiments looking to the extension of such uses in the future, were described last night by Dr. Willis R. Whitney, director of the General Electric Company's research laboratories. His address was delivered before the WGY Farm Forum, over that station, at Schenectady.

The first week of the new year will be featured by offerings of $18,438,358 of new municipal issues by fifty communities throughout the country. This week's revised total amounted to 513,714,801, and the weekly average for 1931 was 531,729,034. Next week's schedule of new issues up for award will represent a slight increase over the total offered during the first week of 1931.

On the first official transit plan, published only a few days ago, we now have the first official comment. It is in the form of an analysis of the plan by Commissioner LOCK-WOOD, on the eve of his resignation to take his place on the bench. He notes a special exception to the guarantee clause, which he considers either unconstitutional or impracticable.

Again New York is to see the art of Waslaw Nijinsky, but this time it will be the art of Nijinsky as a painter, not as the famous young Russian dancer who held audiences enraptured in the Manhattan Opera House on his last visit here in 1916.

Dr. Ray Robinson Losey, ophthalmologist, of 67 Park Avenue, died yesterday afternoon in the Murray Hill Sanitarium after a stroke which he suffered on Wednesday while attending a patient in his office in the same building with the sanitarium at 30 East Fortieth Street. He was 40 years old.

The fund for the relief of the Neediest Cases received $1,514.30 yesterday from sixty-seven readers of THE NEW YORK TIMES whose letters indicated that they were trying to make up for those who cannot afford to give.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- A suggestion that the United States might find it advisable to accept a combination of direct and budgetary limitation as a basic principle at the general disarmament conference, which will convene in Geneva on Feb. 2, is included in a list of recommendations on policy submitted to Secretary Stimson by technical advisers to the American delegation to the conference.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 1. -- While her husband, unaware of impending disaster, gaily welcomed the New Year at a ball of the Veterans of Foreign Wars here, Mrs. Fred Howland, 32 years old, quietly left the party early this morning and returned to their home at 10 Jefferson Place, where she ended her life.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Three New York youths, members of a basketball team, Mrs. Anna Pickard, 70, of Cherry Valley, and Miss Catherine Steels of East Springfield are in a local hospital with injuries received today in an automobile accident on Cherry Valley Turnpike.

The honor of being the first baby born in New York City in 1932 very probably belongs to the ten-pound son of Mrs. Hilda Brown of 161 Buffalo Avenue, Brooklyn, who came into the world at exactly 12:01 A.M. at the Unity Hospital, 1,545 St. John's Place, Brooklyn.

NEWTON, Mass., Jan. 1. -- The Rev. Louis J. Gallagher was appointod president of Boston College today as successor to the Rev. James H. Dolan, who has been transferred to Georgetown University on leave of absence.

PINEHURST, N. C., Jan. 1. -- Charles A. Foehl Jr. of New York and Miss Mary Mason of Elmira, N. Y., won the annual young people's mixed foursome gold championship tournament today with a net score of 70. They had a gross score of 88 and received a handicap of 18.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 -- Because he was the first to learn all the secrets of nerve growth by studying nerves inside animal organisms, thus settling a scientific controversy lasting for seventy years, Dr. Carl Caskey Speidel of the University of Virginia Medical School received today the $1,000 prize of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, given for "a notable contribution to science."

National and intercollegiate champions as well as one world's recordholder will vie with lesser lights of the track tonight when the 1932 track and field season opens at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn with the staging of the sixth annual Columbus Council K. of C. games.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A suggestion has been made by Senator Kean that a Canadian member be placed on the Federal Reserve Board, with a view to stabilizing the dollar between the two nations. This would appear to be an excellent idea, in my opinion.

Lawrence Tibbett, baritone of the Metropolitan Opera Company, whose rendition of love songs in romantic roles has been a feature in recent years of the motion pictures, and Mrs. Jennie Marston Burgard, daughter of Edgar L. Marston, retired banker of this city and Los Angeles, were married yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's brother, Hunter S. Marston, 151 East Seventy-ninth Street.

It cannot be said that the speeches to this week's convention of economic associations at Washington did much to clear the air. Indeed, the question what is the cause and what the remedy for existing financial difficulties may have been obscured, not clarified, by the effort to place blame on the Federal Reserve.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., Jan. 1 (AP). -- Testimony as to incendiary speeches urging miners to "get rid of Jim Daniels and his gun thugs," was offered in evidence here today at the murder conspiracy trial of William H. Hightower.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Asserting that the State's $20,000,000 relief fund will aid only a part of the 1,500,000 needy unemployed. Governor Roosevelt issued a call today to municipalities and individuals throughout the State to respond to the additional requirements for meeting distress this Winter.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Carrying out the ethics of his profession, Dr. Francis X. Dercum, former neurologist, in his will made public today, ordered burned the private case records of his patients, including those of Woodrow Wilson. He was among the specialists called into consultation, during the President's last illness.

As an army transport carried James Finck, with four citations for bravery, back from, the World War in 1918, an erroneous report of his death in action preceded him. His wife, receiving the report, drowned their 4-year-old child and committed suicide by hanging.

The career of CHARLES P. SCOTT of The Manchester Guardian was virtually rounded out two years ago when he retired at the age of 83 and turned over the management of the paper to younger hands. His death now seems like the closing of an epoch.

Martin Beck, former president of the Orpheum Circuit, who left vaudeville several years ago when he built the legitimate playhouse hearing his name in West Forty-fifth Street, will return to that field immediately, according to announcement from the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation.

The downward sweep of foreign dollar bond prices in 1931 to levels considered unbelievable when these issues were marketed, was the natural aftermath of falling commodity prices, the slump in world trade with the consequent drop in foreign exchange rates and, in the case of certain Latin American countries, politlcal unrest.

Ruth Page gave the first of two holiday programs of dances at the Booth Theatre yesterday afternoon. The presentation was designed especially for children. Its chief feature was Marcel Delannoy's new ballet of "Cinderella," which was composed especially for Miss Page and presented for the first time by her last Summer at the Ravinia opera season, just outside Chicago.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 1. -- With Mexico City Catholics starting a churchless New Year, the period for registration of priests closes tomorrow at midnight, but tonight none registered and all Catholic services remained suspended.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- A way out or the present trade stagnation would be the formation of a "sane tariff" group of nations, according to Sir Walter Layton, editor of The Economist and British representative at the recent Basle conference of experts on the Young Plan.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 1 -- There is every indication that after the Japanese troops succeed in occupying Chinchow they will be faced for many weeks with the task of pursuing and eradicating bandits in Manchuria.

LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Jan. 1 -- Yale took the third and final game to sweep its college week series with Army at the Lake Placid Club today, winning 8 to 0. Zitzman, Army goalie, had a total of twenty-eight saves.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Need for "awakening" the nation from its "fool's paradise" of inadequate aerial defense was given today by Major Gen. James E. Fechet as the reason for his retiring from the army.

The survey of the book industry which has been conducted during the past sixteen months under the direction of O.H. Cheney has been completed and the manuscript is now being printed for distribution to the book trade and to the newspapers some time next week.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Jan. 1. -Irving Jaffee of New York carried of the lion's share of the honors by winning the Middle Atlantic outdoor speed skating title, today and, a few minutes later -- his title assured -- he captured the three-mile Donoghue memorial race.

More than 500 labor laws were enacted by Congress and the forty-six States that held legislative sessions in 1931, according to a survey announced yesterday by the American Association for Labor Legislation, 131 East Twenty-third Street. Unemployment relief, accident compensation, old-age pensions and labor's right to organize were among the things covered.

Armour Co. of Illinois report for the fiscal year ended on Oct. 31, 1931, a consolidated loss of $17,339,136, after depreciation and interest. After the payment of dividends of $5,519,928 on preferred and-guaranteed stocks during the year and a charge of $77,262 lor losses and reserves not applicable to the year's operations, there was a reduction of $22,936,326 in the company's surplus account.

An increase of 17 1/2 per cent over 1931 in building construction is forecast for this year by the Copper and Brass Research Association. With public works excluded, the total for the United States is estimated at $3,420,000,000, or more than $500,000,000 above the 1931 total of about $2,909,000,000.

The Old Year could hardly have given a more cheering parting word of news to anxious parents than that announced at the New Orleans meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science on the last day of 1931. If parents could be assured that this discovery means the saving of the lives of their children, the shortcomings of 1931 would be forgotten in gratitude for this one gift.

CALCUTTA, Jan. 1. -- What is regarded here as an ultimatum from Mahatma Gandhi to the Viceroy, the Earl of Willingdon, was issued to the press here today in the form of a telegram answering the Viceroy's message of yesterday.

More than 600 members of the Loyal Order of Moose spent New Year's Day cruising in and out among the coves and bays of Long Island Sound while they awaited the results of their national $150,000 sweepstakes.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1. -- The outstanding event in Soviet internal politics this year was Joseph Stalin's speech published at the beginning of July. While it was not a "New Economic Policy" or "an abandonment of communism" or "a move to the Right," as it has been described abroad, it did re-emphasize the principle advanced by Lenin in his New Economic Policy of "greater reward for greater service."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Defaults on foreign bonds held in the United States amount to more than $815,000,000, according to a list made public today by the Senate Finance Committee. All of the defaulting debtors are South American governments, States or municipalities.
WARSAW, Poland, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Tadeusz Jarecki, composer, of New York, conducted the Warsaw Philmonic Orchestra in the playing of his own symphonic poem, "Chimese," today.

Samuel Untermyer, in a statement issued yesterday, called on Governor Roosevelt to appoint to the Transit Commission, as a successor to Charles C. Lockwood, who resigned on Thursday, "a man of high character, proven courage and independent of Mr. Dahl, Mr. Delaney and the B. M. T."
LONDON, Jan. 1. -- Masterpieces of French art from the twelfth to the twentieth centuries now fill the Royal Academy galleries in Burlington House, which will be open to the public Monday.
ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 1. -- The Montreal Amateur Athletic Association ice hockey club defeated the Atlantic City Sea Gulls, 8 to 3, tonight before a large crowd at the auditorium.

The reduction of $4 a ton in the price of newsprint delivered in New York City, announced by Canadian and American producers early last month became effective yesterday. The new price is $53 a ton, with proportional prices for other sections of the country.

Firmer money conditions prevailed at the end of the year for both call and time loan accommodations. The rates of the former in December were the highest for any month of the year. The renewal average for call loans last month was 2.694 per cent, against 2.5 per cent in November and 2.161 per cent in December, 1930.

With retail business in the usual year-end period of calm, inventories light and commitments for future needs small, business is entering 1932 in the belief that an early resumption of activity is due, according to the weekly trade reviews.

While Federal authorities and the police of a dozen cities, including New York, were engaged yesterday in a combined effort to apprehend the senders of packages containing bombs, most of them directed to influential Italians and Italian officials in various parts of the country in the last four days, additional bombings and attempted bombings in five more cities were reported.

Debate by radio has been more seriously employed in Germany than in any other country. Herr BRUENING in his prolonged contest with HITLER has been at least once upon the air. His recent speech in reply to the Fascist leader's sudden appearance in the role of Germany's ruler-designate was probably the most important radio document of the year.

The city of New York is expected to enter the market in a few days for a loan estimated at from $90,000,000 to $100,000,000. Controller Berry has conferred with municipal bankers in the last few days as to the advisability of marketing an issue of bonds instead of floating additional short-term obligations.

" Following a rather pointed admonition by the Speaker * * * " reads our Washington dispatch, " Democratic leaders were extremely reticent today on the subject of a taxation program." This is truly a test of party discipline. If Mr. GARNER can hold down the outpouring of plans, programs and defiances of Republicans by his committee chairmen and floor leaders, he will reveal himself a real chieftain.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 1. -- Clipping two strokes from the course record, Tommy Armour of Detroit, British open titleholder, set the pace for a field of 150 golfers today in the opening round of the seventy-two-hole Miami open championship, being played on the Miami Springs municipal links.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 1. -- Racing was resumed at the Agua Caliente track today, with the Winter Junior Mile Handicap for 3-year-olds, $1,000 added feature event, resulting in a triumph over a muddy track for C.V. Parsons's Gallineta. The Pasadena Stable's Joe Flores was second and Baron Long's Nacho, the favorite, third.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my daily perusal of THE NEW YORK TIMES this morning I learn the Interesting news that in 1930-31 Columbia University has been the recipient of gifts and benefactions to the extent of $28,000,000.

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- It would be disastrous for the world if the expectations for disarmament are disappointed again. President von Hindenburg reclared today in his reply to New Year's greetings from the diplomatic corps.

The return of Gerard S. Smith, one of the ranking players of indoor polo, to the game at Squadron C Armory in Brooklyn and an important metropolitan circuit game at Squadron A Armory in Manhattan feature tonight's indoor polo.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Charges by the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment that the Woman's Christian Temperance Union had changed its attitude regarding the resubmission of prohibition to a vote, were denied by the women's organization today in a letter to members of Congress.

Business will be resumed in all financial centres this morning after having been suspended for New Year's. Yesterday was observed as a general holiday here and abroad. The markets and the banks will be open as usual today.

The recognition of library administration as a profession is a coming change in the United States, brought about by the development of public libraries, Dean C. C. Williamson of the School of Library Service of Columbia University forecasts in his annual report to President Nicholas Murray Butler.

With estimated sales of $16,400,000,000 of new life insurance to their credit in the last year, leading insurance companies feel that they have made a creditable showing in the circumstances that have existed, and few predict that the coming year will not be better than the past.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 1. -- A great football player who has been doing good turns for others for three years flashed briefly today as a ball carrier and enabled Southern California to win the mythical national championship by defeating Tulane, 21 to 12, as 83,000 excited spectators looked on in the annual Tournament of Roses game.

With the end of the Lenz-Culbertson bridge match nearing, two new players will make their appearance next week, it was announced yesterday by Ely Culbertson. They are Michael Gottleib, who will play as Mr. Culbertson's partner on Tuesday evening, and Howard Schenken, who will team with him Thursday evening.

Yale's undefeated hockey team will make its second appearance of the current local Intercollegiate series when it opposes the University of Toronto sextet at Madison. Square Garden tonight. The battle is expected to provide some interesting and exciting competition, inasmuch as the Eli aggregation is eager to preserve its clean record in the hope of being selected as the United States entry in the Winter Olympics, which will be held at Lake Placid next month.

MASSILLON, Ohio, Jan. 1 -- A gray-haired, time-bitten old warrior, who earned the sobriquet of "General" as leader of the famous march of the unemployed to Washington in 1894, stood today on the threshold of realization of a "dream" thirty-eight years old.

PANAMA CITY, Jan. 1. -- Accion Comunal, the group of young men who overthrew the government of former President F.H. Arosemena a year ago, is celebrating the first anniversary of their triumph with a two-day program regardless of rumors of the possibility of a counter-revolt, which apparently are unfounded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- Crashing over a touchdown in the closing minutes of the first period and showing a decided superiority on both offense and defense throughout the contest, East conquered West, 6 -- 0, today in a gridiron struggle played in the name of charity.

OTTAWA, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- "The worst is over, Canada has survived the crisis, and the same spirit and the same strength which have withstood the stress and strain of the past year will carry us over all intervening difficulties into an era of prosperity heretofore unknown," Premier Bennett said tonight in a New Year's message to the people of Canada.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 1. -- Uruguay's moratorium on foreign commercial debts terminated yesterday with out the Chamber of Deputies reaching action on the Senate's recently passed bill spreading the settlement of payments over the next twelve months instead of five as specified in the moratorium law.

PALM BEACH, Jan. 1. -- New Year's Day in Palm Beach was celebrated in the traditional manner with many teas, receptions and dinners, several being given for the school and college set home for the holidays.

The ancient and modern history of the world, the chief feats of exploration and discovery, and the outstanding national and international events in civilization from the days of Toscanelli and Columbus to the modern era may be read in common stamps, an unusual volume, "Geography and Stamps," points out.

The longest match in the tourney to date, Charles M. Wood of the Fairview Country Club of Elmsford upset Albert Burke of Ireland last night in the semi-final round of the first annual national indoor professional tennis championship tournament at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory.

HAVANA, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Closing gamely through the stretch run. Thistle Fyrn, 6-year-old bay daughter of My Play-Hildred, accounted for the $3,000 added New Year's handicap, stake attraction at Oriental Park today. Her advantage over S.S. Friedlein's Fortunate Youth at the finish of the mile and one-sixteenth was three-quarters of a length. H.V. Stevens's Jack Collins finished third.

The Neighborhood Club of Brooklyn presented its second annual awards last night "for distinguished service to the cultural and civic life of Brooklyn" to four residents of the borough and to one corporation.

Most of the important developments in the railroad history of 1931 are regarded as reflections of the depression. This was the moving factor in the national rate adjustment, in the progress in consolidation and in the move to cut labor costs. The need for economy impressed upon the railroads by dwindling traffic caused them to agree on a consolidation plan for the East after nearly ten years of discussion.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Jan. 1 -- At a formal reception at Mukden this morning signalizing the birth of the new Fengtien provincial government the expected hoisting of a new flag did not take place. Governor Tang Shih-yi's headquarters merely flew the red flag bearing the characters of the provincial government.

TOKYO, Saturday, Jan. 2 -- Japanese advance forces have crossed the Taling River, twenty miles from Chinchow, without meeting any sign of resistance, and are now reported to be within ten miles of that city. The main body of Japanese troops, however, is not pressing its advance, but apparently is waiting to give the Chinese forces there time to retire beyond he Great Wall.

A church loyalty and home visitation and evangelism crusade will be conducted in Protestant churches of Manhattan from Feb. 27 until Easter and in the Bronx from Jan. 24 to Feb. 13. The crusade will be under the direction of the Rev. Dr. Guy H. Black of Indiana, who is the originator of the movement.

Payments of dividends declared by corporations in December were sharply reduced compared with a year ago, food, packing, tobacco and mail-order groups being the only exceptions to the general run of payments omitted and reduced. The aggregate of dividends declared by 1,730 corporations was $363,572,932 in December, compared with $567,877,243 for 2,192 corporations in the same month of 1930.

Financial disaster such as has overtaken Chicago will overwhelm New York City if the city continues to spend beyond the capacity of the tax-payers, Peter Grimm, president of the Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., warned yesterday.

In the 1830s a Harvard undergraduate was treated to the terrors of a Public Admonition for "having his hands in his pockets, whistling and having a jaunty air on his way to prayers." In the 1930s undergraduates publicly admonish and jeer the dons.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 1. -- Harvard and Princeton will renew the hockey series which has heen interrupted since 1926 when the varsity teams meet in the Boston Garden tomorrow night.

Despite outbreaks of infantile paralysis and an increase in the prevalence of measles, the health of the city as a whole was "remarkably; good" during 1931, with the infant death rate the lowest on record, according to the annual report of Health Commissioner Wynne, sent to Mayor Walker yesterday.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 1. -- As returns come in from the rural districts the ratio of majorities against prohibition is not so large but in the returns from approximately two-fifths of the vote the wets still have almost three to one.

Sir Reginald Wolseley, English baronet, going back to claim his title, which he inherited in 1923, accompanied by Lady Wolseley, is sailing today on the White Star liner Baltic. Others sailing on the ship for Liverpool via Queenstown are:

Although New York Clty's public schools again became a battle-ground for civic debate in 1931, with the result that the State Education Department will begin its inquiry this month into their "pedagogical efficiency," the past year has been one of considerable achievement for the city's schools.
SHANGHAI, Saturday. Jan. 2 -- Japanese troops entered Chinchow at 6 o'clock this morning, according to foreign dispatches received here.

PARIS, Jan. 1 (AP) -- The chief industrial countries of Europe, faced with the tremendous problem of providing work or aid for at least 10,000,000 unemployed, have entered 1932 with extensive programs of national development and unemployment relief.

The usual demands upon the banks incident to the holiday trade and the year-end assumed somewhat more than their usual significance because a large number of member banks throughout the United States entered December with a substantial amount of indebtedness at the Reserve Banks as a result of gold and currency withdrawals early in the Autumn, according to the monthly review of credit and business conditions of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

MADRID, Jan. 1 -- Organisation of the Accion Catolica, or Catholic Action Society, in Spain to seek "legislative redress" against the curbs, on the Church in the Spanish Constitution was announced today in a pastoral letter signed by the Cardinals, Archbishops and Bishops of Spain.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 1. -- The ten experts competing in the international chess masters' tournament of the Hastings and St. Leonards Chess Club spent New Year's Day in playing the five games of the fifth round at the White Rock Pavilion. There were two sessions and all of the contests were played to a decision.
LONDON, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- The London Gazette today announced the appointment of the Countess of Bessborough to the Order of St. John of Jerusalem as a Dame of Grace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Stamp collectors from all parts of the country, eager to be among the first to obtain the first issue of the George Washington Bicentennial stamps which were placed on sale here this morning, crowded seven windows in the city postoffice from early morning until late tonight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 1. -- In one of the roughest, Wildest National League hockey matches ever played in the Chicago Stadium, the Chicago Black Hawks scored a 3-to-2 victory over the New York Americans tonight.

Sam Katz, a former convict, known to the police as an expert sale-cracker, was arrested early yesterday morning when an alert Jersey City patrolman caught him fumbling at the door of a butcher shop. His fingerprints soon revealed that he was wanted in New York for four burglaries, including one of $100,000 and another of $90,000, according to Inspector John Underwood of the Jersey City detective force.

Definite advertising plans for this year have already been made by 174 members of the Association of National Advertisers, it is disclosed by the results of a poll made public yesterday at the organization's headquarters, 420 Lexington Avenue. Fifty-three of the companies reporting said they would spend more for advertising this year than in 1931.
Dialogue in the House of Chronos. Father Time -- So you're back, 1931? 1931 -- Yes, Father. But I had a hard time getting here.

TRENTON. N. J., Jan. 1. -- Walter T. Arndt. civic reform leader of New York City, who was injured in an unusual automobile accident at Penn's Neck, near Princeton, on Dec. 24, died here today in McKinley Hospital. Mr. Arndt, who was 58 years old, resided at 2 Horatio Street, Manhattan.

It was sleepy-time yesterday down South in the "jungle," those lots where the hoboes rest their weary feet. New Year's day meant very little, to the place. The trouble with taking a rest from the business of hoboing means only that one must work.
New Year's liquor was responsible for the deaths of four persons by acute alcoholism in New York.

Shooting under adverse conditions, 33. M. Higginson won the New Year's traps shoot over the Travers Island traps of the New York A. C. yesterday. He took the High-Over-All Cup with a card of 86 out of a possible 100 targets. While the lowest scratch score that has won a prize so far this season at the Winged Foot traps, the card was an excellent one, considering the handicap of a rain and hail storm.

The University of Southern California football team, holder of the Pacific Coast championship, defeated Tulane, champion of the South, in the annual Rose Bowl game at Pasadena yesterday, 21 to 12, before 83,000. Ernie Pinckert, back-field star, won individual honors, scoring two of Southern California's touchdowns.

Plans for new multi-family housing to accommodate 24,825 families were filed in New York during 1931, William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commissioner, announced yesterday after a survey of apartment construction records of the building bureaus in the five boroughs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 1 -- Rain that poured down steadily through last night and this morning saved President and Mrs. Hoover hours of handshaking today at their New Year's reception. Only half as many callers went to the White House as were there a year ago.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., Jan. 1 -- Laurence W. Dickey, 26 years old, of 37 East Fifty-first Street, New "York City, former captain of the Harvard crew, died in the Northern Westchester Hospital at Mt. Kisco this morning of injuries received when his car overturned on Union Cemetery Road, Bedford Centre, at about midnight.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 1 (AP). -- Wotan won his second important race of the season when he carried the silks of Ed Haughton to victory in the $3,000 New Year's Handicap, feature at Jefferson Park today. He also won the Thanksgiving Handicap on the opening day of the meeting.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 1 (Canadian Press). -- South Africa passed the first innings' total of Australia in the test match today. Australia scored 198, and after occupying the wicket all day, South Africa registered 268 for seven wickets.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The drug traffic comes in for periodic discussion, usually coincident with the announcement of a seizure by government agents or with the tracing of some outstandingly morbid or sensational crime to its influence. At such times the police and the special narcotic divisions of the Internal Revenue Department draw their share of criticism for alleged collusion with the so-called dope rings.

HARLAN, y., Jan. 1 (AP). -- The National Miners Union strike which started today in the Southeastern Kentucky coal fields closed down four mines in Knox County, but in Harlan operators with few exceptions reported their full strength, and in Bell County most mines also were operating.

The United States and Canada, during 1931, had the best health records in their histories, according to Dr. Louis I. Dublin, statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, who bases his statement on experiences of the company's industrial policyholders.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 1. -- Hugo Mansfeldt, formerly widely known as a pianist, and a pupil of Franz Lisat, died at his home here late last night. He was 87 years old and had been an outstanding figure in the musical life of San Francisco for nearly half a century.

Formation of a council of representative business leaders and civic and patriotic club executives "for a concentrated drive to influence public opinion" was announced yesterday by the National Advisory Board of the America-at-Work movement, with offices at 11 West Forty-second Street.

The electric power and light industry of the United States, which brought to a conclusion in 1931 most of the major construction undertakings which it had arranged in previous years, was faced with the necessity of meeting the problems caused by a severe reduction in manufacturing activity.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- With no perceptible signs of a slump in sight, Bermuda has embarked upon another Winter season. Already many of the regular visitors have returned to open their island homes, while the hotels, with one exception, are open for the season, the exception being the Hamilton, which reopens on Jan. 15.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 2 -- The City Bank and Trust Company, one of the largest and most popular commercial and savings banks in Hartford, with more than $20,000,000 in deposits and 40,000 depositors, failed to open its doors today and the State of Connecticut will move for a receiver next week.

MELBOURNE, Australia. Jan. 2 (AP) -- South Africa continued its first innings in the third of the series of five test cricket matches with Australia today and after scoring 358 runs for nine wickets declared its innings closed.

Estimates on how important a part luck plays in the success of a hockey goal tender vary greatly, depending on who makes the estimate. The goalie himself dismisses it almost entirely as a factor, but the luck percentage mounts as one moves down the ice toward the forwards.

GLENDORA, Miss., Jan. 2 (AP) -- An inland sea of muddy water that surged over weakening levess crept higher around homes in the Tallahatchie River Valley tonight, where are marooned thousands of people who are feeling the pinch of hunger and illness.

MONTREAL, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The Montreal Canadiens handed their home-town rivals, the Maroons, a 5-to-1 beating in a wild and exciting National Hockey League game tonight. The canadiens now have beaten the Maroons twice in their three intra-city matches to date.

COMPLETE comfort of the audience rather than great seating capacity will be emphasized in the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre being built at Stratford-on-Avon, which, it is expected, will be ready for opening next April on the birthday of England's immortal playwright.

THE National Automobile Show, thirty-second to be held annually in New York, will open in the Grand Central Palace next Saturday. It promises to be one of the largest exhibitions in recent years, with displays of nearly 300 cars and chassis.
BOSTON, Jan. 1 -- There has been the normal let-down in retail trade this week after the Christmas buying.

To the Editor of The New York Times: MR. KOOTZS otherwise interesting and in many respects article in THE NEW YORK TIMES of Dec. 20, "America iiber Alles," is sadly weakened by the paragraph it contained which singles out four or five names as pre-eminent workers in the art of America.
LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- The bridge match between England and America is all off, so far as Colonel B.M. Beasley. secretary of the Crockfords Club, is concerned.

CRITICIZING the character of radio advertising, Commander J. W. Reeves, U.S.N., has complained as follows to Senator James Couzens of Michigan, chairman, and the members of the Interstate Commerce Committee, which has charge of radio matters in the Senate:
