A radical change in design of the 10,000-ton cruisers now building in various yards has been adopted by the Navy Department, it was revealed yesterday, and will make the new "treaty" cruisers "miniature battleships," far stronger in defensive qualities and in general fighting ability than the eight ships of the Pensacola-Chester class which have already joined the fleet.

DETROIT. HAVING recovered from the first shock of surprise it received at Henry Ford's sudden change of mind, the product of which will be a Ford eight at least by the end of January, Detroit now assesses the stroke as one of Ford's boldest and most brilliant.

A parade and "demonstration" of about 200 Communist agitators in front of the Polish Consulate at 151 East Sixty-seventh Street was dispersed by the police yesterday when the group, armed with umbrellas and revolutionary slogans, attempted to hold meetings in front of an apartment house at the side of the Seventh Regiment Armory and on the steps of a church.

ROME, Jan. 2. -- The first public execution in Italy since the country became an independent kingdom took place at Caltanissetta, Sicily, at dawn today, when Diego Mignemi, who had been found guilty of murdering a 17-year-old youth, was shot in the back in a field on the out-skirts of the city in the presence of several hundred onlookers.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- With minor differences settled, the Republican organization took over the City government today after four years of standing on the sidelines watching the City Manager League handling the reins.

BUFFALO, Jan. 2 -- Approval of a request to President Hoover to appoint a student as a member of the American delegation to the Geneva Disarmament Conference, was voted today by the quadrennial convention of the Students' Volunteer Movement. The proposal was made by Professor Ralph Harlow of Smith College.

EDWARD FILENE, business man of Boston, is no parlor optimist; he does not believe that this is the best possible World to live in, but this doesn't prevent him from seeing that it is as good a world and an age as humanity has ever known, better, indeed, in many respects, provided humans will take the trouble to recognize its differences and the need for different attitudes and a different kind of thinking.

The opening contest in the New York State pocket billiard championship tournament being staged at Dwyer's Broadway Academy, played yesterday afternoon, brought victory to Benny Allen of Kansas City over Andrew Ponzi, Philadelphia cue to 100, in fourteen innings, pocketing 57 balls to come from behind and to wielder.
JACK DEMPSEY is taking a long time coming back. This is just another indication of how far away he had gone.

BERLIN. IN the short space of less than two years a new and turbulent force -- organized revolutionary nationalism -- has swept over Germany from the Rhine to the Vistula and completely altered (at least for the moment) the face of German politics.

SHANHAIKWAN, China, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A further expansion of Japan's military and political strength in China beyond the bounds of Manchuria was seen by local observers today in her action in stationing a force of 700 infantry and artillery here during the last two weeks.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 2. -- With two-thirds of the votes in the prohibition referendum counted, the official figures show 386,117 for the lepeal of prohibition, 7,160 for modification and 138,708 for retention of the law.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- Death sentences were imposed today at Kabarovsk on a train dispatcher, a guard, a conductor and a station master, all of whom were found to be responsible for a recent wreck involving loss of life on the Russian-Siberian Railroad. Another railroad man received the maximum prison sentence of ten years, another seven years, and others shorter terms.

A CUBIC yard of freshly fallen snow can weigh anywhere from 140 to 180 pounds. And these are only starting figures. A cubic yard of wet and older snow can easily weigh 1,500 or 1,600 pounds -- nearly a ton.

I WAS a youngster in Paris in the Winter of 1909-10, attending a school in the Rue de la Sorbonne, where I might have been learning French if I had attended classes regularly. Grammar was taught every morning -- anyway, every morning that found me there.

THIRTY-FOUR scientific societies and the fifteen sections of the American Association for the Advancement of Science held their annual meeting last week in New Orleans. This yearly gathering of scientists is by far the most important of its kind on this side of the Atlantic.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 1. AFTER two of the leanest weeks in the theatre that this uncomplaining -- and, perhaps for that very reason, often neglected -- city has ever known, even in the pre-holiday period, there is plenty of activity on the local Rialto and more than half a promise that it will continue at least a month or so.

The war debts and reparations conference which has been called to meet in Lausanne on Jan. 18 will, according to all present indications, have to get along without the participation of the United States. Our government was, it is understood, most frank with the European nations and made it perfectly plan that we did not regard it as good policy for us to participate.

IN the preparations for the annual Beaux-Arts Ball -- "A Pageant of Old New York and the First Inaugural Ball of the United States of America" -- particular stress is being placed upon costumes so that the event may appear to be an authentic reproduction of the testimonial ball to George Washington after his inauguration.

WITH the ranks of professional players and teachers being swelled by some 2,000 graduate musicians every year, the lot of the thousands of unemployed workers in this line of entertainment in Germany is becoming worse and worse, according to data presented to a meeting held in Berlin a couple of weeks ago under the auspices of the National Association of German Musicians and Music Teachers.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2 -- Compiling his second sub-par round in as many lays, Tommy Armour, veteran Deroit golf professional and holder of he British open title, maintained his lead at the half-way mark today in the Miami open championship on the Miami Springs municipal course.

An unusually strenuous schedule of thirty-one exhibition games, yet so tactfully arranged as to make it one of the finest Spring training tours ever devised by Manager John McGRAW' has been drawn up for the New York Giants, who, after three " successive years in Texas, will pitch their camp in Los Angeles to prepare themselves for the 1932 pennant campaign.

WILMINGTON, Del., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Three receivers have been appointed by Chancery Court here for the American Community Power Corporation of Grand Rapids, Mich., on grounds of insolvency. The corporation is the principal subsidiary of the American Commonwealth Power Corporation, for which three receivers were appointed by the court at Dover last Thursday.

THE feat of transporting Juan de la Cierva, inventor of the autogiro, from a pier on the North River to Floyd Bennett Field in one of the aircraft of his design was looked upon by the aviation industry last week as having opened up a new field for craft of that type.

Vincent Richards of New York won the first national indoor professional tennis championship tournament by vanquishing Charles M. Wood of the Fairview Country Club, Elmsford, N.Y., in straight sets in the title final at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 2. -- Funeral services for Richard V. Oulahan, late chief Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and dean of the corps of correspondents, were held in Holy Trinity Church in historic Georgetown today in the presence of President and Mrs. Hoover, Secretary Stimson, and other officials, diplomats, delegations from organizations in which Mr. Oulahan had been a member and hundreds of other friends.

WHY is it that similar animals and plants are found on both sides of the ocean? The late Professor Alfred Wegener thought that the continents were once united, that they were torn asunder to drift apart, and that they are still floating about on a substratum of magma.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- With the beginning of the Winter season many cottages owned by regular seasonal residents of Nassau are being opened in anticipation, of the arrival of the American colony, while the New Colonial and Fort Montagu Beach Hotels are also being prepared for early opening.

The movement for consolidation of railroads in the East will get under way again on Wednesday, when public hearings on the four-party plan for this area will start before the Interstate Commerce Commission. The plan of the commission for the East called for five systems, but about 80 per cent of the mileage involved received like allocation in each plan.

WINTER is a timely season for this hale and hearty book to make its appearance, and as the proceeds of the sale are to go toward enriching the library of the Explorers' Club, it would be a gratifying tribute to the distinguished contributors if the public made of it a best seller.

The arabesque gold-leaf ceiling of the Metropolitan Opera House is spattered with small black marks and the cherubs who smile down are riddled with partridge shot fired from a shotgun. To the operagoers, however, it cannot be noticed, but attaches of the Metropolitan are not likely to forget what happened to the balloons that got away yesterday afternoon during the first performance of "Donna Juanita."

The inventory of assets of the Bank of North Hempstead, Port Washington, L.I., showing a total of $2,728,345.30, will be filed tomorrow by Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, with County Clerk Thomas S. Cheshire, at the courthouse in Mineola, L.I. The bank was closed last Monday by Mr. Broderick because of the non-liquid condition and depreciation in the value of the assets.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Foremost among problems facing Congress when it reconvenes is the bill to create a $500,000,000 reconstruction finance corporation, as advocated by President Hoover, which in many functions would duplicate the War Finance Corporation which operated in the days after the World War.

SATURDAY night, Dec. 12, was a momentous occasion for the producing firm of Macgowan Reed. On that evening, for the first time since the partnership began a little more than two years ago, we could have used an "S.R.O." sign.

WHEN directors or writers at the Coast studio of Metro-Gold-wyn-Mayer wish to know the name of a certain type of jewel case ornament favored by Marie Antoinette, the costumes characteristic of a family of Dyaks or the exact appearance of the interior of a Buenos Aires cabaret, they go to Mrs. Nathalie Bucknall, who for the past five years has been in charge of the research department at Culver City.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 2 (AP) -- The exultant mood in which Democrats are approaching the 1932 Presidential campaign has been disclosed in practical fashion weeks before the national committee meeting here Jan. 9 to select the convention city.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 31. -- Another milestone has been reached by the Charter Group Administration here, with the establishment of a pension system for all city employes. Friday marked the last day upon which employes could enroll voluntarily. All new employes after Jan. 1 must enroll.

SPEAKING recently in response to the announcement that he and Jane Addams had been named joint winners of the Nobel Peace Prize for 1931, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler quoted a poem by Alfred Noyes, entitled "The Pact." It was written for Tins NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Nov. 11, 1923, to commemorate the tenth anniversary of the Armistice.

PERHAPS the most remarkable fact mentioned in this story of the greatest amusement industry ever developed by the human, and therefore easily bored, race is that the motion pictures are Just a little over a generation old.

To the Editor of The New York Times. In an article in THE NEW YORK TIMES entitled "The Goals That Japan Has Set for Herself," George E. Sokolsky says that Baron Shibusawa "was stunned by" and "could never forget" a sign which once appeared in Golden Gate Park, San Francisco: "Japanese Are Not Admitted."

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 2 (AP). -- C.V. Whitney's Chimney Sweep, 5-year-old brown gelding by Whisk Broom II -- Polly Flinders, came fast in the stretch today to win the Culver Military Academy Purse, feature race of an ordinary card at Jefferson Park.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- New regulations of the treasury, barring from entry into the United States of the products of forced and indentured labor, if domestic production was sufficient to meet consumptive requirements, went into effect today.

It developed yesterday that all of the twenty-four men and women who Were arrested last Dec. 7 in a gymnasium at 552 Seventh Avenue on a Charge of violating a section of the penal law by engaging in exercises minus clothing were exonerated subsequently, by Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein in the Jefferson Market Court.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 2. -- For the first time in the history of the colony a gift took the form of broadcast radio program when tonight the Shepard Stores of Boston sponsored a linking of WMAC of that city with WQAM of Miami to present a program in honor of the birthday of John Shepard Jr., Mayor of Palm Beach.

Fifteen Norwegian skiers and their two non-competing captains, Ingvald Smith-Kielland and Olaf Helset, who will represent their country in the third Winter Olympiad at Lake Placid from Feb. 4 to 13, are scheduled to arrive tomorrow on the Europa, it was learned last night from Paul Wiig, secretary of the Norwegian-American Olympic Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- President Hoover made an inspection today of the new $17,500,000 Department of Commerce Building, in advance of its complete occupancy by the bureaus and divisions of the department on Monday. The President spent more than half an hour walking about the halls and corridors of the structure, which covers eight acres, or three entire city blocks, in the heart of Washington.

IF the first month of 1932 is a good criterion, the new year will be a happy one for the major broadcasting organizations. Ten hew programs will make their debut over the WABC network during the seven days beginning tomorrow. Five of the programs will be introduced tomorrow, including the premiere of a series of chamber muaicales broadcast under the auspices of the Music Division of the Library of Congress.

Although the all-breed show of the Rhode Island Kennel Club at Ports-mouth, R.I., on Aug. 21 is still many months in the future, those sponsoring the event already are laying plans for another successful exhibition.

LONDON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The congestion at the top of the championship table became greater after today's games in the English League, First Division. Everton, the pacesetters, lost, being beaten, 4 to 0, at Birmingham and West Bromwich Albion shaved the leader's lead to two points when it blanked Arsenal, 1 to 0, in a great game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- George Washington was the first geographer of the United States and the foremost traveler of his time, according to the National Geographic Society, which has made a map of his travels as its contribution to the commemoration of the 200th anniversary of the birth of Washington.

MOUNT STERLING, Ky., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Judge Henry R. Prewitt declared today in a vigorous denunciation of editorial attacks on courts that neither John T. Moutoux nor any other reporter from The Knoxville (Tenn.) News Sentinel would ever sit in Montgomery Circuit Court as long as he is judge.

HAVANA, Dec. 29. -- Thousands of persons made their annual pilgrimage to the San Lazaro Chapel of the Havana leper colony in Rincon recently to attend the religious ceremonies held there each year in veneration of San Lazaro, patron saint of lepers.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 2 -- An all-day search for Theodore C. Young, director of real estate for the Paramount Publix Corporation, ended tonight with the discovery of his body in an automobile beneath fifteen feet of water at the foot of Black Heath Road, Lido Beach.

Defaults on the payment of interest due yesterday on bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange were comparatively few, according to notices posted by the Exchange. Only four South American issues went into default for that reason and six domestic issues, consisting of five small railroad loans and one hotel loan.

THIS thorough and workman-like analysis of the war-germ in modern civilization is marred by several false assumptions, which detract from its value without definitely destroying the author's thesis. Dr. Nearing is a radical.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Walker D. Hines of New York, former Director General of Railroads, who had been selected by the League of Nations to serve on its commission of inquiry into the Manchurian situation, has found it impossible to accept the appointment for personal reasons.

THE adaptability of Oriental ruga as harmonious floor coverings for Interiors of practically every description, their traditional durability and their individual charm of design have made them an important feature in Interior decoration.

Stocks made yesterday what Wall Street considered an inauspicious beginning in the new year. The moderate but rather general decline was ascribed to "weak situations" in a few stocks, including the reported dissolution of a pool supposed to have been operating in one of the volatile issues on the Stock Exchange.

Thelma Cudlipp Grosvenor, a group of whose canvases will be on view at the Marie Sterner Galleries until Jan. 15, is a well-known illustrator. Mrs. Grosvenor has been a staff artist on Vanity Fair and has contributed to Scribner's, Vogue, The Saturday Evening Post, Harper's Bazaar and other magazines, and has illustrated books for several publishers.

The new ten-mile course on Lake St. Clair, where the British International Trophy motor boat races will be held this year if another challenge comes, as is expected, is to be triangular with one straightaway of 23,810 feet, or approximately 4 1/2 statute miles.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 2. -- Scarlet Brigade, E.B. McAtee's 6-year-old include son of Light Brigade-Crimson ambler, maintained a slight lead broughout the closing stages of the le and a sixteenth Jefferson Count purse, feature today at Tropical rk, to win by a lengrth and a half om Mrs. B.E. Chapman's Nealon ay.

UNDER authority from the State Legislature the police of New York are experimenting with a new legal weapon which gives a broader interpretation of the term "disorderly conduct" and is directed against so-called "public enemies."

Carmela Ponselle returned to the Metropolitan last evening, singing Santuzza in "Cavalleria Rusticana." Alfredo Gandolfi was the teamster Alfio. acting well the sympathetic neighbor of Mascagni's troubled heroine.

Coincident with the reopening or schools this week following the Christmas holiday recess, the attention of New York City's scholastic athletic followers will be turned toward the three tournaments and the trio of title indoor track and field meets which will hold the centre of interest this month.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The year has turned, but not the tide of governmental costs. In twenty years, while man-power has increased a third and national wealth has doubled, the cost of government has multiplied more than five-fold.

Depositors in closed banks everywhere will be interested in an account from our Watch-Tower correspondent at Louisville today of the status of the receiver's suit against the directors of the National Bank of Kentucky. That institution, one of the largest and most important in the country, was closed Nov. 17, 1930.

FORTY authorities on economics, psychology and related fields will speak over WEAF's network in a weekly coast-to-coast educational broadcast during the first five months of 1932. The speakers will be presented by the National Advisory Council on Radio in Education as a continuation of its "Listen and Learn" lectures inaugurated last Fall.

The all-star trio known as the Ostriches swept over Squadron C, 16 to 10, in the Class A indoor polo contest that featured the play at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night. The winners gave away six goals, yet won easily.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 31. -- California is looking to 1932 to provide something different to satisfy its jaded appetite for political excitement. The present indications are that for the first time the wet and dry debate will be injected into the election of a United States Senator from this State.

The University of Toronto hockey team frustrated Yale's hopes for an undefeated season by conquering the Bulldog skaters at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 5,000 persons, witnessing: the second of the intercollegiate games which have become a feature during the holiday season in New York, saw the fast skating puck chasers from Canada completely dominate the Elis to emerge the winners by 4 to 0.
The New Haven Eagles upset the Bronx Tigers last night at the New York Coliseum by the score of 3 to 0, in a Canadian-American Hockey League contest before 2,500 spectators.

There are more changes going on in more fields of human belief and interest than ever happened at the same time in any earlier epoch. If our idea of the return of a good time is to get back to the conditions of yesterday we shall certainly be disappointed.

Charges that men with political connections, but who are not real estate brokers, have received substantial fees in connection with the leasing of property to the city have been brought to the attention of the Hofstadter legislative committee and are under investigation.

ALBANY, Jan. 2 (AP). -- A New York City physician who complained to Governor Roosevelt that the New York Academy of Medicine was conducting an "infantile paralysis serum racket" has been requested by the State Health Department to submit a detailed report in substantiation of his charges.

So little authentic information about Glorgione's personal life has come down to us that the author has the advantage of a very free hand in developing his story.

The first of four launchings planned by the Grace Line for 1932 will take place in February, when the Santa Rosa will go down the ways of the yards of the Federal Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company at Kearny, N.J. One of the most important building programs under way in American shipbuilding, the Grace Line contracts will represent an investment of about $19,000,000 at a time when most American shipyards are operating far below capacity.

Declines in stocks were the rule on the Curb Exchange in the new year's first two hours of trading. The small group of investment trusts which doubled in value in the last few minutes of trading on Thursday yesterday lost practically all their gains, excepting Goldman - Sachs Trading, which held much of its gain on announcement that Atlas Utilities had acquired a large interest.
PINEHURST, N.C. -- The Pinehurst sports program for the coming week will embrace golf, archery, trapshooting, polo, tennis, fox-hunting, and considerable activity on the bridle trails.

It destroyed the united front of the victorious nations, and It resulted in the wrangling by Germany over the carrying out of the conditions of the peace.

The $815,000,000 total of defaulted loans held in the United States tallies closely with previous estimates.

Augustus H. Doyle, 27 years old, manager of an H.C. Bohack grocery store at 1,416 East Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, was shot through the chest yesterday when he resisted one of two armed men who had stolen $107 from the cash register.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Jan. 2.-- Here for a final week-end before the opening of the Legislature, Governor Roosevelt lunched today with Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit.

The annual New York exhibition of paintings by the Russian academician, Iwan F. Choultse, is to be seen this year at the Ainslie Galleries in the Waldorf-Astoria. Much has already been written about this well-known artist's work. If you like snow scenes that are unquestionably marvels of verisimilitude, you will like Choultse.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- December brought little change in the volume of business in most American markets abroad, the tariff and exchange situation hampering progress in a number of countries.

THE two-act opera "Emperor Jones," after the drama of Eugene O'Neill, of which Louis Gruenberg is the composer, will be produced next season under the direction of Erich Kleiber at the Berlin Opera. In acting as his own librettist, Mr. Gruenberg preserved so well the flavor of the original drama, that O'Neill has congratulated him upon the dramatic effectiveness and fidelity of his condensation.

A contribution of $10,000 by John D. Rockefeller Jr. to the emergency employment fund of the Westchester County Children's Association was announced yesterday by Mrs. Carroll Dunhaon, president of the association. Mr. Rockefeller sent a check for $5,000 and said the remainder would follow when the goal of $100,000 was reached.

Pre-school education in the Soviet Union is an integral part of the whole educational system and carries the children through the period when they would be attending the first and second grades in this country; It lasts until the children are 8 years old.

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 2. -- Assis Brasil, who is the Brazilian Minister of Agriculture and is also accredited as Ambassador Extraordinary to Argentina, is expected to arrive here tomorrow to spend several days conferring with the Brazilian delegates to the Montevideo economic conference, who are to proceed to Buenos Aires for a conference among Argentina, Brazil and Paraguay in the latter part of this month.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2 -- Major D. Henry Mordecai, sportsman, who recently had been living in New York, died this morning at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, after an illness of two months.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- After seventy-five minutes of bristling hockey. New York won from Boston, 6 goals to 5, at the Arena tonight in the series to pick a team to oppose Yale in the final round of the Eastern Olympic Hockey tryouts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Plans for speeding taxation and tariff programs when Congress reconvenes on Monday were pushed today by Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- Harvard's hockey team faced Princeton tonight in the Boston Garden for the first time since 1926 and although the Crimson won, 4 to 3, it was a desperately fought battle all the way.

WHEN Ramon Novarro the other day said that film stars were like apple pie, he meant that too much of one or the other would push the consumer beyond the saturation point. That is why, in ten years of laughing and sighing and fighting and loving for the world's cinema enthusiasts, he has held himself to a schedule of two pictures a year, despite the importunities of producers.

MOSCOW, Jan. 2 -- The Russians have called the year just ended the "decisive" year of the Five-Year Plan, by which they mean the year which decided the plan's success. On the whole the word is justified and the burst of optimism with which the Soviet press yesterday saluted the beginning of 1932 has no parallel in the past.

The level of stock prices at the end of December was virtually the lowest point reached on the current reaction. Although an upturn occurred, following the bear-market low established on Dec. 17, prices fell again after a three-day rally and, except for a slight upswing in the last few trading days, would have duplicated the previous low mark.

A tea dance was given yesterday in the Neptune Grill of the Pierre by Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Campbell to introduce their daughter, Miss Patricia Maureen Campbell. Smilax and Spring flowers decorated the grill, and Miss Campbell and her mother received in a bower of Spring flowers.
DARIEN, Conn., Jan. 2. -- More than 200 competed today at the New Year Indoor Horse Show of the Ox Ridge Hunt Club. Ten classes were shown and each was well filled.

IT is the definite promise in what we have already achieved in architecture which compels me to discuss its future -- though not after the manner of H.G. Wells and Jules Verne! A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush. The time la ripe.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Undergraduates from forty-four States, the District of Columbia, two dependencies and nineteen foreign countries are enrolled at Princeton University this year, according to a geographical survey just completed by Wilbur F. Kerr, registrar of the university.

A NEW English opera, "The Devil Take Her," by the Australian composer Arthur Benjamin, was presented several weeks ago at the Royal College of Music, with Sir Thomas Beecham conducting. It is in one act, and the same program was a presentation of Gustav Holst's "Savitri."

FORT SMITH, Ark., Jan. 2 (AP) -- A young man held up the president of the First National Bank of McLoud, Okla., at noon today, drove twelve miles to Shawnee, where he boarded an airplane he had chartered an hour previously and was arrested by officers waiting for him at the airport here.

NOW here is the half-way mark in what is still called, in spite of everything, a theatrical season. And, accordingly, an ivy-covered tradition commands that what is left of the playgoing public shall no longer remain ignorant of the trend of events at the Broadway box-offices during the last five months.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Two Federal prisoners are in solitary confinement at the county jail here and other inmates are being questioned as a result of the finding of four "home-made" blackjacks and the thwarting of what Warden John D'Arcy believes was a plot for a general delivery yesterday.

One hundred and eight exhibitions were held under the sanction of the Association of American Horse Shows during the year 1931, eleven more than in 1930 and the largest number in the history of the national organization, which was incorporated on April 27, 1917.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 31. -- It is at this juncture in the march or struggle of the country that the Democrats of Pennsylvania claim national attention. Although their voting record in the Electoral College has been nil for some seventy-six years, in national conventions of the party their strength is exceeded only by that of New York.

C.W. Phellis led a field of twenty-two gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday. He took the high scratch cup by breaking 98 out of a possible 100 targets, a splendid score under the handicap of snow, which made the shooting difficult.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday was slow and the downward course of prices served to chill the enthusiasm which speculative interests displayed during the closing days of 1931. The first business day of the new year provided little of interest, so far as the markets were concerned.

ALTHOUGH Donne has now been dead 300 years, this "Garland" is less a commemoration of his tercentenary than a token of his rebirth in modern poetry. For Donne, more than any other poet of the past, has influenced English and American poetry of the last twenty years.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The younger set of Westchester County were guests of honor tonight at two dances. One took place at the Ardsley Racquet and Swimming Club, with Mrs. Paul K. Randall in charge. She was assisted by Mrs. Robert A. Patterson, Mrs. Edwin Valmer, Mrs. Theodore Kelly, Mrs. Jerome Monk and Mrs. J. Wood Rutter and Mrs. Walter B. Walker.

THE earth may not be the only inhabited worl'd in the universe; there may be many more solar systems like our own, and many more planets where the physical conditions for life resemble closely our own. These are the conclusions drawn from a new theory for the origin of the solar system., presented last week by Ross Gunn, physicist of the Naval Research Laboratory, in a paper read to the American Astronomical Society in Washington.
The great wave of holiday generosity which provides relief annually for New York's Neediest Cases has practically rolled by, and the fund now has reached $272,132.57.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 2 -- Although Chinchow has been occupied by the Japanese after the Nanking Government had instructed Chang Hsuehliang to refuse to withdraw, Peiping reports declare that Chang has instructed 15,000 troops remaining north of the Great Wall to resist any further Japanese advance and to prevent the Japanese from reaching Shanhaikwan and other points apparently included in the plan of the offensive.

STOCKHOLM. IN Swedish architectural circles the most important civic projects centre in Gothenburg, Sweden's western seaport. Here the building of a new theatre has been entrusted to the well-known architect Carl Bergsten, and in a recent competition for plans for a new concert hall the first award went to Ville Tommos.

The College Art Association opened yesterday at its headquarters, 20 East Fifty-eighth Street, an exhibition of work by artists belonging to the Woodstock group. This is a traveling exhibition, which has already been shown at the Springfield Art Museum, Springfield, Mass.

Tenement House Commissioner William F. Deegan yesterday announced a program of amendment of the multiple dwelling law sponsored jointly by him and the Multiple Dwelling Law Committee. The proposed changes are intended to solve problems that have existed for many years and some of which were created by present business conditions.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Jan. 2. -- Miss Katharine Winthrop of Boston made her Christmas vacation from the Foxcroft School in Virginia a profitable one, for she successfully defended her national girls' tennis championship on the Longwood covered courts, defeating Miss Helen Jones of Swampscott, Mass., in the final today by 6-3, 6-4.

The substantial decline in output of crude oil recently, brought about largely through the Sunday shut-down of wells, is believed to have staved off a cut in prices. The closing of the wells is considered generally to be most constructive and as promising to solve some immediate problems of the industry.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 2. -- J.M. Rudel of Montreal and Robert G. Morrison of Pittsburgh tied with W. H.B. Ward of Hartville, Ohio, and J.R. Bowker of Detroit to lead the best ball of partners against par tournament of the Tin Whistles Club today, each team having a score of 3 up.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- A slight Increase was shown in bank debits outside New York City during the week ending Dec. 26 over the preceding week, although they continued below the level of the same week last year, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Department of Commerce.

PRINCETON, N. J., Jan. 2. -- Details of the 10,000-mile trip throughout the United States which the Summer School of Geology and International Resources of Princeton University will make in its specially designed Pullman car next Summer were announced here today by Professor Richard M. Field, director.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- A world-wide expedition bent on discovering the baffling secret of the cosmic ray will be undertaken this year by Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago, Nobel prize winner in 1927 and distinguished for his research in this field.

VICTOR HERBERT was born in Dublin. Ireland, in 1856. His father, Edward Herbert, was a lawyer. His mother was a daughter of Samuel Lover, novelist, painter, song-writer, dramatist, humorist, musician, entertainer, and ardent Irish patriot.
The selection of Barney Berlinger, noted Penn track and field star, as the outstanding amateur athlete of 1931, has been greeted on the campuses of the country with a high measure of satisfaction.

The program was announced yesterday for the annual midwinter meeting of the New York State Bankers' Association, which will be held on next Friday in the auditorium of the Federal Reserve Bank here. The members will be welcomed at a luncheon given by directors and officers of the Reserve Bank, at which short talks will be made by George L. Harrison, governor, and Owen D. Young, vice chairman.

LONDON, Dec. 17. A interesting and exceptional thing has happened at the Haymarket, Ronald Jeans, the author of "Lean Harvest," has written, as its successor, an entertaining piece called "Can the Leopard . . . ?"

A MOTION PICTURE within a motion picture has been photographed at Paramount. The method by which it is possible to photograph the screen has been sought for a long time by motion picture engineers. It is an intricate problem in synchronization and lighting.

MEMBERS of the Good Shepherd Auxiliary will give a bridge party, supper and entertainment on Thursday afternoon at the Plaza for the benefit of Good Shepherd Reception House in New York. There will be games, starting at 4 o'clock, after which the supper and entertainment will be held.

A slight improvement in general business conditions for the coming year was seen yesterday by the managers of credit groups of the various industries connected with the New York Credit Men's Association in a survey made by that organization. While the general consensus of opinion leaned in this direction, a few opinions were that business would be much better, at least during the second half of the year.

"Back to the farm" is the watchword in Porto Rican education, as described yesterday by Colonel Theodore Roosevelt, Governor of the island, in an address before the League for Political Education at Town Hall. Instruction in theory, as now used in the United States and formerly practiced extensively in Porto Rico, has been replaced by training in the actual life needs of the student, he said.

Since the current low level of the price of silver is not a major factor in the world depression, attempts at increases through artificial measures would be of no assistance to trade, Handy Harman, silver dealers, report in their annual review of the silver market.

The Manhattan College basketball team was defeated, 39-24, by a powerful Dartmouth five, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. It was the third consecutive setback for the Jaspers and Dartmouth's eighth triumph in nine games. At the half the Indians held a 15-11 advantage, but they turned the final period into a rout.

Mahatma Gandhi will be invited to a world "Fellowship of Faiths" meeting in Chicago during the world fair there next year, it was announced yesterday at a luncheon in the Park Central Hotel under the auspices of the threefold movement, which comprises the Union of East and West, the League of Neighbors and the Fellowship of Faiths.

The extension of properly controlled long-term commodity loans to foreign customers, with a view to reducing surplus stocks of goods, was advocated yesterday by Robert M. Harriss of Harriss, Vose Co., commodity brokers, who act for the American Cotton Cooperative Association on the New York Cotton Exchange.

VISITORS to "Explorers of the World," at the Criterion, may notice hanging on the stage the hide of a tremendous Kodiak grizzly bear killed by Harold McCracken, who is one of the six explorers contributing to the film. If pressed, Mr. McCracken, who is a lean, gentle man, with horn-rimmed spectacles, will tell the history of the pelt.
MADRID, Dec. 31 -- The average Spaniard, who has always found it difficult to comprehend things American, is amazed at what he terms the tendency to panic of the citizen of the New World.

WHILE the population of France has increased by about 10,000,000, or about 30 per cent, in the last century, as figures from the recent French census reveal, the population of the United States has increased by about 110,000,000, or about 900 per cent.

BOGOTA, Dec. 28. -- The third major revision, of Colombia's import duties within seven months has just been effected by an executive decree covering about 120 of the 794 classifications in Law 62 of May, 1931, which superseded the 1913 tariff.

Mr. JOHN DRINKWATER'S ironical recommendation of SHAKESPEARE as required reading once a week for politicians may amuse the literate at Westminster, but will scarcely be heard of at Washington, where it might seem more needed. In the '20s and '30s the great men of the Senate, steeped in MILTON and SHAKESPEARE, delighted to throw apt quotations at one another.

Congressional investigation of Fascist and anti-Fascist activities in the United States to halt the operations of both factions loomed as a possibility yesterday as Federal officials in cooperation with the New York police and the authorities of other cities redoubled their efforts to run down the conspirators who had sent bombs addressed to leading Italian representatives in this country.

The opinion was expressed yesterday among advisers of Governor Roosevelt that the meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Washington next Saturday would be far less eventful than was expected earlier In the Winter. They declared it to be very doubtful if the wet plank of John J. Raskob would be placed before the committee meeting in any form that would require a vote.

OTTAWA, Dec. 31. -- The end and the beginning of a year find Canada still seeking, but with growing confidence, that elusive corner which the experts have told us periodically that we were just about to turn. There have been two years of depression -- but the war lasted four years and Canada came out of it stronger and more self-confident than ever before.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- Jacob J. Rosenblum, Assistant Federal Attorney in New York City, began a study here today of expenditure returns filed in the 1928 Presidential campaign by New York City headquarters of the Democratic National Committee.

THOSE first rehearsals That slow, limping, imperfect "feeling" for lines. The director keeps up great gayety and cheerfulness over the play and every one exchanges dutiful congratulations on its excellence. Privately, the juvenile thinks the play is bound to fail, and the character woman is hopeful but doubtful.
BUDAPEST, Jan., 2. -- Snowstorms which have raged for two days throughout Hungary and Yugoslavia have produced chaos in railroad traffic.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal. OUT of a year which was the most uncomfortable, If not the most chaotic, for individuals, both executive and histrionic, in the life of the cinema industry, comes, to use Hollywood's own language, the dawn of a new day.

WERNIGERODE, Germany, Jan. 1 -- Transformation of a nanny goat into a beauteous maiden, according to the formula of a fifteenth-century book of magic will be tried out by a group of German and British psychic researchers under the direction of the National Psychical Research Laboratory of South Kensington, London, and the summit of Brocken, the Harz Mountain of legends and witches, has been appropriately chosen for staging the "experiment."

BLUE ANCHOR, N.J., Jan. 2 -- The Winslow Township committee, after dismissing the police force of five men, voted at its organization meeting today to invoke divine aid in solving the township's unemployment problem.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Jan. 2 (AP) -- A Lucas County grand jury today indicted six officers and directors of the Security-Home Trust Company, which closed June 16.

THE assertion of South America's importance in the world which Dr. Normano vigorously makes and brilliantly sustains in this book might have led the author to have transposed his title into terms more fitting to the real confidence in the future which today most South Americans intensely feel.

Pastors will preach today on the new year. They will draw lessons from the depression in 1931 and point out causes for thankfulness. In a number of churches there will be Christmas pageants, oratorios and cantatas. Three Protestant Episcopal edifices will have Bishops in their pulpits.

ECONOMISTS and others in a position of freedom and no responsibility could work out these problems without practical risks. They could spin their theories and Say what the practical man ought to do, but they tended to lose sight of an important consideration when they became indignant that immediate trial was not made for all the obvious improvements that Were so clear to them.

SANTA MONICA, Cal., Jan. 2 (AP). -- Scoffing at such adverse conditions as a soggy course and a strong wind from the Pacific Ocean, a quartet of amateur-pro teams slashed the par 71 municipal course today with best ball cards of 65 to lead the qualifiers in the second annual Santa Monica $2,500 tournament.

OSSIP GABRILOWITSCH, conductor of the Detroit -- Symphony Orchestra, will assume the direction of the Philharmonic -- Symphony for a week beginning Wednesday evening. For his program on Wednesday and Friday afternoon he has chosen both the familiar and the rarely heard Beethoven's Second symphony, Tchaikovsky's "Romeo and Juliet" overture-fantasy, Schonberg's "Verklarte Nacht" and Brahms's "Academic Festival" overture.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Accused of kidnapping and extorting ransom from a physician and his wife, six men, one of them a former Assistant State's Attorney, are charged by Patrick Roche, chief investigator for Prosecutor Swanson, with composing "the worst gang of extortioners and kidnappers ever organized."

Playing with far more fire and sustained pace than it had shown thus far this season, the team of Squadron A scored an unexpected victory over the Brooklyn Riding and Driving Club at Squadron A Armory last night, 9 to 2 1/2. The game was the only one of the evening in the metropolitan indoor polo circuit, and the Brooklyn riders had gone into action favored to add to their victors.

WITH its fifth instalment the Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences reaches alpbabetically the subject of economics, and the discussion of the various subdivisions of that subject that fall within the alphabetical limits is naturally the most elaborate in the volume.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Harold Brooks Gardner, 36 years old, Eastern manager of the Westinghouse Airbrake Company, died of pneumonia today at his home, 391 Beechmont Drive. He is survived by his widow, Mrs. Helen Bessler Gardner and three children.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The first meeting of the United States delegation to the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva in February will be held here Tuesday with Secretary Stimson, following the arrival of General Charles G. Dawes, Ambassador to Great Britain and chairman of the delegation, who is due in New York on the Europa Monday.

WITH between 174 and 177 members voting wet in the House of Representatives and between 27 and 30 in the Senate, the question of modifying or repealing the national prohibition legislation is likely to be brought to the floor of both houses during the life of the present Congress.

ARNOLD VOLPE directed two demonstration symphony concerts in Kansas City two weeks ago. The purpose was frankly experimental, to determine whether a symphony orchestra could be organized by drawing only on the city's musicians, and to determine further whether Kansas City wanted a permanent symphony orchestra of its own.

Niagara University brought a three-game winning streak to the C.C. N.Y. gymnasium last night and gave Nat Holman's unbeaten quintet its hardest fight of the season before the Lavender could conquer the visitors, 32 -- 27, to run its own victory string to seven games in a row.

Member of the 1924 and 1928 United States Olympic fencing teams, Mrs. Charles H. Hopper, who has been in England for some time, has returned to this country and resumed training with the hope of being selected for a post on the American squad for this year's international games at Los Angeles.

Detective John A. Kranz, who was shot last Tuesday morning with his own revolver by a man whom he was taking to the East Sixty-seventh Street station, died in the Lenox Hill Hospital at 7:35 o'clock last night. Kranz, a World War veteran and the recipient of several citations for his work on the Police Department, had received two blood transfusions and was to have received a third last night.

Rapid transit unification should be forgotten for the present and a concerted drive started, with court aid if necessary, to force early operation of the city's new Eighth Avenue subway line, Samuel Untermyer, former special counsel to the Transit Commission, said in a statement issued yesterday as he was departing for a vacation in Palm Springs, Cal.

TO those Interested in the detailed history of the American Revolution the correspondence and papers of General John Sullivan will be welcome for the valuable side-light material they rurnish. The considerable collection, of which the first instalment is here given, is principally drawn from the, archives of the New Hampshire Historical Society and serves to help clear up the controversy over Sullivan's abilities as a high officer.

Expectations for better conditions in the realty market during the coming year have been expressed by many leading brokers and operators. It is worth noting, however, that these views in the majority of cases are tempered with conservatism and little radical improvement is looked for, at least until the latter half of the year.
Twenty-six years ago Ralph Hitz came to New York from Vienna and took a job in a restaurant in lower Broadway because he thought that such work would at least assure him of plenty to eat.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 2 -- Because of the drastic reduction in metal prices and a lessened demand for non-metallic minerals and structural materials, the total value of mineral production of Canada in 1931 amounted to $227,768,000, against $279,873,578 in 1930, according to a report issued by the Dominion Bureau of Statistics.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP). -- The Pennsylvania Railroad would be authorized to acquire and operate the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad under proposals upon which the city of Boston and the Boston Port Authority are to base their intervention in the trunkline proceedings now before the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Colgate's basketball team combined a rapid attack with unflagging aggressiveness last night to defeat Columbia, 31 -- 23, in the Morningside gymnasium.

ONCE again the historical committee of the Town Hall is to present a pageant of old New York. Entitled "Honor to Washington," it will be given on Feb. 24 at the Town Hall and will be the fifth in a series that has portrayed many notable episodes in the development of the city.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 2. -- Isaac I. Kashdan of New York, S. Flohr and Miss Vera Menchik, the latter two representing Czechoslovakia in the international chess masters' tournament in progress at the White Rock Pavilion, were today's winners in the sixth round.

SIR BASIL BLACKETT, a director of the Bank of England and chairman of Imperial and International Communications, will be the speaker in the weekly re-broadcast from London, to be transported to WABC's audience at 12:30 P.M. this afternoon.

EAST HAMPTON, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- The Hampton Aero Yacht Club is being formed by New York residents who are members of the Hampton Summer colony. The new club plans to use a landing field being built at Three Mile Harbor by Winthrop Gardiner.

PARIS. BEACH togs and bathing suits inevitably occupy a goodly share of space in the South-bound trunk, whatever be the season or the weather, for when the sea is too cold there are always the smart swimming pools with their artificial suns and shores.

By the beginning or this year, the building and loan associations of the country had paid out during their history dividends of about $500,000,000, according to the United States Building and Loan League, which has computed that in 1931 the percentage of safety of 12,000,000 shareholders' investments in the associations increased 0.16 per cent over 1930, when it stood at 99.89 per cent in the first half of last year.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee reported yesterday these additional contributions to the fund which the committee is raising for the relief of the unemployed. Subscriptions to the fund may be sent to Thomas Cochran, treasurer, 29 Broadway.

MADRID, Dec. 16, 1931. IN conversation the other day with a member of the National Music Council, we inquired what policies would prevail regarding modern repertory in the new Spanish State operatic organization shortly to be created.

A total of $92,894,791, of which $89,482,474 was for lines of the new city system, was spent in rapid transit construction in 1931, according to a report made public yesterday by the Board of Transportation. Since its creation on July 1, 1924, the board has expended for rapid transit purposes $505,093,639, or 64 per cent of the total rapid transit costs since the city's first subway was undertaken.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Charles Blair Macdonald have left the Plaza for a stay of several months in Bermuda.

AIKEN -- Sports activity at this resort will begin in earnest with the arrival of the New Year. Polo, Aiken's particularly prominent pastime, is expected to have an unusually good season. The game was introduced at Aiken in the Spring of 1882, so that this season will see the fiftieth anniversary of the event.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It has been emphasized that only 10 to 15 per cent of the population of this country are receiving adequate dental care. Many explanations have been made in attempting to disclose what has brought about this condition of affairs.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 28. -- Next year will see Presidential elections in four and possibly five of the small republics between Mexico and the Panama Canal. New Executives are to be Chosen in Costa Rica, Panama, Honduras and Nicaragua, and the recent revolution in Salvador may render necessary there also an appeal to the ballot box.

WASHINGTON. THE refunds of Federal taxes of $69,476,930 made to individuals, industries, institutions and estates by the government during the fiscal year 1931, an accounting of which was made to Congress last week by the Treasury Department, brought the total of such refunds, since their publicity was made mandatory by law in 1922, to $1,271,266,522, this sum including interest of $230,812,483.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2 -- Thirteen events are listed for Harvard sports teams during the coming week with hockey accounting for six of the contests.

LAST year the American public had the opportunity of seeing a remarkable collection of old Russian icons assembled by the Soviet Government and previously shown in Germany and England. The exhibition introduced the Western world to a hitherto little known branch of religious painting.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2. -- Yale will put into effect a policy of retrenchment in its athletics this Spring and Winter, it was announced tonight.

WHILE that enterprising vacationist Edward G. Robinson is nosing about Paris, his employers at the Warners' studios are making everything in readiness for his next film. "Two Seconds" will be the title, and those with better than average memories may recall it as the play that has to do with the fleeting impressions that crowd through the mind of a condemned murderer as he sits in the electric chair.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 -- Rear Admiral Cameron McRae Winslow, U.S. N., retired, former commander of the Pacific fleet and an outstanding figure in the Spanish-American War, died today at his home, 205 Commonwealth Avenue, at the age of 77, as a result of a heart attack.

FIGHTING since time immemorial has been men's business. War and all its shining and expensive weapons have been theirs to ordain. Obediently women have borne their share of work and deprivation to pay war's bill. Occasionally in the old monarchic order, by an act of God or of nature, a queen or a Joan of Arc has had her say.
In finance and industry the past week generally was quiet, largely devoted to winding up the affairs of the year.

THE new colony of Inini, which France has formed by cutting all the hinterland from French Guiana, in South America, contains great wealth about which the barrier of a difficult climate is thrown. French Guiana has been limited to a strip of coastland only about twenty-five miles in depth; the remaining savannahs, hills and small mountains rise out of the fog and miasma of the interior.

WHEN the scarred excavation which now extends over several city blocks is filled with gardens and buildings; when everything is ready to start the vaudeville, the talking pictures and the broadcasting from Radio City, there will be but one appropriate form of dedication.

BARCELONA, Dec. 19. -- Spain's new republic, having changed from "provisional" to "regular" form with the adoption of a Constitution and the inauguration of a President, seems to have its most serious problem on hand in allaying the forces of social discontent.

New York University's swimming team triumphed over Rider College 41 to 30, in the London Terrace fifty-foot pool yesterday. The Violet natators placed first in five of the eight events to score their first victory in two starts this season.

PARIS, Jan. 1. -- More Americands went home for Christmas this year than in any corresponding season for a long time. A goodly number of the permanent colony remain however, and while New Year's entertainment was pitched in a some- what lower key, many leading hotels and restaurants attracted a fashionable clientele.

MORE than 100 sportsmen pilots and their friends will take off tomorrow morning from the Long Island Aviation Country Club at Hicksville for a four-day cruise to the All American Air Meet at Miami. The pilots in the cruise proper all will be amateurs and members of the United States Amateur Air Pilots Association.

FAIR consumer response to clearance offerings featured the week and completed a month that will probably show a decline in dollar volume for local stores of about 8 per cent. The report on holiday trade, based on sales for the first twenty-four days of December, issued during the week by the local Federal Reserve agent, indicated a drop for that period of 7 1/2 per cent, which was somewhat better than was anticipated.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- In his weekly radio talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight, Frederick William Wile paid this tribute to Richard V. Oulahan:

Harold Grossman, State singles champion, and Irving Dicker provided an upset in the seventh annual New York State one-wall handball doubles championship tournament by eliminating the first seeded pair and the present National title-holders, Jack Seaman and Arthur Aiello, in a hard-fought quarter-final match that went to three games last night on the court of the Union Temple in Brooklyn.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 2 -- Six officers were shot and killed and three wounded late today when they attempted to arrest Harry Young, a hill country desperado, in an isolated farm house near here.

Chinchow and Tsitsihar represent a new phase of the revolution in China. For the first time since the founding of the republic in 1911, a Chinese army has made a stand against a foreign power and has done some fighting.

HAVANA -- The scheduled arrival of seven cruise liners from New York this week, bringing 5,000 pleasure-seeking passengers, in addition to the steady inflow by regular transportation routes, is evidence that the peak of Havana's formal Winter season is rapidly approaching.

Plans for a world's heavyweight championship bout between Max Schmeling, the titleholder, and Mickey Walker, Elizabeth, N.J., challenger, in Miami on Feb. 25 or 26, neared completion when Jack Kearns, manager of Walker, who reached here yesterday from Chicago, conferred with Jimmy Johnston, Madison Square Garden boxing director.

The voices of scientists, economists and politicians were heard in the land as the old year ended. What the politicians and economists said was muffled by that overtone of confusion which has hummed throughout 1931. From the scientists alone, who deal impartially and timelessly with past, present and future, the note was clear.

Direct philanthropic gifts in the United States in 1931 probably exceeded $1,500,000,000, according to an estimate compiled by the John Price Jones Corporation, fund-raising consultants, made public yesterday.

The Municipal Art Society of New York in its January bulletin renews its request to the Board of Estimate and the City Planning Commissioner, John F. Sullivan, that the proposed extension of Riverside Drive be routed to the east of Inwood Hill Park and outside it to preserve the attractiveness of the park land as a unit.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Scholastic honors were won by 120 students of New Jersey College for Women during the past academic year, according to an announcement made today by Miss Esther W. Hawes, registrar. Fifty-six seniors, thirty-one juniors and thirty-three sophomores maintained the average grade of 1.9 or above required to win honors.
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 2. -- The Princeton Tigers turned back the Cathedral Five of New York City tonight in a slow basketball game, 43 -- 19. The score was 21 -- 10 at the halfway point.

TWO years ago most airplane pilots were worried because everybody said we were becoming a bunch of chauffeurs. Today, with three pilots out of work for every man with a job. the old timers are not worried. We know absolutely, despite all the misleading clap-trap that is published, that instead of getting easier, commerciat piloting is becoming each day a more highly specialized and responsible job.

The Long Island Women's Golf Association announced yesterday the results of the election of officers for 1932. Miss Josephine Windle of the North Hempstead Country Club was chosen as president, while Mrs. Joseph E. Davis of Piping Rock was elected vice president.

STOCKHOLM. A DAY in Stockholm is tinged with sublimity and serene splendor when its hours filter through the consciousness of a poet as sensitive as Sten Selander to spiritual beauty and enduring values.

FOR some time now the musical stage has been acquiring intelligence and artistry. More than a year ago "Three's a Crowd" began the task of modernizing the revue. Last Spring "The Band Wagon" finished that particular branch of pioneering by reproducing the lithe, agile, stinging tempo of the age in a carousal of splendors.
ALBANY, Jan. 2 -- The Legislature will assemble here at noon Wednesday to begin its law-making activities before the background of the national political panorama.

THE administration at Washington is soon to hear from Walter W. Stewart, American member or the international committee which recently issued its report from Basle, on the complex problem of German reparations. An unusual type of business mind was brought to bear upon that problem by Mr. Stewart.

After a comparatively quiet two weeks in which there was little or no competition, women swimmers in the metropolitan district have resumed training again and this week will see the first meet since the holiday period, a competition being listed at the Women's Swimming Association on Jan. 6.

MANY boxes and seats have been purchased for the concert which will take place on Tuesday night in the ballroom of the Plaza in aid of the philanthropic enterprises of the Spence Alumnae Society. The artists will be Miss Guila Bustabo, 14-year-old violinist, and John Charles Thomas, baritone.

THE clash in Manchuria brings into sharp focus the differences in personality and character, in methods of thought and of work, between the Chinese and the Japanese. Everything that has happened in that troubled region in the last three months has emphasized dissimilarities long recognized by the two peoples themselves but amazing to the Western World.

SEVERAL performances of current Broadway attractions have been taken over for the benefit of philanthropic organizations. The performance of "Animal Kingdom," a new play by Philip Barry, on the night of Jan. 13 at the Broadhurst Theatre will aid the Child Study Association of America.

IN this brief and vigorous sketch of an unsung and important American, Mr. Davenport has synthesized almost all of the facts and anecdotes about Boles Penrose which have escaped the erosions of time and calculated, implacable silence.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- A committee representing the governments of Westchester County and several Hudson River communities will shortly call upon the Port of New York Authority to discuss the feasibility of constructing the $35,000.000 Hudson River Boulevard, or Riverside Drive Extension, as a toll highway.

Yesterday's trading in the over-the-counter securities market was quiet with few important price changes. Bank stocks opened lower and moved off a bit further after the first hour. Industrials, public utilities, chain stores and communication stocks' displayed a slightly easier tone with fractional changes the rule.

Robert K. Story, former Republican Assembly man from Brooklyn and sponsor in the lower house of the resolution under which the Hofstadter committee has been functioning, was arrested late yesterday on a charge brought by a 16-year-old Brooklyn girl.

Of Wilson's courage I do not need to apeak. He never dodged the responsibilities of leadership. He made mistakes of judgment, but he never took counsel of his fears. He truckled to no man or to no group of men. He dared to overturn precedents and strike out in new paths.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2. -- This story by David Lawrence, commenting on the career of Richard V. Oulahan, was sent out today to papers served by the Consolidated Press Association:

LEKE PLACID -- Winter sportsmen who have come to Lake Placid for the holidays, and many for the entire Winter season, are participating enthusiastically in the program of skiing, skating and sleighing parties arranged annually by the Lake Placid Athletic Club.

ONE of the most active centres in hustling Moscow is a place where one may receive, so to speak, one's "Doctorate of Films." To become a motion picture actor in Russia is as serious a business as becoming an engineer or scientist, and takes as long.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- In four weeks of only fourteen working days, members of Congress have introduced 9,000 bills, a record for the time.

THE Cadillac Motor Car Company announced yesterday the introduction of four new lines of automobiles, including the Cadillac and La Salle eights and the Cadillac V-12 and V-16. Seven Fisher bodies are presented on the La Salle chassis; the Cadillac eight and twelve cylinder models are offered in seven Fleetwopd and thirteen Fisher bodies, and the V-16 comprises seven Fleetwood and eight Fisher bodies.

While the influx of orders during the early part of last week was partly due to an accumulation of requisitions over the holiday week-end, a decided upward trend was in evidence during the week, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell. Inc.

IN recent years the Gulf Coast resorts in West Florida, Southwest Alabama and Southeast Mississippi have attained more prominence, largely because of their ease of access from the North Atlantic seaboard. Roads that formerly were difficult to negotiate in wet weather have been improved and a large proportion of them paved.

LONDON, Jan. 2. -- London today became a mecca of the art world when the Royal Academy galleries at Burlington House were thronged with visitors of all nationalities for a private view of the great exhibition of French art.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Smashing the six-year-old world record for ten games, Ray Barnes of Baltimore today rolled into the lead in the United States championship sweepstakes of the National Duckpin Congress, and on the way to another world mark.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 2 -- A group of Harvard professors, headed by Roscoe Pound, dean of the law school, has requested the Institute of Intellectual Co-operation of the League of Nations to consider means by which Italian University professors may escape the obligation to take an oath of allegiance to the Fascist regime.

OLDSMOBILE will introduce both a six and a straight eight at the National Automobile Show in New York this year, it is announced. The combined line will offer a choice of a six or an eight cylinder engine with only a relatively small difference in price.
The coming week brings a number of unusually interesting sales to the art auction galleries.

Despite the absence of any important developments, favorable or unfavorable, the leading commodity exchanges of this city experienced a much firmer undertone and gradual increases in prices during the three trading days of the past week.

The 1932 dog show season will be ushered in, so far as the East is concerned, by the Pekingese Club of America. This club's show will be staged at the Hotel Roosevelt, as in the past, and this year will be judged by Alva Rosenberg of Brooklyn.

The Neediest Cases Fund at present reaches as far as the following nine cases, but does not provide for them completely. Each of these cases is the last on the relieved list of one of the nine charity societies whose Neediest Cases were brought together in this twentieth annual appeal.

In seclusion for the fourth day at New York 'University, Katharine G. Watson, graduate student at the university, is finishing an experiment today with 160, white mice in an attempt to determine whether or not exercise increases resistance to pneumonia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Senate Finance Committee will resume on Monday its investigation of the flotation of foreign securities in this country, with evidence already in hand indicating profits to American banking houses of millions of dollars.

The first trading day of the new year saw moderate rallies in some sections of the bond market on the Stock Exchange, notably in the case of United States Government bonds and high-grade foreign loans. Domestic corporation issues, as a group, however, did not do so well, although several individual issues moved up a point or more during the two-hour trading period.

Miss Celeste B. Andrews was introduced to society yesterday by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alfred C. Andrews, at a reception with dancing in the Roof Garden of the Pierre. Miss Andrews, who will return tomorrow to her studies at Smith College, wore a gown of red crepe trimmed with silver fox fur and carried a bouquet of talisman roses.

PALM BEACH -- Settling earlier and with less apparent effort than last year into the round of social, sporting and artistic endeavors, the season just beginning gives every promise of eclipsing all previous Winters in brilliance and variety of activities.

ADOLP WEISSMANN was one of the foremost German newspaper critics of music, living and working in Berlin. The articles in this little book are evidently contributions to his daily newspaper output, or his bi-weekly "feuilleton."

MR. WAUGH, like a bored Roman of the late imperial days, set forth in the Fall of 1930 to attend the coronation of the present Emperor of Abyssinia, and incidentally to observe the queer doings of several of the non-British races of Northeastern Africa.

In that magic world of 10-year-olds in which milk-bottle tops and marbles are hoarded with all the awe and solemnity accorded to crown jewels, fashions in collections differ according to the habitat of their young assemblers. Country children are far more passionate and versatile collectors than town children and more than twice as apt to possess vast and varied hoards of all kinds of objects from acorns to tinfoil.

Daniel J. Ferris, national secretary of the Amateur Athletic Union, in a survey for The Associated Press, said yesterday that for the forthcoming Olympic Games Finland, the greatest rival of the United States for scoring honors since the war, has developed in 22-year-old Lauri Lehtinen an even greater runner than Paavo Nurmi.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The navy's new cruiser airship Akron will leave on or about March 1 for the Pacific Coast, there to take part in naval manoeuvres under the direction of Admiral Frank H. Schofield, commander-in-chief of the United States fleet.

HAROLD BELL WRIGHT'S next novel, and other books to follow, will be published by Harper Brothers. The title is "Ma Cinderella," and the scene is laid in the Ozark Mountains. The book will be published early next Fall.

Getting back to a profitable basis of operation in the face of lower prices and smaller pales volume is the major problem of distribution for 1932, according to the consensus of opinion of retail executives in a telegraphic and local survey made by THE TIMES.

WASHESTGTON, Jan. 2 -- When President Hoover sent his special message to Congress asking for ratification of the one-year moratorium on intergovernmental debts, this outstanding feature overshadowed all other portions of the communication except his request for early Senate action upon the matter of American adherence to the World Court, a request which the Senate Foreign Relations Committee promptly sidetracked pending disposition of "pressing domestic matters."

EAST LANSING, Mich., Jan. 2. -- Michigan State College amassed a lead in the first half that Cornell University was unable to overcome in a late rally and defeated the quintet from Ithaca, N.Y., 29 to 26. in a fast basketball game tonight.

How China is governed without any government at all is even more puzzling than how China is governed with a government. Every Cabinet officer of the Nanking Government resigned a few days ago. CHIANG KAI-SHEK flew to his village home in a modern airplane, T.V. SOONG went horseback riding in Shanghai, WELLINGTON Koo went to a resort near Shanghai.

TOPEKA, Dec. 31. -- Political weathercocks in this part of the Middle West are performing in a peculiar manner. They indicate pockets in the political atmosphere; perhaps air currents which are going counter to the way ground observers believe the wind is blowing.

FRAIL Anne Boleyn" is more cohesive in its narrative than is "The Private Character of Henry the Eighth," but for all that one element of traditional virtue we have a suspicion that practiced and practicing historians, whether academic in stripe or not, would throw up their hands at the author's many extravagances of style.

MADRID. EVERY one in Madrid who went to the opening expected trouble. A play written by one of Spain's new Ambassadors, advertised as "anti-Jesuit," produced less than a month after the old conflict between church and State had been fought out in the Cortes, was bound to be full of dynamite.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Pope Plus XI, whom I have had the privilege of seeing half a dozen times, has seen fit to express his Christmas greeting to the world in the form of a plea for the "reunion" of Christendom, and an invitation to Protestants to "return" to the Roman Church.

Resumption of a program of athletic competitions in all branches of sports between the United States Military and Naval Academies, beginning with an Army-Navy football game next Dec. 3, probably will be announced in the near future.

A plan for a "scientific" test to determine the best method of bidding in contract bridge was announced yesterday by Major Charles L. Patton, president of the Knickerbocker Whist Club and a former president of the American Whist League. He proposes to hold a duplicate match in four cities, with 200 hands played by each group and the score based upon the correct biddi..g of the hands.

BOSTON, Dec. 31. -- New England looks back on the old year with grim satisfaction. It was a hard-times year, but times were a good deal harder outside than inside these six States. New England looks forward to the new year with grim determination. No matter what may come, the people of these States will stand fast, resolved to make the most of any opportunities that may offer.

NEW LONDON, Conn., Jan. 2 -- The whereabouts of the Sound steamer Carisco, a freighter operated by the Thames Kiver Line, was in doubt for some time today. The vessel, due here from New York at 7 o'clock last night, failed to appear at this port and was unreported at any port along the Sound.

A world's championship ring battle at moderate prices will usher in the New Year in boxing at Madison Square Garden. The principals will be Christopher (Bat) Battalino, Hartford Italian, and Lew Feldman of Brownsville, and they are to battle fifteen rounds, or less, for Battalino's world's featherweight crown on Friday night.

LISBON, Dec. 16. -- American exports to Portugal have dropped off considerably of late on account of the dollar being quoted at 33 escudos since the fall of the English pound, instead of the former 22.50 escudos. As the pound kept going down and the dollar rising in value the Portuguese Minister of Finance at first refused to quote dollar exchange.

MR. GHENT'S historical narrative is the outcome of many years of study of the discovery, exploration and settlement of the Far West of the United States. He has made himself an authority on this section of the history of this country and now interestingly he can relate it he has shown in a previous book on "The Road to Oregon."

WASHINGTON. WITH the flotation of new government loans on $1,323,483,700 on Dec. 15 another $328,267,750 was added to the public debt of the United States. The general structure of the debt was not fundamentally changed, however, inasmuch as refunding operations resulted in the replacement of about $1,000,000,000 in short-term securities.

Charles M. Caldwell of 500 Angell Street, Providence, R.I., a minority stockholder of the Binghamton Light, Heat, and Power Company, began suit yesterday in Federal Court here to nullify as fraudulent and void the sale of that company's generating and distributing plants to the New York State Electric and Gas Corporation, an affiliate, for debentures of Associated Gas and Electrio Company, valued at $6,417,025.17.

FORTHCOMING performances at the Metropolitan Opera House will aid the charitable activities of various organizations. A special performance of "Peter Ibbetson," with Mme. Lucrezia Bori, Edward Johnson and Lawrence Tibbett in the leading roles, will be given on the afternoon of Jan. 29 for the benefit of the Southern Woman's Educational Alliance.

BOSTON, Jan. 1. INTO the new year Boston continues its perverse theatre-course. Having filled two playhouses nightly and done well by two more in the fortnight before Christmas, it is rather indifferent to post-Christmas fare.

RICHMOND, Dec. 31. -- The session of the Virginia General Assembly, which opens on Jan. 12, is expected to be distinguished among other things for the number and power of the lobbies which will descend upon it from various directions. One of the most important and influential of these will undoubtedly be that which represents the county officials of the State.

GRETA GARBO is the bright name at the Capitol this week. With Ramon Novarro and Lionel Barrymore for her chief assistants in "Mata Hari," the Swedish star interprets the celebrated dancer and spy who died before a French firing squad after a short and bizarre career.

MR. SERGEl KOUSSEVITZKY, conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra and on occasion, a transcendent player at the double bass, has not yet reached his fifty-seventh year, and his career is still. it may be hoped, far from ended.
ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- Discovery of a new method of preserving honey as an opaque, gray-white butter instead of a golden liquid was announced today at Cornell University.

PARIS. DEGAS followed Monet at the Jeu de Paume. It was a pompous show, omitting most of the horses and jockeys and ironing women that come spontaneously into your mind as a sort of Degas symbol, and including too many of the Ingres-like black-and-parchment color portraits that may have been commissions.
