WILMINGTON -- An exhibition of Russian art will be held in the galleries of the Wilmington Public Library Building from Jan. 11 to Jan. 31. This exhibition is sponsored, selected and arranged by Dr. Christian Brinton. "The finest exponents of realism, idealism, internationalism and surrealism," it is announced by the Wilmington Society of Fine Arts, will be shown.

ETHEL COTTON, a teacher of expression, began to fear some years ago that, because she was so keenly interested in her professional work, she was narrowing her outlook and dwarfing her nature. So she deliberately made an attempt to increase and vary her personal contacts and enlarge her Interests.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Jan. 2 -- With E.J. Blood contributing five points with an impressive triumph in the ski-jumping event, New Hampshire University's Winter sports team today captured the President Harding trophy in the College Week games at the Lake Placid Club.

LONDON, Dec. 20. -- In accordance with the scheme sanctioned by the Home Office some months ago, hundreds of policemen are being transferred from the central areas of London to the suburbs, where populations have quadrupled in some cases without any increase of the local forces.

IN final analysis, Russia today is a scientific experiment. It is an experiment still in progress, an experiment designed to test out certain theoretical conclusions arrived at by Marx as to the structure and working of human societies, a laborious experiment which cannot give any adequate answer to the questions asked of it for another generation at least.

PEOPLE are talking about opera who never heard opera before from or within the confines of the Metropolitan's golden horseshoe. Haensel and Gretel found a new audience when radio gave them wings to carry their songs from coast to coast.

A new sprint star catapulted himself into the track picture last night when Ed Siegel, a husky 18-year-old youngster from the Swedish-American A.C., made a clean sweep of the sprint series at the sixth annual Columbus Council, K. of C., games at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn, vanquished the 1931 national sixty-yard champion and equaled the world's record at sixty meters.

AN old house on the Boston Post Road on the outskirts of Mamaroneck. now reduced to a lowly filling station, was more than a century ago the scene of a memorable event. Here it was, on New Year's Day, 1811, that James Peter De Lancey, grandson of Caleb Heathcote, first Lord of Scarsdale, gave his daughter Susan in marriage to James (later Fenimore) Cooper, son of Judge William Cooper of Cooperstown.
LONDON. THE recent election of George Belcher to an associate membership in the Royal Academy illustrates the growing appreciation of caricature in England today.
SKYTOP, Pa., Jan. 2 -- Winter sports have begun at the Skytop Club, despite the handicap of less snow than usual and holiday sojourners have been entertained by skating and hockey contests.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 31. -- When J. Hampton Moore breaks half-century precedent next Monday by taking the oath for a second term as Mayor, Phlladelphians will try to forget their tax troubles for a while and settle down to watch the Police Bureau perform under the next administration.

Several excellent sales of postage stamps have been announced for the opening month of the new year, an indication that the philatelic fraternity will pursue its pet hobby with unabated enthusiasm in 1932. All of the sales will feature fine United States issues, and it is interesting to note that prices for fine copies of both nineteenth and twentieth century issues have shown little if any tendency to decline during the past year.

DALLAS, Dec. 31. -- The people of Texas are taking advantage of what Tom Love called the best Christmas present they ever got. Last week the Supreme Court held valid a law passed last Summer which remits penalties and interest on delinquent taxes if they are paid before next Feb. 1.

American owners of foreign securities "can be a tremendous influence for good in the economic readjustment of the affairs of the world and in bringing a return of trade balance and prosperity," according to Charlton Ogburn of 111 Broadway, who is organizing an association of such security owners.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dr. Joseph Jastrow, quoted in a recent issue of THE TIMES, advocates a school for inventors. He says invention has assumed the dignity of a profession on a par with law and medicine. Training for inventors, he holds, is just as necessary as for lawyers and doctors.
AND here, as they line up at the moment, are shows for the remainder of January -- excluding, of course, those of the coming week, which are listed elsewhere in these pages.

PANAMA, Dec. 29. -- The conflict between the Government and the National Election Jury over the expulsion of Dr. Gregorio Miro, Conservative member, by the Chiarista members of the Liberal party, which have a majority on the jury, has enlivened the political situation here.

Aided by a grant from the Carnegie Foundation and by the skill of an international group of scientists that he himself has organized, Professor ARTHUR H. COMPTON will begin next March a study of cosmic rays world-wide in its scope. By supplementing the older measurements of MILLIKAN, REGENER and himself with observations to be made in Peru, New Zealand, Kashmir, Australia, Hawaii and Alaska, Professor COMPTON hopes to settle some of the more controversial questions.

BECAUSE of its rather complicated nature the technique of fresco painting is perhaps less well understood by the layman than many of the other arts. True fresco painting may be said to be the application of earth colors, oxides of iron and manganese on a surface of wet plaster.

William Randolph Hearst, publisher, in a New Year's address broadcast last night from Los Angeles over the National Broadcasting Company's network, declared that the greatest misfortune that ever happened to the United States was the nomination of Woodrow Wilson for President, with Champ Clark being "cheated" out of the nomination.

THE contract between Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, Mr. and Mrs. First Actor, and the Theatre Guild will expire at the end of this season, but, according to one of the Guild's Myrmidons, will be renewed. Which means that, although the Lunt-Fontanne partnership has received all sorts of highly advantageous offers from other managements, it will go a-touring next season in "Reunion in Vienna."

The names of 861 business and industrial concerns in New York City and vicinity to receive awards for excellent safety records in the seventh annual State-wide accident prevention campaign of the Associated Industries of New York State, Inc., were announced yesterday.
BOMBAY, Sunday, Jan. 3 -- Negotiations for peace in India broke down today and the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi was momentarily expected.

SINCE Vincent Youmans doesn't compose them often, the world premiere of "Smiling Through," his musical version of Jane Cowl's dramatic vehicle of twelve seasons ago, was important news last Monday night in Philadelphia. ("Smilin' Through" was Miss Cowl's somewhat more whimsical title for it.)

GENEVA, Jan. 1 -- The hope of the world for a happy New Year is expressed in League circles along with reasoned fear that 1932 may prove much unhappier than 1931. This pessimism starts with the assumption that the situation of every nation is bound to grow worse so long as every nation seeks to save itself by sacrificing its customers and the common good.

an exhaustive edition of Emerson's letters and papers is in preparation in America, The Times Literary Supplement fears lest the "fundamental thrift of the Emersonian tissue" may disappear from view in this abundance of material. . . . The Glasgow Herald says of W.L. Comfort's "Magnus Colorado" that it is a great thriller, but that is the least of its virtues.

BOSTON, Jan. 2 (AP) -- Senator David I. Walsh today warned against the danger of depositors of closed banks being exploited through payment of large fees to agents engaged in salvaging funds of the institutions.

PARIS, Dec. 10. ACRITIC who has some experience of the theatre would be very foolish if he were to rule out of consideration any type of play merely because of its type. The surprising thing about dramatic art is that its masterpieces are sometimes found to have belonged to a type which might almost have seemed to imply a negation of art.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The approaching retirement under the age law limit of 64 years of five of the navy's best known officers was announced today by the Navy Department.

MOSCOW, Jan. 1 -- Among the new year's resolutions the Soviet Government is reported to be making is a decision to tackle the "discount racket" within the coming twelve months. This merry game probably does more harm to Soviet credit and Soviet business generally than any other single factor.

Although steel operations during the week ended yesterday increased to between 20 and 24 per cent of capacity, compared with 15 to 20 per cent in the preceding week, and a further slight increase was indicated for this week, steel producers have rarely entered the first quarter of a year with so little business on their books, according to the weekly summary of the steel markets by the magazine Steel.

If the forecast of American Federation of Labor officials comes true, the peak of unemployment this Winter will find 7,500,000 persons without work. That is the dark view of the matter, and a sufficiently somber picture it makes. A somewhat cheerier statement of the case would show that if in the next two months we are to have 7,500,000 people without employment it means that we shall still have 41,000,000 people in employment.

Charles D. Dickey, Philadelphia banker, who until last Thursday was a partner in Brown Brothers, Harriman Co., in charge of the latter firm's Philadelphia office, has become a member of the firm of J.P. Morgan Co. Formal announcement of Mr. Dickey's appointment Will be made tomorrow morning.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 2 -- Live coals which dropped from a stove in the apartment of Peter Kuczynski, on the third floor of a six-family frame dwelling at 506 Market Street, set fire to the floor this morning, and the flames burst through the thin wall to a room in the adjoining apartment, in which 2-year-old Edwin Kulawiec was asleep in his crib.

THE Monte Carlo opera season will open on Jan. 21, under the direction of Raoul Gunsbourg. Two new creations, "Le Petit Lord," by Alfano and "L'Escarpolette," by Paul Delmet, who lived fifty years ago, head the program. There will be also a series of performances by the Vienna State Opera, which will give among other operas "Tristan und Isolde."

BERLIN, Jan. 1 -- In the line-up of forces on the field of German domestic politics, ready for the resumption of hostilities which many think must be a fight to the finish, and surely will be more bitter than ever, organized labor holds a position of great importance and of striking significance.

CHICAGO, Jan. 2 -- Employes of the West Park Board, the Forest Preserves and the Sanitary District received a holiday today as the three local governments defaulted on bond principal and interest. The West Parks failed to raise $300,000, the Forest Preserves $653,000 and the Sanitary District $1,519,965.

HOPEWELL, Va., Jan. 2 (AP) -- Two requests for ball and a Motion to amend the order imposing a thirty-day sentence for alleged contempt, were not enough to save J. W. Mapoles, editor of The Hopewell News, from a week-end in jail today.

Dr. Henry B. Wellcome, a native of Wisconsin and a British citizen by naturalization, who is head of Burroughs Wellcome Co. of London, manufacturers of chemicals and galenicals, with branches in the United States and many other countries, was knighted by King George on New Year's Eve, according to a cablegram received yesterday by the company's office at 9-11 East Forty-first Street.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- The call for the new Reparations Conference which came this week and the letter from Prime Minister MacDonald to Premier Laval have produced the uncanny feeling that Britain is living through old events all over again.

ATLANTIC CITY, N. J., Jan. 2 -- The Atlantic City Sea Gulls defeated the Montreal Amateur Athletic Association ice hockey team tonight at the Auditorium, 4 to 3. Entering the final period the score was tied at -- 2, but Happy Harnott caught St. Germain's rebound to tally in 3:15 and gave the Canadians the lead.
HAVANA, Jan. 2 (AP). -- Pronounced mudders had a filed day at Oriental Park today, none but the stoutest performers being asked to negotiate the heavy track. Platers monopolized the program.

FINE ARTS BUILDING -- Fortyfirst annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors. This show, the largest ever sponsored by the association, includes a group of paintings sent over by the Women's International Art Club of London.

TRANSPORTATION by air is growing up. This fact was revealed last week, not by new rows of figures showing growth and expansion but by the announcement of fare cuts by two major Jong -- haul lines which may portend a rate war. Rate wars, have marked the adolescence of other and older forms of transportation since the time when passengers and goods began to be transported for hire.

WHILE the rest of the world is still getting used to calling the U.S. cruiser Akron the "world's largest airship," a sister ship has fast been taking form at the great Goodyear-Zeppelin dock at Akron, Ohio. Already one of the main transverse rings has heen erected.

MUKDEN, Jan. 2 -- The last vestiges of Chinese authority vanished from Manchuria today with the completion of the withdrawal to the south of the Great Wall and to the westward into Jehol of the last forces of Chang Hsueh-liang. Chinchow, which had been the seat of Chang Hsueh-liang's so-called Manchurian Government since late in September, was entered by Japanese troops this afternoon.

MUKDEN, Dec. 4. -- Under the new Manchurian Administration set up here under the protective wing of the Japanese military clique, the capital city of Manchuria is suddenly being permitted to indulge in an orgy of public gambling and police-protected vice unequaled in China during the last five years.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 2. -- The Catholic church today initiated a passive resistance campaign against the federal district priest limitation bill. The first move was the issuance by Archbishop p'ascual Diaz of a pastoral letter of instructions, citing the church's arguments of the unconstitutionally of the new law and instructing clergy and laity to file petitions for "amparos." or injunctions, against the execution of the measure.

1932. For the new year this department has firmly resisted the temptation to promulgate a Plan of Its Own whereby the country night be lifted to a state of unprecedented prosperity, by the scruff of the neck if necessary. We had thought of suggesting a Quarter-of-a-Year-Plan by which a year to the future would consist of three months.

THE excuse for new biographies of King Henry IV is not to add to our knowledge of him (which hardly seems possible), or even to supply a lack, for there are countless books about the "Vert Galant." It can only be because people like to write about him -- for which they can hardly be blamed.

From Elisha Ledge above Narragansett Bay to Cape May, where the Delaware River cuts into the shore line the Lighthouse Service under the Department of Commerce carries on its duties day and night, in fog and snow, in weather fair or menacing. This is the third district, covering the area described with a force of about 850 men, nine lightships and eight tenders in whose care are 800 "aids to navigation."

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 2 -- Those guns booming across Manhasset Bay today were not distant echoes from the Japanese-Chinese dispute over choice parts of Mancuhria, but a chilblain flight and pursuit of the Frostbite Yacht Club. It was a clean out-of-season yacht race, sailed much as if an ice-skating contest were held on the hottest day of July.

Bank statements showing condition at the close of business on Dec. 31. 1931, which have been rnade public thus far, generally show a shrinkage of total resources and of deposits, with the larger Institutions usually reporting the larger relative losses.

Among the passengers who sailed for Liverpool yesterday on the White Star liner Baltic was Sir Reginald Beatty Wolseley, Bart., who succeeded to the title in 1928 and is the tenth baronet. It was created in 1744. He is now going over to assume his rank for the first time with Lady Wolseley.

THE second session of the Lothian sale at the American Art-Anderson Galleries, on Jan. 28, will be an all-America evening. At least, its books come under that broad and convenient classification. Americana, which means early history, geography, travel and navigation connected, however remotely, with America.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 2 -- Unemployed men will start a "march" to Washington Tuesday in motor trucks and other conveyances to make a new demonstration in search of relief.

NOW it is quite clear. Mayor Walker would mediate in Cuba because he has ambitions for the United States Senate and he would go to the Senate because he enjoys making speeches. But it appears that nobody has invited our Mayor to Cuba, mediation and settlement of differences are not Senatorial qualifications, and there will be no Senate vacancy from New York for many, many months.

LEBANON, Pa., Jan. 2 -- Charles H. Strouphauer of Fredericksburg, a former Pennsylvania amateur champion, scored twenty straight to annex the high gun trophy in the twelfth annual New Year amateur classic featuring today's white flyer shoot of the Pleasant Hill Gun Club.

An inquiry has been sent by the North American Yacht Racing Union, a parent body of yacht racing on this continent, to owners of 8-meter and 6-meter yachts as to whether they would be willing to send their craft to Los Angeles for the selection contests preliminary to the Olympic races were their boats designated.

A grand total of $100,000,000 -- a new record for community chests in a single fiscal year -- seems to be assured for 1932, according to a summary of the campaigns already completed in 206 out of 391 cities. This was the substance of a summary submitted yesterday to Walter S. Gifford, director of the President's Organization on Unemployment Relief, by J. Herbert Case, president of the National Association of Community Chests and Councils.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 2 -- The Department of Justice agents are making an investigation into charges of fraud in the allocation of government loans to farmers in Alabama, and it is understood that evidence may be presented to a special grand jury this month.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So long as the different nations and races remain alien to each other in sentiment and culture, there will continue to be these unhappy barriers which now exist between governments, with the result that the different countries constitute hostile and often fortified camps, each viewing its neighbors with apprehension and enmity.

The first Metropolitan Opera performance of Suppe's "Donna Juanita" took place yesterday afternoon, with Mme. Jeritza in the title role. This production is the sequel to the Metropolitan adventure of last sea son in the realm of light opera when it produced Suppe's "Boccaccio."

William T. Tildes 2d, world's professional tennis champion, will begin a campaign in defense of his title at Madison Square Garden tonight against a field of leading players. The matches tonight will mark the first of a series to be played in various cities in this country.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Completing the final stretch of the 72-hole competition with his third sub-par round in as many days, Tommy Armour, veteran Detroit professional, who holds the British open golf crown, today won the Miami open championship from a field of 150 starters by the overwhelming margin of nine strokes.

MANILA, Jan. 3 -- The Big Wedge Mining Company, operating the Antimok properties in the central group near Baguio, reported today one of the most sensational gold strikes in Philippine history. Samples of ore brought to Manila show a remarkable assay value for straight commercial ore, running at least $2,000 to the ton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A naval replacement bill which would practically restore the 1933 construction program worked out by the General Board, approved by the Secretary of the Navy and subsequently disapproved by the President and ordered eliminated from estimates for the fiscal year 1933, will be introduced in the House tomorrow by Representative Vinson, the new Democratic chairman of the Committee on Naval Affairs.

Carload shipments of the twenty-nine principal commodities in the first quarter of 1932 Will be approximately 5,241,746 cars, compared with actual shipments of 5,612,161 in the same period of 1931, a reduction of 370,415 cars, or 6.6 per cent, according to estimates submitted to Shippers' Regional Advisory Boards.

Deviating from his customary method of selecting national champions for the various places on his annual All-America track and field team, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, was influenced to a great extent by best performances in the compilation released yesterday and printed in Spalding's Offical Athletic Almanac.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- The New York Rangers, leaders of the American Division of the National Hockey League, and the Chicago Black Hawks fought to a 1-1 overtime tie before 13,000 spectators in the Chicago Stadium tonight.

LONDON, Jan. 3. -- Sharp criticism of the British Government's policy in India was expressed today by M.A. Jinnah, a Moslem leader and Mahatma Gandhi's bitterest enemy at the London round-table conference, who is the last of the Indian delegates left in England.

The battle lines of local and national wets and drys were more closely drawn yesterday as both, prohibition and anti-prohibition leaders and organizations issued statements supporting their respective positions and made plans to conduct broader and more intensive campaigns this year.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., Jan. 3. -- To his fellow-townsmen Daniel Rentschler for a long time has seemed to be a man who had achieved the heights of his ambition. He admits himself to he one of the wealthiest men in Bergen County, he who left the medieval Black Forest town of Wittenburg, Germany, as a penniless boy of 13 without even a trade, to seek his fortune in the New World.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Returning a card of 80-13-67, Norris W. McLean was deadlocked for the low net honors with William T. Hawe, who also turned la a score of 80-13-67, in the fourth qualifying round of the weekly Snowbirds golf tournament held by the members of the Siwanoy Country Club over the club's course today.
LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Sir Henry Lytton, famous Savoyard, 65 years old today, is now on tour with the D'Oyly Carte Company at Birmingham.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 3 -- With two holidays last week, the cotton market was quiet and quite steady. There was some end-of-the-year liquidation and evening-up of commitments and also some hedge-selling against liberal buying of spots in the interior, but there was enough trade buying to absorb the offerings and prices rose a little more than half a dollar a bale.

The Ladies of Charity of the Catholic Charities in the Archdiocese of New York will hold their annual card party on the afternoon of Jan. 23 at the Plaza. The funds realized will be devoted to furthering the organization's work. Unusual demands for clothing and other articles for needy families are being made on it.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 (Canadian Press) -- Officials of the Dominion and Provincial Governments, business leaders and industrialists, writing in the year-end financial and business review of the Toronto Globe today, held out hope that Canada would see its way out of the business depression in 1932.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 3. -- Mr. and Mrs. George A. McKinlock entertained with a large luncheon today at the Gulf Stream Club.

No definite clues to the identity of the group that sent twelve tombs by mall and express last week to representatives of the Italian Government and to other Fascist sympathizers in the large cities of the East and mid-West had been found, up to last night, although scores of Federal investigators and city police were working on the case.

Much can be said for Senator HULL'S suggestion that the President or the State Department sound out foreign governments on the question of calling a conference about tariffs. The whole world seems to be deliberately arming itself to destroy international trade precisely at the time when it is needed most.

The coming year will be a period of convalescence for business and industry, which will see the end of the hysteria among security owners, according to a consensus of the directors of the Merchants Association of New York regarding the outlook fr 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Inefficient business methods and practices more than any other factor is responsible for bankruptcy and other business failures, according to a study of 612 cases in New Jersey during 1929 and 1930, made public today by the Department of Commerce.

A plan for stabilization of the dress industry, which for years has suffered from economic dislocation and strife between employers and workers, was begun yesterday with the acceptance by Dudley Field Malone of the post of chief counsel and governing director of the Association of Dress Manufacturers, Inc.

Bernard Ford, 21-year-old representative of the Good Shepherd Athletic Club, finished first in a field of ten runners in the weekly handicap road race conducted by the Manhattan Athletic League on Riverside Drive yesterday. The victor, with an allowance of two minutes, was clocked at 15:36 for the race, which was held over a course of two and three-quarters miles.

A campaign to halt begging in the streets of New York, which, it was declared, has reached a state calling for immediate action, was launched by the Welfare Council yesterday through a committee headed by Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the committee on street begging of the Welfare Council section of agencies caring for the homeless.

The Democratic campaign for 1932 will be formally launched on Jan. 14 with fifty dinners definitely arranged for that evening in twenty-four States, it was announced yesterday by John W. Davis, chairman of the party's "victory campaign."

PARIS, Jan. 3. -- Premier Laval's spokesman asserted today that nothing bad been decided regarding the rumored meeting between him and Prime Minister MacDonald of Great Britain before the Lausanne reparations parley, and that if there were such a meeting It would be only after further conferences of the French and English financial experts.

The handicap checker match that is the outcome of Mrs. Anna Berliss's heated challenge to the finalists in the recent New York City Checker Championship following the elimination of her husband, started yesterday at the Gramercy Chess and Checker Club, 36 Union Square, with Louis Ginsberg, the champion, playing Mrs. Berliss.
GENEVA, Jan. 3 -- After two years of pioneer work the International Labor Office has now given its answer to the question that has aroused world-wide curiosity:

GENEVA, Jan. 3. -- The reports of the League of Nation's experts who investigated the situation in Liberia in 1931 is understood to make the possibility of the successful execution of the reforms required in connection with abolition of slavery depend on two main conditions.

The maldistribution of the world's gold supply is blamed for the widespread falling of commodity prices, and Cooperation, by Great Britain, the United States and France is urged for a "more satisfactory" distribution of capital resources by Professor Charles Rist, former deputy governor of the Bank of France, in a new book, "The International Gold Problem."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- As the Democrats prepared today to push their tariff measure through the House, Senator Connally of Texas, through the Democratic National Committee, said:

PARIS, Jan. 3 -- Two works by American composers, "Lone Prairie," by Arthur Shepherd, and "Money Musk," by Leo Sowerby, were given for the first time in Europe today when Fabien Sevitzky conducted the Paris Symphonic Orchestra at Salle Pleyel.

SANTA MONICA, Cal., Jan 3 (AP). -- In the face of a cold wind from he Pacific Ocean, two teams set the pace today in the second qualifying round of the annual Santa. Monica imateur-pro golf tournament, matching yesterday's low best ball scores of 65.

MUKDEN, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Detachments of Lieut. Gen. Kenji Muro's division, which completed the occupation of Chinchow by marching in today, were expected to be sent shortly along the railway to the southwest for the mopping-up stage of the "campaign of suppression."

With a 45 calibre bullet wound in the head, the body of Mrs. Elsie Smith, 36-year-old wife of Sergeant Albert L. Smith, attached to the Ordinance Department of the Army at Camp Dix, N.J., was found yesterday lying across a bed in the apartment which she occupied with her husband at Miller Field, near New Dorp, S.I.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 (AP) -- United States officials tonight were confronted with a new ramification of the Manchurian difficulties following the attack by three Japanese soldiers upon Consul Culver B. Chamberlain, but formulation of the nation's official attitude toward the affair awaited direct reports to the State Department.

By blankingr New Bedford, 6 to 0, in the final play-off at the Polo Grounds yesterday, the New York Giants won the American Soccer League championship for the 1931 season. They scored a total of 9 goals to 8 for New Bedford in the two games played.

The question of the status of City Magistrate Abraham Rosenbluth, who has been ill since a year ago last October, is scheduled to be brought to a head by the final report on the magistrates' courts on which Samuel Seabury, counsel to the legislative investigating committee, is now working.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Jan. 3 -- The almost unbelievable story of a Negro who masqueraded as a white man for eighteen years of brilliant service in the United States Army, thirteen years of which were as a commissioned officer in charge of white troops, was unfolded tonight here and in Los Angeles.

Charles G. Dawes, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, is due today from London on the North German Lloyd liner Europa, as are Sir Thomas Brocklebank, director of the Cunard Line, and Oliver Baldwin, son of Sir Stanley Baldwin, former Premier of Great Britain and Lord President of the Council in the new National Government.

BOMBAY, Monday, Jan. 4 -- Mahatma Gandhi was arrested at his home here at 3 o'clock this morning on the eve of the new civil disobedience campaign which he has predicted will plunge the people of India into "the fires of suffering" once more.

BRIAKCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Hayden Carruth, author and editor, well known especially for his humorous writings, died at his home here, Journey's End, late tonight of heart disease after a brief illness. Four sons survive, Oliver E., Gorton V., Paul Hayden and Max Irwin Carruth.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It the letter of Srinivas Ram Wagel on "India and Gandhi," printed in THE TIMES, had been written in the days of the old East India Company, or even as recently as the middle of the last century, the views expressed might not have been considered unreasonable.
LONDON, Monday, Jan. 4. -- The Government of India is entering its new struggle against the India Congress with virtually the unanimous support of London newspapers.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 3 -- A revolutionary movement, which for more than a week Irigoyenists in Buenos Aires have been predicting in their own circles for the new year, broke out in several parts of the province of Entre Rios between midnight and dawn today.

LONDON, Jan. 3 (AP). -- George Lansbury, leader of the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons, in commenting on Mahatma Gandhi's arrest, said tonight, "Conditions in India must be very bad in the judgment of the Viceroy to have forced him to exercise his powers in this way.

The restoration of world-wide prosperity depends wholly on man's voluntary reacceptance of God's omnipotence, declared the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of Union Theological Seminary, yesterday morning at the Brick Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Thirty-seventh Street.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 3. -- The count in Finland's prohibition referendum has almost been completed and the latest returns leave the previous wet majority almost at the same figure. Indications tonight are that the wets will have 70 per cent of all the votes, with prohibition condemned by a majority exceeding its foes' fondest hopes.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- A campaign to make the country safe for prohibition before the national elecions in November will be started here next week at the opening of the annual convention of the Anti-Saloon League of America, Dr. J. Scott McBride, general superintendent, announced today.

As there was reason to expect, the new year prophecies which have been hazarded publicly by business men were this time extremely cautious. That practically all of them would be conservatively hopeful was also to have been anticipated; not so much because the habit of the season predisposes to consideration ot the brighter side of things, as because most people dislike to be publicly known as predicting evil.

MUKDEN, Jan. 3 -- Three Japanese sentries early this morning beat and badly disfigured Culver B. Chamberlain of Kansas City, Mo., United States Consular official, when he attempted to catch a train to Harbin, where he was to take up the post at Consul.

William H. Matthews, director of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, announced yesterday that 30,518 unemployed men and women had been placed at useful, non-competitive work up to the end of December through the committee's Work Bureau. The jobs are being financed out of the $18,000,000 relief fund raised by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

Thanks to a grant of $4,000 by the Carnegie Corporation of New York, the American Association for the Advancement of Science publishes twenty-seven lists of books on science for general readers as well as students. It fell to the lot of the Enoch Pratt Library of Baltimore to perform the difficult task ol compiling the lists, naturally with the assistance of librarians in other cities and of professional scientists.

The American Steamship Owners Association will ask Congress to revise the coastwise shipping laws in order to bar foreign flag ships from the operation of "cruises to nowhere." This action follows several appeals of American shipping men for protection against foreign competition in a field that has proved fruitful to foreign lines in the last two years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- At the instance of the Canadian Legation, the State Department has inquired of the Governor of Colorado concerning the case of Joseph Byron Jones, a Canadian citizen, who was born in 1881 in St. Catherines, Ont., and is now serving a life sentence in the Canon City Penitentiary for the murder of George P. Fraley on March 14, 1924, at Bessemer, Col.

LONDON, Jan. 1 -- Financial London enters the new year with full recognition of the bewildering and perhaps unprecedented conditions Which exist, but nevertheless with the hope that the worst of England's economic crisis has passed. No serious attempts have been made this week to forecast the economic future.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- In its most important wealth, the health of its people, the United States was never so prosperous as in 1931, Surgeon General Hugh S. Cumming declared in a report to President Hoover, made public today.

A Useful Citizen. The late WALTER T. ARNDT was a reformer far from the "lunatic fringe." A man who refused to be a cynic about the possibility of improving political institutions, he lived to see written into law-and, what is more, into practice -- a surprising number of the changes which he advocated.

In an unusually frank interview in yesterday's TIMES Magazine, Mr. SAMUEL L. ROTHAFEL said that the-atrical managers of the present and future must aim their entertainment at the left side of the public chest. What " ROXY " says about any kind of amusement deserves careful consideration by gentlemen in the business known as the profession.

In Soviet Russia the outstanding event of last year, as noted by Mr. DURANTY, was the promulgation in July of the principle of wages in proportion to service. This departure from the Communist doctrine of equality of reward -- "from each according to his ability, to each "according to his need" has gone along with kindlier treatment of the bourgeois intellectuals and technicians.

LONDON, Jan. 3 -- Ths special players authorized by the Archbishops of Canterbury and York were ignored in thousands of churches today when churchgoers in all parts of the British Isles observed a day of national intercession and prayer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- A bill providing for the free coinage of silver on the basis of sixteen ounces of silver to one of gold, as once advocated by William Jennings Bryan, will be presented in the Senate tomorrow by Senator Wheeler of Montana.

HAVANA, Jan. 3. -- An official statement regarding the riot on the night of Dec. 30 in Principe Castle, where many political prisoners are confined, seven of whom are reported to have been badly wounded, was issued today by Secretary of the Interior Octavio Zubizarreta.

With only thirty rubbers left to play in the 150-rubber contract bridge match between Ely Culbertson and Sidney S. Lenz, each supported by various partners, the result is practically decided. There is still an outside chance that Mr. Lenz and Commander Winfield Liggett Jr. will be able to overcome the 20,220 point lead of Mr. Culbertson, but it is very slim.

A fair showing on post-holiday sales was made by retailers during the week and the wholesale markets were active in filling orders on all types of ready-to-wear for January sales events. Formal evening gowns provided major activity in the dress trade, with a fair volume of reorders developing on low-priced silk dresses.

The Essex Club squash tennis team turned in an unexpected 6-to-O victory over the Montclair A.C. representatives in a New Jersey Group match of the Class B metropolitan team squash tennis championship tournament on the victor's courts in Newark yesterday.
CLEVELAND, Jan. 3 -- Less freight was shipped on the Great Lakes 1931 than in any year but one since the World War.

Confidence and courage and not more wealth will pull the world out of the depression, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler declared last night at a dinner given for him by the Lotos Club in the clubhouse, 110 West Fifty-seventh Street, in honor of the recent joint award to him and to Miss Jane Addams of the Nobel Peace Prize.

RICHMOND, Va., Jan. 3. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., in an address here today, urged that the Democratic party nominate a Presidential candidate "who will take the whole prohibition issue out of the campaign and who will stand as flatfooted for enforcement as Mr. Hoover."

The New York Americans strove diligently for victory last night but, after battling the Boston Bruins for seventy minutes in a thrilling overtime battle, had to be content with a scoreless tie. A crowd of 12,000 persons in Madison Square Garden saw the National Hockey League rivals take part in a bitter struggle which produced many exciting moments.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 3. -- Miss Anna B. Pratt, nationally known for her social service activities, particularly those dealing with youth, died in the Pennsylvania Hospital here today in her sixty-fourth year. She had been ill since last Spring and had been a patient at the hospital for several weeks.

TUXEDO FARK, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- Dominating the play throughout with his hard drives and spectacular shots. Frank R. Frazier of Boston triumphed over William C. Wright of Philadelphia, national court tennis champion, in straight sets today, 6-3, 6-4, 7-5, to win the Tuxedo Club's annual court tennis Gold Racquet tournament.

It is regrettable that New Year's resolutions have fallen into disrepute, for they represent an idealism in human life that should be cultivated, according to the Rev. Dr. Hermam Brezing, president of Wagner College, Staten Island, who preached yesterday morning in the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Advent, Broadway and Ninety-third Street.

Net income of the Utilities Power and Light Corporation for the twelve months ended on Sept. 30 was $6,325,028, equal to $3.22 a share on the Class A stock after preferred dividend requirements, and to 56 cents a share on the Class B and pommon stocks outstanding, compared with $8,007,911 or $4.71 a share on Class A and $1.32 on Class B and common shares, after Class A dividend requirements, the year before.

MONTREAL, Que., Jan. 3 (Canadian Press). -- To take the place of their goalie, Norman Smith, injured in yesterday's match with Canadiens, the Montreal Maroons have recalled the veteran Flat Walsh from New Haven of the Canadian-American League.

Cancellation, reduction or further postponement of war debts and reparations and prompt lowering of tariff schedules are two measures favored as essential for immediate relief from the depression by a special committee and the membership of the National Economic League, as shown in a referendum of the league made public yesterday.

DOVER, N.H., Jan. 3. -- Fire raging for twelve hours in a gale-driven blizzard destroyed the Morrill Block with a loss of $1,000,000 and threatened the heart of this city today before the combined efforts of firemen from nine cities and towns in three States could check the flames.

The Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick, pastor of the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street, in his sermon yesterday morning told his congregation that happiness was a major duty of life, but he cautioned his hearers that some of the happiest persons on earth were in institutions for the insane.
Public indifference to official corruption revealed by the Seabury Investigation, and otherwise was criticized in sermons yesterday.

The sale of the United States Lines to a newly organized company controlled by the International Mercantile Marine Company and R. Stanley Dollar and Kenneth D. Dawson of the Pacific Coast, and the collapse of the Intercoastal Steamship Conference are regarded as the most important events in American shipping in 1931.

The annual Bal Guignol will be held on the night of Jan. 15 in the ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton for the benefit of the Reconstruction Unit of the Post-Graduate Hospital. At several recent meetings of various committees for the dance, plans were made for a special entertainment and decorative features.

Because we have given the American Indians nothing but cruelty and hardship they have a claim upon us which no other race or people have, Mgr. John P. Chidwlck, pastor of St. Agnes's Roman Catholic Church, declared in a sermon yesterday morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Gene Turnney, who in his time has outpointed such diverse personalities as the Manassa Mauler and the Bard of Avon, gave a basing lesson yesterday afternoon. His pupils were the 600 or so inmates of the Department of Correction's hospital on Welfare Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- On Friday night more than a thousand "Jeffersonian Democrats" will assemble here at the annual Jackson Day dinner, where they will listen to "keynote" addresses by all living Democratic nominees for President, including James M. Cox of Ohio, 1920; John W. Davis of West Virginia, 1924, and Alfred E. Smith of New York. 1928.

The Transit Commission made public yesterday an agreement with the B.M.T.'s rapid transit operating company, the New York Rapid Transit Corporation, reducing from $11,944,419.20 to $5,423,101.56 the company's accrued deficit, as of June 30, 1931, under Contract 4 with the city.

The City Affairs Committee, in a letter to George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, defended its recent criticism of delays in public school construction, and declared that Dr. Ryan, in his reply had not quoted accurately the charges made by the committee.

Dr. Will Durant, philosopher, outlined yesterday in a lecture a complete national and international program of rehabilitation which, he declared, would save our civilization from the danger of succumbing to the same process of disintegration and decay as destroyed Grecian, Spanish and French civilizations after military struggles which he compared to the World War.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Squads of heavily armed detectives tonight guarded every highway entering Houston, Texas, believing the Young band of desperadoes were heading for that State. The belief was supported by a message from Streetman, Texas.
THE Man from Barbados pulled up a chair and began orating on his usual topic, which is hockey. As a preliminary, he lighted a cigar.
ATLANTA, Ga., Jan. 3 -- Dividend checks for more than $5,000,000, representing earnings of Georgia corporations in the last three months of 1931, were mailed yesterday.

Overcome by gas while attempting to inflate a toy balloon in the bathroom of his home, William Goddard, 14-year-old student of Polytechnic Preparatory Country Day School, who lives at 119 Kenmore Place, in the Flatbush district of Brooklyn, was rushed to Kings County Hospital last night and there placed in a respiration chamber in an effort to save his life.
A generally optimistic outlook for 1932 has been taken by 135 editors of business papers in opinions expressed in their ninth semi-annual survey of the business outlook.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Another Western Conference basketball championship will be launched tomorrow night, with three games on the opening card.

Listen to a tale of woe! The Massachusetts State Republican Committee, has cut off its telephone service. Its office force is reduced to one man. Lieut. Gov. YOUNGMAN, yearning for promotion, hastened to relieve this official poverty. He offered to pay the committee's telephone bills.

A rare collection of musical instruments dating back to the Fourteenth Century, about twenty instruments in all, was presented last night to the Music School of the Henry Street Settlement by Mrs. Juliette de Coppet Stengel, daughter of the late Edward J. de Coppet, founder of the Flonzaley Quartet, and daughter-in-law of Mme.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 3 -- Airplanes and bloodhounds aided several hundred law officers, National Guardsmen and citizens today as they searched through Southwestern Missouri and parts of adjoining States for members of the Young gang, who escaped yesterday after killing six county and city officers and wounding two others in a battle on a farm seven miles west of here.
LONDON. Jan. 3 (AP) -- People in widely separated parts of the world tonight were facing almost unparalleled weather conditions which have caused heavy losses in human life and property.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- Deflation in grains, live stock and all commodities has carried prices down to the lowest levels in years, and the start of 1932 is on a better basis than in recent years. Trade leaders in general look forward to better things.

Faith that the world is now at the forking of the economic road and that the new year has blessings in store if the future is approached with courage was expressed in several sermons from New York pulpits yesterday.

At a moment when third-party clamor by Republican independents is being revived at Washington, a life-size impressionist portrait of William E. Borah, "America's Senator-at-Large," is being hung in Ray T. Tucker's already well-filled portrait gallery of Presidential possibilities.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 3. -- The Hudson Valley Hockey Club turned back the Osceola Club, 12 to 2, tonight at Playland in a Westchester Amateur Hockey League engagement.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Rebels who rose against the government at La Paz were defeated by forces in Entra Rios Province, said officials in Buenos Aires tonight, and the rising has been put down.

John Brennan, former cross-country captain at Fordham University, established a new course record in capturing the time prize at the weekly handicap road run conducted under the auspices of the St. Anselm's Athletic Club in the Bronx yesterday.

TOKYO, Jan. 3 -- To the accompaniment of diplomatic flag-waving by some of the Chinese who judged it wise to stand in with the new regime, General Muro's division formally entered Chinchow today and established headquarters there. The local authorities thanked the Japanese commander for not entering until the Chinese troops had completed their withdrawal.

The report of the International Labor Office on its investigation of "Ford standard" wages for Europe shows low standards of living go with low wages, according to the Twentieth Century Fund of New York, which provided the funds for the inquiry.
Breaking 96 out of a possible 100 targets, R.B. Cole led a field of twenty-nine gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday.

While General JAMES E. FECHET, former Chief of the Army Air Corps, in retiring takes a too despondent view, conditions are bad enough, as was shown by Assistant Secretary DAVISON in his annual report. In a survey of the past year The Army and Navy Journal says of the Army Air Corps:

BERLIN, Dec. 31 -- The last week of the year has witnessed definite improvement in sentiment, which was expressed in the sharpest recovery of securities since mid-September. The report of the advisory committee at Basle was taken favorably. The fact that this report, while describing in detail Germany's present financial difficulties, almost ignores the question of her capacity to pay in average prosperous times, was interpreted as foreshadowing a provisional "moratorium settlement."

MONTEVIDEO, Jan. 3. -- Argentine bankers, business men, farmers, cattlemen and every one else associated with the republic's economic activities heaved a sigh of relief as the worst year in recent history terminated.

The City Club, in a communication forwarded yesterday to the legislative committee investigating the administration of justice in this State, suggested that nomination of judges be by the Governor, with the right reserved to the people to make additional nominations by petition, all on a non-partisan ballot.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 3. -- Splits in the All-India Congress ranks were apparent in Northern India before Mahatma Gandhi's arrest. In the United Provinces a new "no-rent" campaign has caused serious differences among Congress politicians, who fear it will set the landlords against the Congress party and will sidetrack the proper development of the Nationalist movement.

Spirited sextets from Canada and Minnesota dealt defeats to the two leading ice hockey club teams of the metropolitan district in the amateur double-header in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Congress will reconvene tomorrow with the leaders of both parties determined to speed action upon President Hoover's emergency recommendations. Returning to the capital today members reported that the Home districts insist on quick disposition of measures aimed to correct credit conditions and afford assistance to the railroads.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 3. -- Operations of ateel mills last week were some-what better than had been expected. For the six working days, the average daily output approximated the daily rate In the first four days of the preceding week. In ingot production the rate was approximately 20 per cent of capacity.
CHICAGO, Jan. 3. -- Receipts of cattle at seven leading markets in 1931 were 8,324,000, the smallest since 1915. Prices were the lowest in recent years.

STE. MARGUERITE, Que., Jan. 3. -- Although handicapped by an injury to Rodger Bushell, the Cambridge captain, the combined team Oxford and Cambridge Universies took the International ski meet today from McGill University of Montreal by nearly three points.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 3 -- Naval exercises preliminary to the fleet manoeuvres in the Pacific will begin tomorrow when ships of the scouting force of the United States fleet, now at Atlantic coast ports, begin moving south to Guantanamo, Cuba. They will hold gunnery exercises there for the remainder of this month and then will depart for the Pacific Coast for "war" exercises and joint concentration with other forces of the fleet.

Three programs of dancing made yesterday another busy day for those who follow such performances. In the afternoon Ruth Page, assisted by Blake Scott and a group, gave the second presentation of her new "Cinderella" ballet at the Booth Theatre, before an audience which though small in size was distinguished in character and generous in applause.

Announcement was made yesterday by Paul Block, chairman of the 1931 emergency appeal of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies, that the campaign which was to have been concluded Dec. 31 had been extended for ten days as from that date.

BALTIMORE, Md., Jan. 3. -- When an old-fashioned watch ornamented with diamonds came into the hands of a Baltimore art collector recently the nearly century-old legend and mystery of what became of Abraham Lincoln's intended wedding gift to his bride was solved, according to the collector.

The railroads of the country today will put into effect the freight rate rise recently granted by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The increase in net revenues resulting from this freight rate rise, which it is expected will amount to between $100,000,000 and $125,000,000 annually, will be pooled and used to furnish financial assistance to railroads with a view to preventing defaults on fixed charges.
HAVANA, Jan. 3 (AP) -- Lavelle (Buddy) Ensor, famed jockey of a few years ago, came back in dramatic fashion at Oriental Park today.

Columbia University has taken the lead in establishing higher standards in the practice of surgery and other specialized branches of medicine, it wag announced yesterday by the University Council, by its adoption of the degree of Master of Science in postgraduate medical education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- In a comparison of the expenditures of the Federal Government for the fiscal years 1911 and 1931, appearing in an article in today's NEW YORK TIMES, the extraordinary growth of the number and the cost of new arms of the government, created in recent years, stood forth in graphic form.

Governor Paul M. Pearson of the Virgin Islands arrived last night on the steamship Munorleans on his way to Washington with a resolution from the St. Thomas Harbor Board petitioning Congress to grant to the Virgin Islands permanent exemption from the application of the United States coastwise shipping laws.

ALBANY, Jan. 3. -- New York State residents enjoyed good health during 1931, Dr. Thomas Parran Jr., State Commissioner, reported today. That the health of the people should remain good while there was so much unemployment, was paradoxical, Dr. Parran said.

DETROIT, Jan. 3 (AP). -- Showing a surprising reversal of form, the Detroit Falcons defeated Toronto's Maple Leafs, leaders of the International Group of the National Hockey League, by 3 to 2 tonight in an overtime match that was a wild, uproarious scramble from start to finish.

PARIS, Jan. 1 -- In financial circles here the idea that the present depression has been due to and will be prolonged by a scarcity of gold is regarded as altogether incorrect. The case of France is taken to prove the economic fallacy of that idea, for whereas there exists on the French market what amounts to gold inflation, nevertheless depression in France itself is increasing.

GILROY, Cal., Jan. 3 (AP). -- Mrs. Gertrude McEnroe of Butte, Mont., who directed officers to the scene of Lieutenant French's death, near here today, told them that she left San Francisco with him at 5 A.M. to drive to Los Angeles, and that he had apparently become deranged and sought to take her life and his own.

An entertainment under the auspices of the Child Placing and Adoption Committee of the State Charities Aid Association will be given on Wednesday night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis. The proceeds will be used to find good homes for destitute children.

With two excellent acts to start it off and the Four -- count 'em -- Marx Brothers to close it, the first new vaudeville program to arrive at the Palace in more than two months is currently on view there as successor to the Cantor-Jessel show. In one way and another the bill manages to line up a pretty fair entertainment, although between its extremities it is inclined to slump distressingly.

Most of the 104 contributions that added $2,150.25 to the Neediest Cases Fund yesterday were accompanied by letters expressing a continued determination not to let the response to this twentieth annual appeal fall short.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 3 -- Churchless Sundays returned to Mexico City today for the Catholic population after one and a half years of amity between the church and the State.
Many year-end changes in the personnel of banks, Stocks Exchang firms and industrial corporation were announced yesterday.

"A Chapter in American Art" Is the title of an exhibition that opens today at the Rehn Gallery. It is an important and engrossing chapter, the collaborators being all of Mr. Rehn's "regulars," and a few who are doubtless in process of becoming "regulars."
NEW YORK. Sir John Bell of London is arriving on the Olympic and will be at the Barclay.

With no base price for men, material or money for building purposes, the new year in the construction industry in about eight-tenths of the country starts from scratch, according to Alien E. Beals. Writing in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports, Mr. Beals lays emphasis on the fact that this is a buyers' market, with buyers scarce.

ON a brisk afternoon in the Fall of 1917, a short but compactly built player wearing the Orange of Syracuse University stood on Nebraska's 30-yard "line in the football game between those institutions at Lincoln. The score was 9-7, favor Nebraska.

The Manhattan Symphony Orchestra, Henry Hadley conducting, presented a program of music last night at the Waldorf-Astoria that relied on composers no more recent than Berlioz, although there were arrangements of two of three works by men of this century.

Two motives apparently actuate the Senate Finance Committee in inquiring into the sale of foreign bonds in this country. One is to expose the profits made by the bankers who handled those loans. The other is to bring a reproach against the Government for not having vetoed such flotations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The International Labor Defense has announced that it will fight the execution of John Moore, Winston Salem Negro sentenced to the electric chair "for stealing a pair of shoes."

Six ships of the scouting force of the United States Fleet which have been berthed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard during the holidays will haul down the withered pine trees from their fore and main tops today, shift their colors from flagstaffs to gaffs, cast off their mooring lines, and, steaming out the Narrows, head south for the annual Winter exercises and manoeuvres.

HAMILTON, Ont., Jan. 3 (Canadian Press). -- John Dickenson -- the last of Hamilton's "Five Johns" who amassed fortunes by ignoring the advice of the greatest experts of their generation -- died here today in his eighty-fifth year. He was associated with the late Sir John Gibson, John Patterson, John Sutherland and John Moodie in the promotion of the Cataract Power Enterprise, which later became the Dominion Power and Transmission Company.

CHICAGO, Jan. 3 -- A nursemaid employed in the home of John H. Heindel of River Forest, a suburb, killed two little children left in her charge and then committed suicide by hanging early today. Her act was attributed to insane jealousy of the children, to whom she was intensely devoted, coupled with a fear which had grown into an hallucination that she was to be separated from them by dismissal.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 3 -- There can be no such return of the Protestant churches to the Roman Catholic church as Pope Pius XI suggested in his recent encyclical, the Rev. Dr. Samuel Trexler of New York City, president of the United Lutheran Synod of New York, said in a sermon preached this morning at the Lutheran Church of the Holy Communion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 -- Latin-American nations, with few exceptions, face a discouraging outlook in foreign and domestic commerce for 1932, after a year featured by the imposition of high tariffs to balance budgets, dislocation of public finances and restrictions on basic commodity production in an effort to better prices, according to a survey, of economic trends made public today by the Department of Commerce.
ALBANY, Jan. 3 -- With his annual message drafted, Governor Roosevelt returned to Albany tonight prepared for a busy week. The Legislature will convene Wednesday noon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 3 -- Experiments with the use of talking films in education will begin in the junior high schools of Lynn, Quincy and Revere this week. Tests to discover the effectiveness of teaching science with the supplementary aid of films will continue over a period of six weeks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter in THE TIMES signed "British" seems to call for some corrective reply. Before considering his views, permit me to assure "British" that after four delightful years among his fellow-countrymen, at Oxford and in the British Museum and the Public Record Office, whose friendship I highly prize, I am not as Anglophobe as my comment here might indicate.

The Fifth Avenue Association announced yesterday that it would begin a campaign on Jan. 20 to get the Board of Estimate to direct the proper city officials to begin negotiations with the New York Central and the New York Harlem Railroads for the removal of all surface car lines from Madison and Fourth Avenues.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 3. -- The result of the prohibition referendum in Finland is viewed with considerable satisfaction by the anti-prohibition forces now engaged here in an effort to advance what they regard as a growing movement toward repeal or modification of the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead act.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 2. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average of 1926, is 66.3, which compares with 66.7 a week ago, 67 two weeks ago, 67.1 three weeks ago and 67.6 four weeks ago. The highest average, of 1931 was 78.5 in the week ended Jan. 3; the 66.7 of Dec. 26 was the lowest.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Jan. 3 -- Sensational riding by Jockeys S. Coucci and T. Reno, each of whom scored a triple at the Agua Caliente race track today, featured a program of eight ordinary events which were contested over a track that still was sloppy, although the weather had cleared.

John F. (Chick) Meehan, former football coach at Syracuse and New York University, will take over his new duties as director of physical education at Manhattan College today. Meehan will also coach football at Manhattan.

Joseph A. Broderick, State Banking Superintendent, will make a second attempt to have the Legislature enact a bill to provide for the segregation of thrift accounts in commercial banking institutions.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3. -- Despite threatening weather, the Tulane-Southern California game at Pasadena New Year's Day smashed all Rosa Bowl records for attendance and gate receipts.

Surveying the outlook for 1932 in a statement issued yesterday, James Speyer of Speyer Co. warned that this country cannot expect a return to prosperity as long as the rest of the world is in distress, and urged assistance for the railroads, remodeling of "antiquated anti-trust laws" and amendment of the prohibition law as essential to the solution of industrial and financial problems.

A fleet of forty planes, all but one or two of which will be piloted by amateur fliers, will take off this morning from the Long Island Aviation Country Club field at Hicksville, L.I., for Miami. The pilots and an equal number of passengers are for the most part members of the recently formed United States Amateur Air Pilots Association and the national chain of aviation country clubs.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4 -- A total income from premiums and investments exceeding $216,829,000, an amount greater than the income in the boom year of 1929 and only .27 per cent under that of 1930 was announced here today in a preliminary annual statement by the three travelers insurance companies.

St. John's College received its first scare of the basketball season from a fighting Niagara University five in the 106th Infantry Armory last night, but rallied after trailing at one stage, 10 to 2, to win by 36 to 26. It was a nip-and-tuck battle throughout he first half, and it was not until midway in the second half that the Redmen clinched the game.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Reversing a judgment by the Supreme Judicial Court of Maine, the Supreme Court of the United States today decided that some intangible assets are subject to inheritance taxes only by the State where the owner lives. The decision, which is regarded as of great interest, was in the case of the First National Bank of Boston, executor of the estate of Edward H. Haskell, against the State of Maine.
Senate. Passed Capper bill authorizing Farm Board to distribute 40,000,000 bushels of wheat to charity.

Reports were current yesterday that Governor Roosevelt was leaning strongly toward the appointment of a Republican, preferably one without strong party ties, to succeed Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood as a member of the State Transit Commission.

Formation of the Stock Exchange firm of Biggs, Mohrman Co. by four young, men who were associated with the late John W. Pope, stockmarket operator and member of the Stock Exchange, was announced yesterday. The firm's offices are at 1 Wall Street.
BERLIN, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Dee. 31 shows the following changes, in reichsmarks:

ELIZABETH, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Fire, preceded by an explosion that blew out the north wall of a two-family dwelling at 608 Second Avenue, in the Italian section of this city, destroyed the building late tonight. The explosion was heard many blocks away.

A 12-year-old boy, who had been stunned and critically burned by a shock from a third rail on the tracks of the Long Island Railroad at Shepherd Avenue, Brooklyn, was dragged by three younger companions from the path of an onrushing express train just after dusk last night.

Max Schmeling, heavyweight champion of the world, was counted out in the first round last night -- but not in the prize ring. It happened in the invitation ping-pong tournament played at the Hotel Algonquin under the auspices of the American Ping Pong Association.

Securities weakened on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday under the leadership of utilities and oils, with few of the declines attaining important proportions. Several industrial stocks shared in the declines, among them Aluminum of America, Cord Corporation, Ford of Canada A and B, and some inactive issues. Woohvorth, Ltd., advanced.

The new calendar system in Supreme Court of New York County, whereby the calendar will be called only once a week to save time for the court, attorneys and litigants, was put into effect yesterday. The calendar of cases which will be heard up to Friday was called in trial term before Justice Isidor Wasservogel and in special term before Justice Phoenix Ingraham.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 4. -- A "pay-as-you-go administration" was promised Philadelphia by J. Hampton Moore today as he took the oath of office as Mayor for the second time in twelve years. The 112th Mayor, peering into a treasury which does not contain funds sufficient to meet the city and county payrolls of Jan. 1, and to which is due more than $20,000,000 in delinquent taxes, immediately set in motion plans to effect drastic economies.

In the congestion of the centennial calendar we had forgotten that CHARLES STUART CALVERLEY was born Dec. 22,1831; born BLADES, the unromantic name taken by his grandfather, doubtless for sufficient pecuniary consideration, and thrown off by his father in the "50s.

This Time It Is the Bluegrass The typical American community resents the Interference of "outsiders" in its affairs. It is only necessary to tell troublesome strangers to "go back where they came from" to get the average town or county lined up on that side, even though the strangers are protecting the oppressed or the innocent.

MONCK'S CORNER, S.C., Jan. 4 (AP). -- Two depositors of the branch of the People's State Bank, which closed here Saturday, entered the bank today, forced an assistant cashier to open the vault, fled with $2,000, and then returned and surrendered after hiding the money.

Nearly 400 persons thronged the court room and corridor of the new matrimonial branch of the Brooklyn Supreme Court yesterday morning, some seeking divorce, some separation, and some simply satisfying their curiosity concerning this new departure in court practice, which functioned smoothly under its bachelor judge, Justice Lewis L. Fawcett.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 4 -- The organization meeting of the 1932 Board of Supervisors was marked today by the dropping of Pliny W. Williamson, former majority leader, from the committee on budget and appropriations.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange failed yesterday to make much headway in the first full trading period of the new year. United States Government bonds were weak, and domestic corporation issues averaged substantially lower for the day. Leading foreign loans, however, made some progress, but many of the lower-rated issues of the foreign group lost a point or more in relatively quiet trading.

When the full record of the year 1931 is written, no chapter will be more striking than the one dealing with public health. The country was in the grip of the most serious industrial depression in a generation. No large area was exempt from its effects, Town and country, farmer and mechanic, East and West, North and South -- all were affected.

HONOLULU, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Recent acts of criminal violence here were followed today by a statement from Governor Lawrence M. Judd that a special session of the Hawaiian Legislature would be called if leaders of the House and Senate could agree on a program of constructive action.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- When the Philippine Legislative Committee, which has arrived in this country to urge Philippine independence, confers with Secretary of War Hurley, administrative officials will want to know just what their program is for meeting the obligations of independence in event it is granted them.

Miss Mary Jane Moore, daughter of Mrs. C. Lewis Moore and of Joseph A. Moore, was introduced to society yesterday at a luncheon which her mother gave at the Central Park Casino. Mrs. Moore and her daughter received in the Black and Gold Room, which had been decorated with palms and silvered smilax.

Twenty seamen, representing the engine room and deck crews of the German freighter Bockenhelm, were taken from the ship in Port Newark yesterday afternoon and lodged in the Seamen's Church Institute in New York to await return to Germany, where they face trial and possible imprisonment on insubordination charges.

The recent discovery that the "Peking Man" (Sinanthropus Pekingensis) whose fossil remains were found in a cave less than forty miles from Peking knew how to make a fire and to use tools of stone and bone, is evidence that man must have lived upon the earth far before the time when this individual dwelt in an artificially lighted cave.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Rear Admiral Clark Howell Woodward, commander of Cruiser Division 3 of the United States fleet, who is familiar with Nicaraguan affairs, has been designated by President Hoover as his personal representative in Nicaragua, to be appointed by the Supreme Court of Nicaragua as chairman of the National Board of Elections.

SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Jan. 4 (AP) -- Aware that an encounter possibly will mean a fight to the death, hundreds of officers tonight continued to scour the Southwest in a search for the Young band of desperadoes who slew a Sheriff and five of his aides Saturday.

SANTA MONICA, Cal., Jan. 4 (AP). -- George von Elm, runner-up for the 1931 national open title, and Stanley Turner, both of Los Angeles, today won the Santa Monica $2,500 amateur-professional golf championship, shooting a best-ball score of 66, five under par.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- Considerable political emotion has been caused in France by the publication yesterday in La Depeche de Toulouse of what in reality is the first formal demand in the moderate French press for the wiping out of the reparations debt and a new start with Germany.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The first definite step toward a reduction in Federal salaries as an economy measure was taken today when Senator Borah, Republican, of Idaho, introduced a bill to cut the salaries of the chief officers of the nation, exclusive of the President of the United States and members of the judiciary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Without a record vote the Senate today passed the Capper resolution, authorizing the Federal Farm Board to distribute 40,000,000 bushels of its wheat to suffering Americans. The distribution would be made through the National Red Cross or by such organization as the President might designate, and the Federal Farm Board would be recompensed for the wheat at the prevailing market price at the time of delivery.

With the neatness and digpatch characteristic of the game which carried him to tennis heights, William T. Tilden 2d of Phlladelphia won his first match in defense of his world's professional indoor title last night in the elapsed time of twenty-four minutes.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The response to the government's appeal for prompt payment of the new income tax of five shillings in the pound to help balance Great Britain's budget continues on a scale that astonishes the collectors.

Democratic leadership in Congress has shown common sense in its tariff program. The futile gesture of preparing new rate schedules has been abandoned. They could not escape the double check of a Republican Senate and a Republican President Even if a two-thirds majority of both houses could have been marshaled for certain changed rates against a veto, the new measure would not have been Democratic; it would have been mongrel.

The difficulty of obtaining funds for its sixtieth anniversary endowment drive, begun in 1929, has compelled the American Museum of Natural History to discontinue all exploration and field research work throughout 1932, it was said last night by Dr. Henry Fairfield Osborn in his report as president, presented before the sixty-third annual meeting of the trustees held at the Brook Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- The Democrats set forth their tariff policy today in a four-point bill carrying a section that would deprive the President of the power to raise or lower duties on the reports of the Tariff Commission and would transfer that power to Congress.

Controller Charles W. Berry said yesterday that he would question Deputy City Clerk James J. McCormick under oath in the next few days on the "gratuities" McCormick received for performing of civil marriages at the Manhattan Marriage License Bureau.

Joseph Rao, henchman of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer and a gang leader in his own right, was arrested early yesterday morning when he and another man tried to beat a patrolman on East 116th Street. His arrest on a charge of felonious assult ended an Intensive search begun last July after the Harlem "baby killing."

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, Jan. 4. -- Oliver N. Burdett, architectural sculptor, killed himself with a shotgun at 7 o'clock this morning in the attic of hia residence at 8 Buena Vista Drive here. He was 72 years old and for eight months had been suffering from a nervous breakdown.

Charles G. Dawes, United States Ambassador to Great Britain, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Enropa on his way to Washington to confer with the State Department about the disarmament conference. He said that he expected to travel to Europe with the delegation of which he is to be head.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 4 -- Japan has landed 100 bluejackets at Foochow and has ordered three destroyers to proceed there immediately following an anti-Japanese outbreak yesterday in which a Japanese school teacher and his wife were murdered by a Chinese mob.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 4. -- The first deficiency bill for the 1932 fiscal year, which authorized a total appropriation of $125,886,262.75, the first indication of the rigid economy of the Democratic program, was introduced in the House today by Joseph W. Byrns of Tennessee, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.

With the formal announcement yesterday of the calls for statement of condition as of Dec. 31 by the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banks, additions banks and trust companies made public their positions at the end of the year.

The Simms Petroleum Company has called a special meeting of stockholders for Jan. 18 to approve the further purchase of 100,000 shares of its stock at an average price of $5 a share. If the purchase ia authorized, each stockholder of record of Jan. 20 will have the right to sell to the company at any time before Feb. 10 up to one-seventh of his stock at that price.
LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Two years of talk on drink by the Government Licensing Commission here has resulted in three rival reports, according to political gossip.
CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Peter B. Carey was elected today president of the Chicago Board of Trade, receiving 815 votes of 837 cast. Fred Uhlmann was chosen vice president.

ALBANY, Jan. 4 -- Governor Roosevelt was making final corrections in his annual message today and the legislative leaders were active in routine work in preparation for the opening at noon on Wednesday of a session of the Legislature which, in the popular mind, will have a definite link with national politics in a Presidential year.

BERLIN, Jan. 4 -- With Chancellor Bruening back at his desk after a brief holiday in the Black Forest and the twenty-four-day political truce proclaimed by President van Hindenburg in December terminated last night, the resumption of political activities centres on the coming reparations conference at Lausanne.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Democratic National Committee filed today with the Clerk of the House of Representatives photostatic copies of the payroll of its New York headquarters during the 1928 campaign in reply to the charge made by Representative Will R. Wood, Republican, of Indiana, that its failure to file an itemized account of payroll expenditures constituted a violation of the corrupt practices act.

Philip A. deLaszlo's loan exhibition of portraits opened yesterday at the Knoedler Galleries, where it will remain until Jan. 16. An admission fee la being charged and the proceeds will go to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund.

Powdered, perfumed and bored, 130 feline aristocrats began competition yesterday in the thirtieth annual show of the Atlantic Cat Club at the Hotel McAlpin. The proceeds of the show will be donated to the Bide-a-Wee Home for Animals.
