only $65,000,000 was credited in the first half of the year. General expenditures amounted to $1,372,071,000 200, an increase of $259,000,000. due chiefly to the public building program.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Reduction of the size of battleships, an 8,000-ton limit for cruisers and complete abolition of submarines were said tonight to be the three main proposals which Britain will press at the forthcoming Disarmament Conference in Geneva.

Samuel Seabury, who has just won a legal fight to punish Mayor Walker's financial agent, Russell T. Sherwood for contempt of the Hofstadter committee, encountered defiance yesterday from State Senator John A. Hastings, another of the Mayor's intimates whom he had sought to question.

Hulda Lashanska, New York soprano, who makes public appearances in recital rarely, and then always for charity, gave a concert last night at the Town Hall. The proceeds were to be divided by the Visiting Nurse Service, administered by the Henry Street Settlement and by the Hudson Guild in the Chelsea district of the city.

The leaders won throughout the two groups in the Class C Metropolitan League squash tennis matches that were played last night, though in one instance the lower-ranked team put up a stubborn fight before conceding defeat.

MUKDEN, Jan. 4 -- Apparently believing the United States would be satisfied with a formal expression of regret for the brutal beating administered in Mukden by Japanese soldiers to Culver B. Chamberlain, newly named American Consul at Harbin, only slight disciplinary punishment of the soldiers has been ordered, with mere dismissal for the Japanese civilian interpreter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4.-- Representative James M. Beck of Pennsylvania, former Solicitor General of the United States and leader of the Republican "wet" forces in the House, today virtually served notice on Senator Davis of his State that unless he soon comes out for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, a "wet" Republican will seek his seat.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Following is the text of President Hoover's message to Congress today:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Jan. 4 -- Today's dispatches from Argentina report the complete failure of yesterday's attempted revolution in the province of Entre Rios, saying order has been completely restored.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Broad Meadows, one of the most consistent of the performers from E.R. Bradley's Idle Hour Farm, got down in front of his field for the first time during the Winter season to win the six-furlong feature at Jefferson Park today.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday Jan. 5 (Canadian Press). -- A new cricket record was added to the long list held by Australia's premier batsman, Don Bradman, in yesterday's play in the test match with South Africa. With his captain, W. M Woodfull, Bradman scored 274 runs for the second wicket, beating the world's mark of 235 made by Woodfull and C.G. Macartney at Leeds, England, in 1926.

A plan to refund bonds of Miami, Cocoanut Grove and Silver Grove, Fla., now annexed, set to mature from June 30, 1931, to June 30, 1941, by a new issue of $16,258,000, dated July 1, 1931, and due serially up to July 1, 1963, was announced yesterday by George W. Simons Jr., executive director of the Municipal Securities Association, an organization of investment bankers with headquarters in Jacksonville, Fla.
As its contribution to the Washington bicentennial celebration this year, the New York Public Library will issue a facsimile of the original manuscript of Washington's farewell address.

New public financing throughout the country in 1931, excluding domestic and Canadian municipal issues, amounted to only $2,253,968,000, compared with $5,045,149,000 in 1930 and with $6,262,906,000 in 1929, according to a compilation by Otto P. Schwarzschild, editor of American Underwriting Houses and Their Issues and manager of the National Statistical Service.

Directors of the Railroad Credit Corporation will meet on Jan. 21 to approve a plan whereby railroads sharing in the revenue pool which the corporation is to administer will be enabled to anticipate their advances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- A vigorous protest against the attack by Japanese soldiers in Mukden yesterday on Culver B. Chamberlain of Kansas City, Mo., American Consul who was proceeding to his post in Harbin, was made today by Secretary Stimson to Katsuji Debuchi, the Japanese Ambassador, with the request that he transmit it to the Tokyo Government.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 4 (AP). -- President Uriburu's Provisional Government appeared tonight to have strengthened the probabilities of an orderly transfer of office to President-elect Augustin Justo by its decisive subjugation of yesterday's revolt in Entre Rios Province.

PARIS, Jan. 4. -- The Bourse began the year with a bad session. Weakness which developed last Thursday was accentuated today, and except French rentes, losses were general. After brief rise at the opening, stocks dropped sharply, rallied slightly later, and then dropped again, closing generally at the lowest levels of the day.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Ten "commandments" which he declared would help to stabilize the country and cure the ills of depression were given by Representative Sirovich of New York in a speech in the House today. He asserted that Europe was ready to go to war again and that since the 1815 treaty at Vienna between Russia, Austria and Prussia, the Old World has been a boiling pot of international intrigue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- According to opinion in naval circles, Secretary Adams will declare his sympathy with the $616,000,000 naval replacement bill of Representative Vinson, chairman of the House Naval Committee, when hearings on the bill begin before that committee tomorrow, and Admiral William Pratt, chief of operations, will endorse the ten-year replacement program wholeheartedly.

TORONTO, Jan. 4 -- Irving E. Robertaon, editor-in-chief of The Toronto Evening Telegram, died here tonight of pneumonia. He was the only surviving son of the late John Rosa Robertson, founder of the paper. He was born in Toronto in 1882.

WASHINGTON, Jan, 4 -- Declaring that an "open factory" is the best answer to communism, Representative Rainey of Illinois, Democratic leader in the House, in a nation-wide radio broadcast tonight, over the National Broadcasting system, advocated steps to revive the international trade of the United State, even to the point of open dealing with Soviet Russia.

Three hundred coal drivers employed in Manhattan and the Bronx by Burns Brothers, the Stephens Fuel Company and their subsidiaries will go on strike this morning in protest against a proposed 10 per cent wage cut. At the same time 600 coal drivers employed by these firms in New Jersey will strike in sympathy with the drivers here while 700 drivers of other companies here are expected to be locked out by their employers.

The likelihood that the United States will not aid Germany further through an extension of the debt moratorium, was indicated by William R. Castle Jr., Under-Secretary of State, in an address yesterday before the School of Politics of the Women's National Republican Club, 8 East Thirty-seventh Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Democrats, far and wide, were reported today to be making rung on Federal postoffices in purchases of the new one-half cent Washington bicentennial commemorative postage stamps. The motive underlying this unusual run leaked out today in Rochester, Ind., where dozens of Fulton County Democrats bought up hundreds of the seals.

Entries for the invitation contract bridge tournament for artists, writers and newspapermen to be held in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt tomorrow evening have been coming in at a rate which indicates that more than 200 persons will participate, it was announced yesterday by Bridge Headquarters, Inc., the advisory council of which is sponsoring the affair.

The Transit Commission, in a statement issued yesterday by Chairman William G. Fullen and Leon G. Godley, denied that its tentative $474,500,000 unification plan provided for a pledge of city credit back of all interest and amortization charges on Board of Transit Control bonds and bonds of the elevated lines of the B M.T. and Interborough.

To many who find it almost impossible to resist the plea of street beggars the statement of the Welfare Council yesterday will come as a relief. Sympathy and softness too easily overrule the clear knowledge of harm done by giving money to some woebegone person shivering in a doorway.

Reserving decision on the city's plea for further time to solve the bus problem, the Appellate Division in Brooklyn indicated yesterday that it would grant the extension, but warned against further pleas for more time.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Jan. 4 (AP). -- Anthony M. Then, president of the Toms River Trust Company, closed by the State, was under arrest today charged with making a fraudulent loan. The complaint was made by the State Department of Banking and Insurance. He was held in $1,500 bail when he waived hearing before a justice of the peace.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Lieut. Col. Harold Edward Sherwin Holt, retired, died here today at the age of 69 after a long illness. He was an aviation enthusiast and a pioneer in the development of aeronautical accessories, notably parachutes and flares for night flying.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Sir Walter Layton's secret draft report which was rejected by the Bank for International Settlements advisory committee on the Young Plan at Basle is making trouble in the Franco-British negotiations on reparations.

The first of the monthly index numbers to be published as of Jan. 1, the compilation of Dun's Review, shows that the general average of commodity prices increased .28 per cent during December. This increase brings the present average price to 140,681, compared with 136.416 on Oct. 1, 1931, the low level for the year.

Reports from Tulsa, Okla., that a merger of the Sinclair Consolidated Oil Corporation, the Prairie Oil and Gas Company and the Prairie Pipe Line Company had been completed were denied yesterday in a joint statement by H.F. Sinclair, W.S. Fitzpatrick and Clark Kountz, the officials designated by their respective companies to negotiate for a merger.

Bennie Alien of Kansas City scored his third consecutive victory in the State pocket billiard championship tournament by triumphing over Onofrio Lauri of Brooklyn, 125 to 49, in twenty-three innings at Dwyer's Broadway Academy last night. The victory enabled Alien to retain his hold on first place.
NEW YORK. Lady Lister-Kaye will leave the Ambassador today for Washington and later will go to Palm Beach.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Following is the text of the Democratic tariff bill, as introduced by Representative Collier:

TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 5 -- A determined raid on Sinmin was made yesterday evening by 600 bandits, who were driven off early this morning after violent street lighting with the Japanese garrison. The casualties reported up till 1:30 A.M. today were three Chinese civilians and one Japanese soldier killed and eight wounded.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the turmoil of discussions of reparations and our public and private loans to foreigners, it is noted that no one in authority has presented any plan whereby the foreign debtors could pay their debts to us without undue burden on either the debtor or the creditor.

A Joint statement on behalf of leading Protestant, Catholic and Jewish religious organizations, expressing the conviction that employment and not wage cutting is the cure for unemployment, was issued yesterday while relief organizations continued their efforts to reach the unfortunate with aid.

HAVANA, Jan. 4 -- Six prominent leaders of the August rebellion in Cuba were released from prison today. They are Colonels Roberto Mendez Penate, Aurelio Hevia and Manuel Balan; Mario Menocal, son of former President Mario G. Menocal; Alberto Meneses and Manuel Hevia, the son of Colonel Aurelio Hevia.

The undefeated Davis and Elkins College basketball team recorded its fifth victory of the season by triumphing over the Seventh Regiment quintet, 24 to 21, at the latter's court last night. The winners were in front, 17 to 13, at half-time.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 4 -- In a special message to Congress, which was as frank as it was unexpected, President Hoover declared this afternoon that "the paramount importance to the nation of constructive action" on his emergency economic program was "manifestly even more evident" now than it was when he submitted it to Congress a month ago.

GANDHI'S return to Poona jail brings a sorry New Year's gift to a sufficiently harassed world in the form of a renewal of civil strife in India. Whether GANDHI goes to prison as gladly as he did in May, 1930, may be questioned. This latest campaign against the British raj starts out under less favorable auspices for the Nationalist cause than the struggle which began with the salt-making expedition to the sea two years ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Dissenting from the position taken by other New England States, Rhode Island, through Governor Case, petitioned the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to Intervene in support of the plan of Eastern trunk line executives for consolidating all railroads east of the Mississippi and north of the Ohio River into four systems.

Although the matter of his 1932 contract -- which in itself is not likely to prove a small matter -- may be uppermost in his mind, Babe Ruth is skillfully concealing the fact under the guise of a deep concern for three other figures, his daily golf scores, his waistline and his weight.

In a United States Marshal's van which held eight other prisoners, including Wilfred Brunder, Negro "policy king," W. Bernard Vause, former Kings County judge, rode yesterday from the old Postoffice Building to the Federal House of Detention, to begin a six-year sentence for mail fraud, imposed on him more than a year ago.

Mrs. Anne Stillman McCormick and her husband, Fowler McCormick, a grandson of John D. Rockefeller Sr., had luncheon with Mrs. McCormick's former husband, James A. Stillman, at his residence yesterday, shortly after arriving here from Chicago.

The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday that about 8,000 employes, or about one-half of the personnel on its lines, in Texas and Louisiana, east of El Paso, had voluntarily accepted an unconditional reduction of 10 per cent in wages. The reduction affects shop men, dispatchers, yard masters, mechanical foremen, clerical workers in the general offices, dining car employes and passenger train porters.

The first move made by John F. (Chick) Meehan, new director of physical education at Manhattan College, on taking his post yesterday atternoon was the outlining of a program of intramural sports to go into effect immediately.

The fund for the relief of New York's Neediest Cases received $2,058.65 yesterday from 117 readers, who wrote that they still were trying to make up the shortage in the response to this Twentieth Annual Appeal. Their letters showed a compassion not restricted to the holiday season.

MUKDEN, Jan. 4 -- A Japanese column preceded by an armored train this afternoon left Chinchow and moved southward along the Peiping-Mukden Railway with the intention of proceeding to Shanhaikwan, there to establish contact with the Japanese garrison maintained under the Boxer protocol.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 4 -- President Svinhufvud tonight called a special session of Parliament on Jan. 19 at the Cabinet's request, to act on a bill for the repeal of prohibition, as a result of the recent consultative referendum.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- No power on earth can get the United States off the gold standard, except the United States itself, If it so chooses, Otto H. Kahn of Kuhn, Loeb Co. declared today while testifying before the Senate Finance Committee.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Jan. 4 -- Hugh P. Tiemann, assistant metallurgic engineer of the Carnegie Steel Company, died yesterday morning in the Homeopathic Hospital from an illness which had its inception in burns received on Nov. 28 in his home.

TULSA, Okla., Jan. 4 (AP). -- Oil and bank circles here heard today that the prolonged delay over merger of the Sinclair and Prairie Oil Companies had ended and that the deal would be consummated this month. The reports, which came from persons high in the councils of both parties to the merger, who declined to be quoted directly, were followed by an official announcement that any statement was unauthorized at this time.

Sidney Lenz and Commander Winfield Liggett Jr. cut 3,385 points from the lead of Mr. and Mrs. Ely Culbertson in their 150-rubber contract bridge match at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night. Despite the lead of 16,835 points left to the Culbertsons with only twenty-one rubbers to go, Mr. Lenz said at the close of play early this morning that he believed he and his partner still have "a bare chance" to win the match.

The attitude of the church toward social and economic problems was discussed yesterday at a meeting of the clergy of the Methodist Episcopal Church at headquarters of the organization, 150 Fifth Avenue. The Rev. E.A. Pollard Jones of Grace Church, Brooklyn, presided.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- The Federal Reserve Board condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Dec. 30 shows a decrease for the week of $202,000,000 in loans and Investments, increases of $307,000,000 in reserves with Federal Reserve Banks, of $118,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks and of $100,000,000 in net demand deposits and a decrease of $55,000,000 in time deposits.

In a letter to stocKholders of the United Stores Corporation, which holds 58.6 per cent of the Class A and common stocks of the Tobacco Products Corporation. George K. Morrow, chairman of United Stores, announced yesterday that the directors had unanimously approved the plan of reorganization for Tobacco Products.

PARIS, Jan. 4 (AP) -- Dr. Victor Hou, member of the Chinese delegation to the League of Nations, left today for Geneva with the reported intention of asking that the League Council be called into special session to examine the situation created by the Japanese capture of Chinchow.

MOSCOW, Jan. 4 (AP). -- The central executive committee of the Communist party tonight decided to reorganize the Supreme Economic Council, most important economic branch of the Soviet Government, by splitting it up into three independent commissariats.

CHICAGO. Jan. 4. -- A suggestion that the Republicans toss into the discard the old precedent of renominating a Republican President for a second term and begin to look around for "the best man in the United States," even though that involved having Mr. Hoover "step aside," was voiced in an editorial today in The Rockford Register-Republic, which is published by Ruth Hanna McCormick.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Sir Dennis Burney, builder of the airship R-100, will sail for New York on the Berengaria Wednesday with his new rear-engined streamline car, which he expects will revolutionize the world's automobile industry.

Frederic E. Williamson, the new president of the New York Central Railroad, and W.B. Storey, president of the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, agreed yesterday that on developments other than increased traffic would depend an improvement in railroad conditions this year.

BOMBAY, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru was sentenced at Allahabad today to two years at hard labor on a charge of violating one of the new restrictive ordinances. Pandit Nehru ranks second to Mahatma Gandhi in political importance among the Nationalists and is idolized by Indian youth.

In the new year's first meeting of the new Board of Aldermen, which is composed of sixty-four Democrats and one Republican, seven newly elected members sat yesterday at desks bounteously bedecked with flowers. They were attending their initial session of the board, and the gallery of the Aldermanic Chamber was well filled by their relatives and political associates.

HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 4. -- Lines of depositors formed in the lobbies of every savings bank in Hartford today and, despite prompt handling by tellers, the lines persisted in several banks until closing time.

A jury was chosen in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions yesterday afternoon for the misdemeanor trial of Harry R. Swanson, John S. Wallis and John Erter, engineers, on an indictment charging them with violating Section 554 of the penal law by communicating information they obtained while employes of the Foster-Wheeler Corporation to the Alco Products, Inc., with which they later became connected.

MR. GEORGE HERMAN RUTH, the eminent home-run hitter, has little interest in the Soviet Five-Year Plan. He has drawn up what he calls his own Twenty-Year Plan and he is concentrating on putting it over. As a matter of fact he has it fairly well under control already. He hag it 18 down with 2 to go.

Charles D. (Casey) Stengel, former Giant and Brooklyn star outfielder and in his playing days one of the most colorful figures in baseball, has been engaged by the Robins to serve as head coach and first lieutenant to Manager Max Carey for the 1932 campaign, it was announced yesterday by Dave Driscoll, business manager.

The right hand of Salvatore Ruggirello, rangy Italian heavyweigh, claimed Walter Cobb, Kansas City and Baltimore, as a victim last night in the first round of their schedule ten-round battle at the St. Nichols Arena, providing one of the most surprising fistic upsets of recent years.

Like most people who give the matter a moment's thought, Benn Levy has a high opinion of the human race. He expresses it at considerable length in "The Devil Passes," which was played by an uncommonly distinguished company at the Selwyn last evening.

A call for payment of 10 per cent of the $500,000,000 subscribed to the gold notes of the National Credit Corporation, organized last Fall at the request of President Hoover to provide rediscounting facilities for sound banking assets not eligible for loans at the Federal Reserve, has been issued to banks throughout the country that are members of the organization.

New York City's fire-fighters are to wear more comfortable uniforms next Summer. The high coat collars, buttoning up stiffly about the throat, in which firemen and engineers have sweltered during the hot months of the past are to give way to natty coats with soft rolled collars and lapels.

Walter E. Pruzan, 51 years old, former president of the Boyish Form Corset Corporation and since the failure of that enterprise three years ago a financial adviser with desk room in an office in the Fred F. French Building, 551 Fifth Avenue, shot and killed himself there yesterday morning.

All the markets were depressed to some extent yesterday, but the weakness was most pronounced in stocks and bonds which, in rather dull dealings, lost a good part of the advance made in the closing days of 1931.

The January choice of the Book League of America, "The Weather Tree," by Maristan (Mary and Stanley) Chapman, is to be published today by the Viking Press. Like "The Happy Mountain," by the same authors, published in 1928 and also a book club selection, this new novel is a romance set in the mountains of Tennessee.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 4 -- In a surprise move Assembly wets brought out on the floor late tonight the bill of Assemblyman Anthony J. Siracusa of Atlantic, calling for repeal of the Hobart State enforcement act, the State's prohibition law. With at least four members of the wet bloc absent from the chamber the repealer was defeated by the lack of only two votes for the required majority, the vote being 29 to 22.
Seymour Wemyss Smith, former newspaper man and author, died suddenly of pneumonia early yesterday in the Hotel New Yorker. He would have celebrated his thirty-sixth birthday on Jan. 18.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- Despite the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi and the imposition of sweeping repressive ordinances in India, the British Government announced today it was determined to go ahead with its policy of constitutional progress for that country.

An experience with matrimony does strange things to the normal habits of man. To some it yields excellent material for a pessimistic philosophy, and to others only the vital statistics desired for the files of the City of New York. But there is still a class, a surprisingly large one, that upholds an ancient and honorable American tradition.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the issue of THE NEW YORK TIMES for Dec. 31, it is stated that the All-India Women's Conference now in session in Madras, India, had gone on record against "the sacrificing of human beings in religious temples." This is evidently an error in the transmission of the telegraphic message, as there is nowhere in India any sacrifice of human beings in temples.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 4. -- In compliment to Robin M. Thomas, who arrived today for a visit with Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Thomas, J. Townsend Sackett, son of Mrs. Thomas, entertained tonight with a small dinner at Patio Lamaze. Mr. Thomas is a student at Fountain Valley School in Colorado Springs.

NEW DELHI, India, Jan. 4 -- Ironclad repression was clamped down upon India today by four new sweeping ordinances. They constitute in effect a declaration of ruthless war upon the whole All-India National Congress movement.

About thirty amendments to the State banking laws will be recommended by Joseph A. Broderick, Banking Superintendent, in his annual report, to be presented tomorrow to Governor Roosevelt and the Legislature.

GENEVA, Jan. 4 -- In a communication diplomatically entitled an "aide memoire," China has reminded the Council of the League of Nations both of what has been going on around Chinchow and of its December resolution enjoining both parties not to aggravate matters.

While a country-wide search was under way for Sergeant D. Smith, of the Ordnance Department of the United States Army at Camp Dix, N.J., who is wanted for homicide in connection with the killing of his wife in their apartment at Miller Field, S.I., Sunday morning, the Richmond County grand jury completed yesterday its investigation of the case.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Prediction of trouble in Pennsylvania if Federal funds were not made available for alleviating unemployment distress was made by Governor Glfford Pinchot in testimony today before the La Follette committee investigating unemployment.

NORFOLK, Va., Jan. 4 -- With Henry L. Stevens, National Commander, sounding the keynote in his annual address to officers and members of the Virginia posts of the American Legion, the State body today endorsed project for quick relief for unemployment.

PARIS, Jan. 4 -- The international sugar conference which was due to reconvene here today to seek a readjustment of the Chadbourne sugar plan was forced to postpone the meeting for two or three weeks, causing a new drop in the price of sugar on the New York market as well as talk here of new difficulties with the Javan producers.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 4. -- Isaac Kashdan, United States representative in the international chess masters tournament at the White Rock Pavilion, and S. Flohr of Czechoslovakia were both returned winners in the seventh round today and their tie for first place remained unbroken.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Holding that a rehearing should have been permitted, the Supreme Court enjoined the Interstate Commerce Commission today from enforcing its order in the Western grain rate case under which the railroads contended they would lose $20,000,000 annually.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Creation of a State university organization to unify educational opportunities in New Jersey, establishment of at least eight junior colleges, and a plan of organization and legislation for validating the proposals are recommended in a report of the Stats Board of Regents prepared by Dr. Albert B. Meredith, educational advisor.

It was popular science at its best that Dr. WILLIS R. WHITNEY gave in his recent radio address on the experiments which he has been conducting in a field that must be new to him, a chemist and physicist. Unconsciously he revealed how the scientific mind works -- how it is spurred on to experimentation by some curious phenomenon that calls for explanation.

To the Editor of The New fork Times: With the formal occupation of Chinchow, Manchuria as a whole has come under the grip of the Japanese. It will be recalled that the government at Tokyo has in the past few months repeatedly announced that Japan has no territorial ambition in that part of China.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 4. -- The 155th anniversary of the Battle of Princeton, regarded by many historians as the turning point of the Revolutionary War, was observed here today. Although the battle actually occurred on Jan. 3, 1777, the observance was held today.

Amid the cheers of more than 200 of their fellow-countrymen who crowded the pier, sixteen Norwegian athletes, who will represent their nation in the third Winter Olympiad at Lake Placid from Feb. 4 to 13, arrived yesterday on the Europa, which docked in South Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Weakness in the stock and cotton markets overshadowed everything of a constructive character today in the grain markets, and at no time were wheat prices on the Board of Trade here above Thursday's finish. Commission houses and local traders were on the selling side, and toward the last liquidation by scattered longs was in evidence.

Mr. and Mrs. John W. Tobin gave a tea dance yesterday in the main salon of Sherry's to introduce their daughter, Miss Flora Fairchild Tobin, to society. Mrs. Tobin and her daughter received in the foyer near a screen of farleyance ferns, on each side of which was an Adaline rose tree.

PHILIPSE MANOR, N.Y., Jan. 4. -- Miss Elsie Janis, the actress, upon returning to her home here tonight from New York City, declared that she did not believe in "engagements," but that she would have a very definite report within a week or two regarding her rumored bethrothal to Gilbert Wilson, young motion-picture actor.

The national champion and three former titleholders are in the select field of forty-four players listed to begin play Thursday evening in the annual Clyde Martin Memorial invitation squash tennis tournament at the Yale Club, it was announced yesterday by Fergus Reid Jr., chairman of the Yale Club committee and the National Squash Tennis Association's representative in charge of the tournament.

The London String Quartet and the English piano team of Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson were the artists last night at the fourth of, the Columbia concert series held in Carnegie Hall. The quartet presented as its share of the program Mozart's Quartet in G (K. 387) and H. Waldo Warner's Fairy Suite, "The Pixy Ring."

LONDON, Jan. 4. -- Sterling opened lower today on unfavorable international developments over the weekend. After a slight improvement the tendency weakened again in the afternoon, with New York rate $3.37 1/3, against Saturday's closing at $3.40.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 4 -- Certificates of registration will be presented by Governor Larson tomorrow to 118 pharmacists who qualified in the recent State examination. Among the class are Miss Georgiana A. Schubert, Bound Brook, and Miss Evelyn M. Soffer of Paterson.

ROME, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Foreign Minister Dino Grandi, who recently visited the United States to confer with President Hoover, will head Italy's delegation to the World Disarmament Conference at Geneva next month.

CHICAGO, Jan. 4 -- Shipping demand for light-weight hogs was fairly active today, but the main sales showed losses of 5 to 10 cents from last week's final prices. Heavy kinds, however, gradually weakened and were quoted 15 to 25 cents lower at the last.

MUKDEN, Jan. 4 -- With five Russian civilians killed, twenty-two wounded and the Chinese casualties unknown, Harbin's streets are barricaded and tension and clamor reign, recalling the wild days of the French Revolution.

Governor Franklin D. Roosevelt will formally, and for the first time, be placed before the country as a candidate for the Presidency on Feb. 6, one week after his fiftieth birthday, when the Democratic convention of the State of Washington meets, It was indicated last night by Scott Bullitt, Democratic National Committeeman from that State. Mr. Bullitt arrived here last night with J. Bruce Kremer, National Committeeman from Montana.

If every nation were to cancel every debt of every other nation the world would be far better off politically and economically, and it is almost certain that such action would produce permanent peace and lasting prosperity, according to a new book by Colonel Elisha E. Garrison, economist.

Albert Herskovits, a pioneer among local fur merchants and a well-known figure in the international trade, died yesterday at his home, 262 Central Park West, having been in poor health for a short time. He wag 68 years old on Saturday.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 4. -- A plea for the churches to come closer to the labor movement was made by the Rev. James Myers, industrial secretary of the social service commission of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, addressing this afternoon's session of the annual meeting of the Home Missions Council and the Council of Women for Home Missions, convening jointly here.
In perfect physical condition and anticipating three defenses of his world's heavyweight title this year Max Schmeling of Germany stepped jauntily down the gangplank from the liner Europa yesterday.

LONDON, Jan. 4 -- The Archbishop of Canterbury tonight issued to the Diocesan Gazette what is in effect a prohibition against the marriage in the Church of England of persons who have been divorced, whether innocent or guilty parties; those within the prohibited degrees of the prayer book and those who have not been baptized.

Sharp price declines were recorded in commodity markets yesterday. The losses were found in the grains, provisions and textiles in cash group, while coffee, sugar, cocoa, hides, rubber and silk were lower in contract grades.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4. -- Parallel with the completion today of preparations for the Initial meeting in the State Department with Secretary Stimson tomorrow noon of the United States delegation to the coming general disarmament conference at Geneva, evidence developed of governmental friction should the suggestion for American endorsement of some form of budgetary arms limitation be pressed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 -- Abandonment of the five-mile Whitestone Branch of the Long Island Railroad was ordered today by the Supreme Court, which, in a unanimous opinion handed down by Associate Justice Roberts, upheld the decision of the Southern District Court in New York.

Holders of certificates of deposit representing five-year convertible 6 per cent gold debentures of the Midland National Gas Company deposited under an agreement dated Jan. 1, 1931, have been advised by their protective committee that it has adopted a plan of reorganization in their behalf.

Formation, of Deposited Bond Certificates, convertible debenture series of 1938, an investment trust of a new type, was announced yesterday by the Allied General Corporation, sponsor of the trust. The portfolio of the trust will consist entirely of bonds which are convertible into common stocks or carry stock-purchase warrants.

Business was slow and the price trend downward yesterday in the first full five-hour day of the year on the Stock Exchange. Trading, which was largely professional, involved about 1,500,000 shares. The market was the narrowest since Nov. 17 of last year, with 592 separate issues dealt in.

Frank Macaluso, 42 years old, president of the Columbia Republican Club, which occupies rooms in a building at 421 East Fourteenth Street, and also believed by the police to have been involved in an alcohol racket, was mysteriously shot while standing alone on the sidewalk outside the clubrooms shortly after midnight this morning.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday...3 3/4 to 4 per cent for the best names Friday......Legal holiday The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The smart colt Pilate, which won eight out of ten starts during the past Eastern racing season will in future bear the colors of Andrew Schuttinger, former crack jockey and now a trainer, it became known yesterday. Pilate ran his most recent race on the final day of the Eastern season, when he captured the Belvedere Hotel Handicap at Bowie in impressive fashion in the silks of E.F. Cooney.

Closing of a large branch-banking institution in South Carolina in the holidays had a depressing influence yesterday on prices on the Cotton Exchange here. Weakness in outside markets also was an unsettling factor, and prices declined $1 a bale and closed at losses of 18 to 22 points.

President HOOVER asks Congress to speed up the machinery of legislation. His special message yesterday requested action on various emergency measures "at the earliest possible moment." Where there is, as now, virtual agreement with regard to some of the bills urged by the President, his position is sound.

The book Industry in all its branches, including publication, distribution and selling, is in need of rehabilitation, according to a 150,000 word report, on the chaotic condition in th etrade prepared by O.H. Cheney, former vice president of the Irving Trust Company under the sponsorship of the National Association of Book Publishers.

BOISE, Idaho, Jan. 4 (AP). -- Moses Alexander, former Governor of Idaho, died of a heart attack here today, at the age of 78. He served two terms two Governor after his election in the Fall of 1914. He was a Democrat.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Not since the armistice has New Orleans put on such a celebration as that which greeted the return of Tulane's Green Wave today from the Rose Bowl football game.

Bennie Alien of Kansas City retained his hold on first place in the New York State pocket billiard championship tournament by vanquishing George Kelly of Philadelphia, 125 to 72, in sixteen innings at Dwyer's Broadway Academy last night.
BOSTON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, in action for the first time this season in the Boston Garden, tonight were held to a 3-3 overtime lie by the determined Boston Bruins.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5 -- Gus Winkler, Capone henchman, kept his promise today to recover loot of almost $3,000,000 taken by gangsters armed with machine guns from the Lincoln (Neb.) National Bank and Trust Company on Sept. 17, 1930.

The number of questionnaires mailed to contributors to the Democratic campaign fund of 1928 by Mr. Raskob, exclusive of those returned because of change of address, death of contributors, , was 77,500. The number of replies received was 25,578.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- The Court of Appeals disposed of criminal libel charges today brought by William F. Deegan, Tenement House Commission in New York City, against Nathan J. Bensky and ordered Bensky's discharge from prison.

For several years a new monster, or terrible Brocken spectre, has been rising before the affrighted eyes of American politicians. The thing is dubbed "international banker." Senator JOHNSON of Calfifornia claims to be the first discoverer -- one might say the only begetter -- of the horrid apparition.

ALBANY, Jan. 5 -- Quotations from the Bible may be read in the public schools of New York City, the Court of Appeals ruled today when it affirmed the action of the lower court in dismissing the appeal of Joseph Lewis, who sought to prevent such reading.

NORTH ARLINGTON, N.J., Jan 5 -- A pair of carrier pigeons which Harvard Johnson and Paul Dolce, 16-year-old high school boys, took with them when they ran away from their homes on Wesley Place at 6 A.M. yesterday, so that their messages to their parents could not be traced, caused their capture today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,203,100 barrels, compared with 2,292,900 in the preceding week, a decrease of 83,800 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Daily average production east of California was 1,709,400 barrels, compared with 1,793,300, a decrease of 83,000 barrels.

The Manhattan quintet, after a slump which extended over three games, came back to form convincingly last night, overwhelming the Niagara five, 31 -- 18, before a capacity crowd of 1,200 at the Jasper gymnasium.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Having obtained the approval of Governor Larson, to whom the schedule was submitted Dec. 1 in accordance with the law enacted by the 1931 Legislature, the State Highway Commission made public today its program of construction projects for 1932.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Attorney General Mitchell expects to confer on Thursday with investigators who have been studying alleged price fixing of steel rails and at that time a decision may be reached as to whether to begin action under the anti-trust laws.

MONTREAL, Jan. 5. -- Some progress has been achieved in connection with the proposed merger of six of the leading newsprint companies in Canada, for which negotiations have extended for three months. A questionnaire is to be issued to the various companies and is expected to elicit full information as to the position of the individual mills.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The international concern with which event in Manchuria are viewed was strikingly shown today when it was disclosed here that the British, French and United States Governments were considering further joint diplomatc representations to Japan bearing upon the basic situation in that region.

CHICAGO, Jan. 5. -- Wheat traders are inclined to stand to one side and let the market fluctuate pending developments. The range in the price of the May delivery in the last six weeks on the Board of Trade here has been 7 cents, and at the finish today that future was about half way between the high and the low of the period.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For the splendid editorial "Lift Up Your Hearts," appearing in your Jan. 1 issue, you should receive from the public both thanks and congratulations. Your reference to war debts was most timely. You could have justified your suggestion of their being in fact war subsidies by quoting Senator Smoot's speech as reported on the Treasury reports.

Sidney Lenz and Commander Winfield Liggett Jr. cut steadily into the lead of Ely Culbertson last night in their I50-rubber contract bridge match at the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, gaining 2,660 points in the course of the night. Mr. Culbertson, who played last night with Michael Gottlieb.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art has consigned to the storeroom one of its most familiar paintings, "Washington Crossing the Delaware," a painting praised by the patriotic and condemned by art connoisseurs.
One or Tammany Hall's most munificent distributers of largess will be called upon tomorrow by the Hofstadter committee to explain the sources of his wealth.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Private foreign debts to the United States are going to be paid "unless extraordinary political or economic forces make it impossible," but the payment of governmental obligations is a question of political expediency. Clarence Dillon of Dillon, Read Co. testified today before the Senate Finance Committee.

Gurnett Co., a commission house of medium size with extensive New England connections, suspended business yesterday and notified the New York Stock Exchange that it was unable to meet its obligations. Alien L. Lindley, vice president of the Exchange, announced the suspension from the rostrum at 10:04 A.M.

In his report to the trustees of the American Museum of Natural History a year ago President OSBORN put in the forefront of its needs an increase of endowment from $15,000,000 to $22,500,000. By 1933 the exhibition halls, laboratories and lecture halls were expected to be in full operation.

Gold shipments to France were increased yesterday when the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported exports of $2,200,000 of the metal, $2,050,000 going to France and $150,000 to Switzerland. There were no imports at New York, but from San Francisco word was received of the arrival of $133,000 of gold from China.

Following Monday's decline of nearly 35 points from the high levels of last week, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and under a 10-point recovery ended 5 to 6 points higher for the day. Despite weakness in securities, trade price fixing created resistance and selling from Southern sources declined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The text of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation bill, as agreed upon by the full Senate Banking and Currency Committee in the form it will be reported to the Senate tomorrow follows:

TOKYO, Wednesday, Jan. 6 -- A conference was held at the Finance Ministry today to determine whether $75,000,000 worth of foreign bonds held by the Government Deposits Bureau shall be loaned to the Yokohama Specie Bank to tide it over its shortage of dollar exchange due to the recent abandonment or the gold standard.

GALLIPOLIS, Ohio, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Sheriff Charles Swanson announced today that two inmates of the boys' industrial school at Lancaster confessed that they had made a funeral pyre on April 7 out of a Gallia County log cabin, burning eight persons to death.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Secretary Adams today strongly endorsed the Vinson $616,000,000 naval replacement bill, which calls for a ten-year program to build the navy up to the London treaty limitations. Mr. Adams, appearing before the House Naval Committee, declared that the bill did not violate any Hoover Administration naval commitments.

A petition for the appointment of an equity receiver for Rolls-Royce of America. Inc., automobile manufacturers with offices at 32 East Fifty-seventh Street, was filed yesterday in United States District Court by Mark Hurewitz of 200 Madison Avenue, the holder of ten $1,000 bonds issued by then corporation.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, Jan. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Australia today captured the third match and the rubber in the test cricket series with South Africa. Grimmett gave an excellent display of his bowling prowess to capture all three of the remaining South African wickets in the second innings which ended for 225 runs.
Readers eager to relieve the continuing need of the last of the Neediest Cases sent $2,400,44 yesterday in 162 gifts, which brought the fund to $278,741,91.

MUKDEN, Wednesday, Jan. 6 -- No decision has yet been made by the military authorities as to whether the two Japanese privates who beat and abused Consul Culver B. Chamberlain Sunday morning would be courtmartialed.

Charging that the Hofstadter legislative committee, under the domination of Samuel Seabury, its counsel, has spent $412,000 to pry into the private lives of Mayor Walker and other officials in a fruitless effort to uncover non-existent graft and corruption, Charles F. Kerrigan, assistant to the Mayor, called upon Republican legislative leaders yesterday to terminate the inquiry by Feb. 1, the date set for its report when its creation was authorized by the 1931 Legislature.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 6. -- Senator John A. Hastings of Brooklyn renewed tonight his challenge to Samuel Seabury, counsel for the Hofstadter committee, before which the Senator has declined to appear for testimony.

WASHINGTON, D.C., Jan. 5 (AP) -- The disturbance that was central over Southern Texas has moved northeastward to the upper Mississippi Valley and it has been attended by general rains in the great central vallays, the Gulf States and portions of the Lake region and by snow from Lake Superior southwestward to New Mexico and the Texas Panhandle.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- City College of New York, after winning seven straight basketball games, met its first defeat of the season when it was stopped by Temple University at Mitten Hall tonight, 33 to 29, before a crowd of 3,000.

A Joint meeting of the Metropolitan-New York Branch of the National Academy of Visual Instruction and the visual Instruction section of the Experimental Society of New York City will be held next Friday evening at Education Hall in the Museum of Natural History, Seventy-seventh Street and Central Park West.

The appointment of Herbert Brucker as assistant dean of the Columbia University School of Journalism was announced yesterday afternoon by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. Mr. Brucker has resigned from the editorial board of the Review of Reviews magazine, and will enter his new office on Jan. 15.

Charles J. Romm, 49 years old, of 147 South Ninth Street, Brooklyn, owner of a book shop at 110 Fourth Avenue, and recognized authority on rare books, was sentenced to an indeterminate term of not more than three years in the penitentiary yesterday by Judga Levins in General Sessions.
MADRID, Jan. 5 -- Seven persons, four of them women and one a child, wera killed in two clashes of citizens with the Civil Guard in Spain today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The snubbing of Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, by a committee of newspaper correspondents representing the State Department Correspondents' Association, led to the intervention this afternoon of Secretary Stimson, who, in no uncertain terms, made known his displeasure at the action taken by the committee.

It is idle to speak of a conflict between the British and the French on the question of Germany's debts so long as we cannot say what is the definite British position, and, still more important, what is the definite French position. Popular opinion in Great Britain wants German private debts put ahead of reparations.

MONTREAL, Jan. 5 -- The New York Americans overcame the jinx that seemed to keep them from scoring against the world's champion Canadiens and took a 2-to-1 victory over the Montreal men in an exciting National Hockey League game tonight, tying the score just before the end of the game and gaining the winning tally in overtime.

Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel, will go before the Supreme Court today for permission to attach the bank accounts ot Deputy City Clerk James J. McCormick in an effort to recover for the city $168,000 McCormick is said to have received in gratuities for performing civil marriages.
The Insurance Brokers' Association of New York has moved its offices to 90 John Street.

Officers were elected for the year and tentative dates awarded for the coming season at the fifteenth annual meeting of the Association of American Horse Shows, which was held yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore. Alfred B. Maclay, president, occupied the chair at the business meeting and later was host to about 100 delegates and guests from various sections of the country.

LONDON, Jan. 5 -- There was considerable activity at army headquarters at Aldershot today when more than 400 officers and other ranks of the Royal Welsh Regiment and the Royal Scots left to reinforce their regiments in India.

Approval of the five-day week and the six-hour day and a drive to obtain 1,000,000 jobs in the next few months were the features of the employment program adopted yesterday by the National Employment Commission of the American Legion which met yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Charged with violation of the Harrison drug act and internal revenue regulations in attempting to import 260 pounds of heroin into the country, Naftali Ojalvo, 35 years old, and Isaac Sevilla, 43, were arraigned yesterday before Commissioner Martin C. Epstein and held in bail of $15,000 each for a hearing Jan. 25.

Mrs. Flora Burgess, wife of Arthur Burgess, an employe in the art department of THE NEW YORK TIMES, was beaten severely yesterday by one of two men who ransacked her house at 92-52 218th Place, Queens Village but escaped with only $5. Mrs. Burgess remained at home after treatment by her family physician for shock and for bruises on the forehead and neck.

Two five-story tenement houses at 487-9 Tenth Avenue, near the north-west corner of Thirty-seventh Street, were sold yesterday by the estate of Andrew Rohr to the Wenner Realty Company, which owns the adjoining corner and now controls a plot 75 by 100 feet.

The prediction that America's book Industry, representing an annual turnover of more than $600,000,000, is on the verge of collapse, contained in the survey made by O.H. Cheney At the book publishing world and summarized in the metropolitan press yesterday, aroused a storm of protests among book publishers.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 5 -- The dispatch of a Japanese cruiser and three destroyers to Foochow. where marines were landed following a mob out break and the murder of a Japanese man and a woman, it is believed will lead to the adoption of a policy of landing parties at other disturbed points where anti-Japanese activities continue.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- William Hard, who broadcasts weekly over the National Company's chain under the caption, "Back of the News to Washington," dedicated his radio speech tonight to the memory of Richard V. Oulahan, late chie Washington correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The grudge handicap checker match in which Mrs. Anna Berliss engaged Louis Ginsburg through six games and two sessions at the Gramercy Chess and Checker Club, 32 Union Square, ended in a draw last night. Ginsburg, checker champion of New York City, had conceded Mrs. Berliss two games before the match started.

The first national professional squash racquets championship to be held in New York will begin at 11:30 this morning, when a field of 28 players will swing into action on the courts of the Downtown A.C.

LISBON, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Two hundred persons were arrested and bombs, rifles and revolvers were seized in Oporto tonight when the police conducted a series of raids on suspicion that a revolution movement was impending.

Barring strength In cash grains, which followed the upturn in the contract grades, commodity markets were heavy yesterday. Losses were recorded in the dairy products, lard, tin and rubber in spot markets, while in futures there were losses in hides, rubber, coffee and cocoa. Sugar was steady.

The Painters' and Sculptors' Gallery in East Eleventh Street is holding, through January, an exhibition of work by Hungarian-Americans. This show, according to Margit Varga, proprietor of the gallery, is intended as a "follow-up" for the Hungarian exhibition presented by the College Art Association at the Silberman Galleries earlier in the season.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Acting under the stimulus of nation-wide pressure and President Hoover's special message urging prompt Congressional action on his economic program, the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today voted to report favorably to the Senate tomorrow the $2,000,000,000 reconstruction finance corporation bill.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 5 -- Assemblyman Anthony J. Siracusa of Atlantic County, whose repealer of the Hobart State enforcement act drew a vote of 29 in favor to 22 against at the special session of the 1931 Legislature last night and failed to pass by the lack of two votes from the required majority of 31, announced today he would reintroduce the bill at the first regular session of the incoming Assembly.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Recommendations ranging from Federal regulation of all motor vehicles operated for hire in interstate commerce to modification of anti-trust laws to permit railroads to acquire bus and truck lines already in operation were made to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Leo J. Flynn. one of its examiners.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Ruling that a laborer when appointed a foreman does not give up his vocation, the Court of Appeals today upheld the contention of Frank E. Austin, foreman of a gang of bridge riveters of the Department of Plant and Structures in New York City, that he should receive $4,148.50 instead of $2,226,50 as compensation under the prevailing rate of wages in law.

By giving dramatic form to what is probably a case in the psychology of incorrigible children, T.C. Upham has written a terrifying play, "Lost Boy," which was splendidly acted at the Mansfield last evening. Mr. Upham has hardly attempted to translate it out of its scientific formula, which is a pity, since the psychology is frequently more conspicuous than the character.

With a grave already dug, a mass said for the repose of his soul, and the mourners gathered for the funeral of Pasqualle Costanza yesterday afternoon at the home of the latter's son, Frank, the relatives discovered through a comparative stranger that the dead man was not Costanza.

GARY, Ind., Jan. 5 -- The First National Bank of Gary closed this afternoon following a run which began with the closing of two Hammond banks Saturday and continued with the closing of the Bank of America of Gary Monday. F.R. Schaff, president of the bank, announced the closing was voted by the directors as a preliminary step toward reorganization and to protect the interests of depositors.

Samuel Seabury, chief counsel to the Hofstadter committee in its investigation into city affairs, has been nominated for the presidency of the New York State Bar Association. The list of nominations was released yesterday by Dr. I. Maurice Wormser, chairman of the organization's committee on publications.

HAVANA, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Racing by 2-year-olds was inaugurated for the year at Oriental Park today when the first event on the program, fashioned for fillies at two furlongs, brought together a field of twelve. The winner turned up in Olive Sabath, which races for the Chicago lawyer-sportsman, Al Sabath.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- A bill to consolidate the War and Navy Departments for the sake of economy was introduced in the House today by Chairman Byrns of the House Appropriations Committee.

Authority to pledge for bank loans, the $100,000,000 of 5 per cent Series bonds, issuance of which was authorized recently by the Interstate Commerce Commission, was asked of the commission yesterday by the New York Central Railroad. The application mentions $58,500,000 of promissory notes outstanding against the railroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- The Democratic drive to force the new tariff bill through the House in advance of a tax program and other measures for balancing the budget, was halted temporarily today by administration Republicans who broke up the one hearing scheduled before the Ways and Means Committee with a demand that representatives of the Treasury and State Departments be heard before the tariff bill was reported.

PITTSBURGH, Pa., Jan. 5 -- Father James R. Cox's "army" of unemployed, carrying a plea for immediate relief measures to President Hoover and Congress, left Pittsburgh early today and reached Johnstown, Pa., at noon, with its ranks swollen to nearly 20,000 by delegations which joined it en route.

The Atcbison, Topeka Santa Fe Railway, which has paid $2.50 quarterly since June, 1928, declared yesterday a dividend of $1.50 on its common stock. Considering the $1.50 payment as a quarterly disbursement would place the stock on a $6 annual basis, compared with the $10 rate maintained since 1928.

Whatever hopes parent-members of the Child Study Association of America may have cherished when they entered their meeting room at 221 West Fifty-seventh Street last night must have been diminished when Dr. Frankwood E. Williams, psychiatrist, told them that in all probability no child of their's would attain the Presidency of the United States.

Roy Chapman Andrews, president of the Explorers' Club and leader of the recent ten-year expedition of the American Museum of Natural History to the Gobi Desert, told the students at Barnard College yesterday that women have no place in exploration.
MINNEAPOLIS, Jan. 5 (AP) -- The University of Minnesota today threatened to withdraw its hockey team from the Olympic trials.

Prolonged negotiations to effect a settlement of differences between builders and labor officials over a readjustment of building wages in New York City have broken down. As a result of the deadlock the Building Trades Employers' Association expects to establish on its own initiative a "fair wage" for the industry, lower than the present scale for all branches of the work, to be effective on May 1.

In discussing the outlook for Federal economy it is frequently assumed that fixed charges over which the Government has no control make it impossible to effect any large reduction of expenditures. This accounts in part for the attitude of resignation with which the public Views the consideration of appropriation bills.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 5 -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Terry West entertained twelve guests at dinner tonight at their home, Villa Tramonto.

BOMBAY, Wednesday, Jan. 6 (AP). -- The British began rounding up leaders of the Indian Nationalist Congress at 4:30 A.M. today. Vithalbhai Patel, former president of the Indian Legislative Assembly, was arrested a half hour later.

Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street -- the hub of the city's midtown shopping centre -- was a scene of turmoil at 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon when a detective of the pickpocket squad fired five shots in the air to halt a naan charged with having taken $132 worth of neckties from A. Sulka Co.'s shop at 512 Fifth Avenue.

The eleventh week of the Metropolitan Opera's season next week will include a number of interesting features including the season's first performances of "Siegfried," "Rigoletto" and "Il Trovatore"; the return to the company of Gertrude Kappel and Lawrence Tibbett and the second performance of von Suppe's "Donna Juanita."

An apathetic stock market declined moderately yesterday in response to a series of depressing developments, then retraced its steps to end the day only a abort distance below the closing level of the afternoon before. The bond market was weak, foreign exchanges were quiet; agricultural staples, stronger.

Fifty per cent of the churches in New York City are monuments of emptiness, the Rev. Dr. Donald B. Aldrich, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension, declared in an address yesterday at a retreat of clergymen at the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, held under the auspices of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

En route to Lake Placid to participate in the Winter Olympics, the members of the Norwegian team who arrived Monday spent a busy day here yesterday, being guests of honor at three receptions and still finding time to take a sight-seeing tour around the city.

To the Editer of The New York Times: I read with interest the communication of Leonard P. Crout of Toronto, in which he discusses the relation of the Canadian dollar to that of the United States. Every well-wisher of the two nations would endorse any practicable method of tying the two exchanges together so as to assure parity.

The Transit Commission sought to make a States' rights issue out of the Interstate Commerce Commission's approval of the Long Island Railroad Company's plan to abandon the Whitestone branch. But it had a poor case in fact as well as at law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So many people are engaged in keeping old sores open and in cherishing ideas of national distinction which have become antiquated, and so few sea dispassionately the world situation which the war settlement has brought about, that the wisdom of the remarks recently made by the American Ambassador to Berlin in an address before the American Chamber of Commerce in the German capital may be overlooked.

TIENTSIN, China, Jan. 5 (AP) -- Chang Hsueh-liang, deposed Governor of Manchuria, whose troops have been driven out of that province by the Japanese, has received an unofficial ultimatum warning him to retire further into North China, it was reliably reported here today.

Discussions are In progress for establishing a community of interests between the sponsors of the Northern Natural Gas Corporation, whose pipe lines run from Kansas and Texas to Nebraska, Iowa, Missouri and South Dakota, and the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Corporation, which runs from the Texas Panhandle to Central Indiana, where it connects with the Columbia Gas and Electric System, which operates in many Eastern States.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 5. -- The government of India, having struck the first blow and outlawed the Central Executive body of the All-India Nationalists Congress, the Provincial Governments are now acting independently on their respective fronts.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Gilbert Elston and Melvin Lewis, two leading jockeys of the Jefferson Park meeting, battled for honors in today's one-and-one-sixteenth-mile feature, with the chief award going to Elston.
Two large Madison Avenue properties were among eleven Manhattan offerings which passed yesterday at auction to plaintiffs in foreclosure actions. Eight Bronx parcels were taken over similarly.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 5 -- Albert Bushnell Hart, Professor Emeritus of History at Harvard, declared today that the "failure" of the League of Nations in the Manchurian situation had proved that the League never would be able to meet a real international crisis with more than an appeal to the offending nations to consider the interests of mankind.
PARIS, Jan. 5. -- A report was current today in Paris that Aristide Briand's health had suddenly suffered a relapse and that the veteran Foreign Minister had had two sucessive strokes.

The Merchants' Association announced yesterday that It had appealed to the Treasury Department to repeal its decision and to make available to truckers and business men the nature of inbound ships' cargoes. Prior to last Aug. 8 information contained in manifests of Vessels inbound and outbound was available and published by certain newspapers.

Buyers' Registrations Jump. Registration of buyers in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a large Increase over the figures for the previous week, but remained well behind the total reached in the corresponding week a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.
LONDON, Jan. 5 -- Sterling opened lower in all the foreign exchanges today, developing an irregular tendency. The New York rate after dropping to $3.36 recovered to $3.37, then weakened to $3.36 1/2.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- Early consideration by the House of the proposal to turn 40,000,000 bushels of Farm Board wheat over to the Red Cross for milling and distribution to the unemployed, which was adopted by the Senate yesterday, was forecast today when the agriculture committee virtually completed hearings on a measure carrying it into effect.

Surprised and overpowered by holdup men they had been sent to capture, two detectives of the West Forty-seventh Street police station faced departmental charges last night because they had allowed themselves to be robbed of their revolvers and bound with other victims at 242 West Fiftieth Street.

LEICESTER, England, Jan. 5 (AP). -- Theras, carrying the American silks of Jesse Metcalf, today won the Wigston Steeplechase by eight lengths. Only four horses started the two-mile journey. Metcalf recently purchased Theras with the intention of starting the jumper in the Grand National next March.

BOMBAY, Jan. 5. -- Despite the three days' strike proclaimed by the local All-India Congress committee as a protest against the arrest of Mahatma Gandhi. Bombay seemed fairly normal today. Seven mills were closed but elsewhere the suspension of business was confined mainly to the principal cloth markets and the Stock Exchange.

GENEVA, Jan. 5 -- Formal announcement of the Mandates Commission's approval of statehood for Iraq was made here today with the release of its special report to the Council of the League of Nations. No one doubts that the Council, when it meets Jan. 25, will also approve, thus allowing Iraq to become, a sovereign State this year, as, Britain had planned, and also the fifty-sixth member of the League and its second Moslem member.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 -- When put in per capita terms, the growth of Federal expenditures for government in the last twenty years becomes graphic.

The New York Rangers added another victory to their imposing list last night when they turned back the rugged Montreal Maroons, 2 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden. But the triumph came hard to the New Yorkers, for the visitors from the North offered the strongest of opposition and remained a constant threat to the league leaders until the very end of the battle.

HASTINGS, England, Jan. 5 -- Still undefeated by any of their rivals, Isaac I. Kashdan of New fork and S. Flohr of Czechoslovakia remain tied for the lead in the international chess masters' tournament at the White Rock Pavilion, the eighth and semi-final round of which was contested today.

CONCORD, N.H., Jan. 5 -- Former Representative William N. Rogers of Wakefield and this city, a wet Democrat, was elected today to succeed the late Fletcher Hale, Republican, as Representative from the First New Hampshire District.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 5. -- Four Federal District Judges ordered the government today to show cause why it should not be enjoined from enforcing the new law limiting the number of priests in the capital; one court flatly rejected the injunction petition of a priest; and the only other district court instructed the petitioner to clarify his appeal against the statute.

The tennis match that drew more than 13,000 spectators to Madison Square Garden last year will be repeated there this evening when William Tilden, world's professional champion, and Vincent Richards meet in the feature engagement of the professional indoor tournament being staged by Jack Curley.

Search in this country for the estate of Richard Wall, automobile salesman who was shot and killed in Paris, France, on Dec. 19, resulted in the finding of 350 Liberty airplane motors valued at about $100,000 owned by him and stored in Jersey City, it became known yesterday.

HOUSTON, Texas, Jan. 5 -- The trail of Harry and Jennings Young, brothers who slew six Missouri peace officers Saturday night, came to an end today as they stood toe to toe in a cottage here and shot each other to death to avoid being captured alive.

Statements were issued yesterday by several banks and trust companies of their position at the end of the year in response to calls made by the Controller of the Currency and the State Superintendent of Banks.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5 -- Until such time as a stockholder has exhausted all other remedies he cannot begin an action against a banking institution which is under charge of the Superintendent of Banks, the Court of Appeals held in effect today in deciding the action of Thea Isaacs, appellant, against Bernard K. Marcus and other defendants; Bank of United States and Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, respondents.

ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 5. -- Establishment of a State banking board and investment relief for securities hit by depression will be sought on the opening of the Legislature tomorrow by the Joint Banking Committee as the first step in a program of banking law revision in the State.

Stocks were subjected to further selling pressure yesterday, but rallying tendencies appeared in the late dealings and closing quotations were down only slightly on the day. Trading on the Stock Exchange involved about 1,400,000 shares, compared with a trifle more than 1,500,000 shares on the previous day.

The 1928 report of the Democratic National Committee on campaign expenditures for that year violated the corrupt practices act, but prosecution is impossible because of the statute of limitations, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, said yesterday after receiving the report of an assistant who had been sent to Washington to examine the report.

Volina Powers, soprano, of Detroit, gave a recital in the smaller music salon of the Barbizon-Plaza last evening, somewhat delayed in starting until her accompanist, Benno Kantrowitz, reached the hall.

Aside from a break in United States Government bonds, the bond market on the Stock Exchange gave a fairly good account of itself yesterday. Foreign loans were traded lightly but finished generally higher, with net gains of 1 to 5 points fairly numerous. In the domestic group utility issues and many high-grade railroad bonds pointed higher, but the lower-rated issues of the latter group and industrial bonds were unable to make much headway.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- Following is the text of Chairman Raskob's letter to the Democratic National Committee, which was made public here tonight:

Dusty Cooke, fleet outfielder of the New York Yankees, has arrived in New York, it was learned yesterday, to undergo a rigid examination of his right shoulder which he injured shortly after the 1931 pennant race got under way and which practically put him out of commission for the balance of the season.

An Authority on Stepping Down. Mrs. RUTH McCORMICK calls upon President HOOVER not to seek a renomination this year. Admitting that the political precedents are all in favor of giving a President a second term, she argues that it would be a very graceful thing for Mr. HOOVER to ignore them and "step down," so that the Republican party might put up a candidate who stood a better chance of election.

In preparation for the meeting of the Democratic National Committee in Washington on Saturday, a number of supporters from Western States of Governor Roosevelt's candidacy for the Presidency have stopped off here for conferences with the Governor's advisers in the city.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 5. -- A new track record was set and a 9 to 20 favorite defeated at Tropical Park today in one of the closest finishes of the meeting thus far. Yargee, a 7-year old gelding by Towton Field-Thistle Etta, bore the colors of R.F. Coppage to victory by a head after Sour Mash, the heavily-backed public choice, faltered in the last furlong of the fourth race.

VIENNA, Jan. 5 -- The Austrian Government today notified a number of short and medium term creditors that it could no longer pay amortization on their loans, but would continue to pay interest as hitherto.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- With about $1,000,000 on hand to meet the city and county payroll for the last two weeks of December, totaling $1,625,000, employes in the smaller offices received their salraies today. Others will be paid tomorrow and it was hoped that by the end of the week the full payroll would be met.

Chairman RASKOB'S letter to the Democratic National Committee, published today, shows a way around the two barriers to prohibition repeal which would require years to level. These are: the unwillingness of two-thirds in Congress to submit a clear-cut repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, and the difficulty of obtaining the assent to repeal by thirty-six States.

MOSCOW, Jan. 5 -- The formation of three new commissariats, for heavy Industry, light Industry and lumber, virtually completes the process of administrative reorganization for which the signal was given by Joseph Stalin's speech last Summer, when ha made it clear that the old commissariats had grown unwieldy.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 5 -- University of Pennsylvania's varsity track candidates, hopeful of retaining the Intercollegiate indoor championship, have started the long grind of preparation on the board track at Franklin Field.

BERLIN, Jan. 5 -- The coordination of the French and German airlines from Europe to South America will be the chief topic of discussion at a two days' meeting of the Franco-German subcommittee on aviation, to begin here tomorrow.
Before any one knew what had happened, Leopold Stokowski had leapt upon the conductor's stand last night in Carnegie Hall, and launched the orchestra into a shrill Cuban dance by one A.G. Caturla.

MUKDEN, Jan. 5 -- That the evacuation of the Chinchow zone by the Chinese regular troops and the occupation of that district by the Japanese has not solved Japan's problem in Manchuria is evidenced by a series of attacks made yesterday by Chinese irregulars, two of which entailed sharp fighting.

Death sentences were Imposed by Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday on Alfred Corbellini, 21 years old, of 251 East 105th Street and Alfred Cozzi, 20, of 558 East 191st Street, the Bronx, in the shooting of a policeman during a restaurant hold-up last May 2.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon gave a farewell luncheon at the Plaza yesterday for their cousin, Charles Astor Bristed, who sailed last night on the Conte Grande for Italy.

Loft buildings, a theatre, three garages, taxpayers and numerous dwellings comprise 163 parcels of real estate in this city listed for sale at foreclosure next week. The aggregate value of the properties is $12,134,800, of which $5,000,000 is land value alone.

A delay in completing contracts for Max Schmeling, world's heavyweight champion, in his proposed defense of the title against Mickey Walker, former world's middleweight titleholder, has postponed the signing of the bout, scheduled for today, it was announced yesterday by Joe Jacobs, the champion's manager.

A broad program of loss-taking, with the proceeds of the sales invested in United States Government short-term obligations and other highly liquid securities, characterized the activities of the Lehman Corporation in the six months ended on Dec. 31, according to the report being received by stockholders today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 5. -- The American position before the general disarmament conference which convenes at Geneva next month was discussed in great detail this afternoon by President Hoover, Secretary of State Stimson, Ambassador Dawes, the chairman, and Senator Swanson of Virginia.

The forty-foot rum-runner Patricia, an old offender, bound in from a mother ship with a large cargo of liquor last night, fell in with Coast Guard Cutter 2291. In the two-mile chase that ensued thirty shots were fired by the cutter from a onepounder and the Patricia finally was set afire.

The winning streak of the Newtown High School basketball team, city P.S.A.L. titleholder, which had reached eighteen games in two seasons, was snapped yesterday when the Queens County combination bowed to Thomas Jefferson High of Brooklyn, 23 to 20, in a non-league encounter on the Newtown court.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In today's TIMES I read of the efforts of the Rev. Dr. A.R. Mansfield to alleviate distress among seamen at the Seamen's Church Institute at 25 South Street, and while conveying my sincerest good wishes for his sterling efforts, I believe that an explanation of his problem is contained in the adjoining columns.

Senator CAPPER'S highly Capperian resolution authorizing the Federal Farm Board to distribute 40,000,000 bushels of its stored wheat among suffering Americans and animals was passed by the Senate without a record vote. Thus those Republican statesmen who love to annoy President HOOVER without a too direct display of their animosity were able to conceal their illustrious names.

PARIS, Jan. 5 -- Despite the bad news of yesterday's session in Wall Street, the Paris Bourse had a good day after a pessimistic opening. The upward swing carried quotations to a point where the greater part of yesterday's losses were regained. An outstanding event of the session was a rise in the Young Plan loan from 397 to 450 an increase of about 13 per cent.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, who let it be known recently that bail bond runners and solicitors for lawyers were not welcome in the Federal Building, when they came there in great hordes and cluttered up the corridors and the court rooms, adopted direct tactics yesterday.
