The Coal Merchants' Association decided unanimously yesterday afternoon to make no independent, individual agreements with the striking coal drivers who are resisting a 10 per cent wage cut and other feattures of the new agreement proposed by the coal dealers.

Martha Graham and Charles Weidman, with their respective groups, each gave half a dance program last night at the New School Auditorium, assisted by the Pan American Chamber Orchestra under the direction of Adolph Weiss.

The first big real estate deal of the year was closed yesterday when Colonel Jacob Ruppert bought the thirty-five-story skyscraper at the northeast corner of Forty-fourth Street and Third Avenue for about $3,500,000.
"Never No More." James Knox Millen's play, will open tonight at the Hudson Theatre. It will have an all-Negro cast.
AMSTERDAM, Jan. 6 -- An important invention in the radio field has been patented by W.P.C. Vanderhorst of Rotterdam.

ALBANY, Jan. 6 -- Ten thousand Republican women are being recruite for active service in the Presidential and State compaigns this year, according to Miss Sarah Schuyler Butler, vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, who attended the opening of the Legislature today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Tragedy marked the first hearing today before the Interstate Commerce Commission on the proposed modification of Ha final plan of railway consolidation in the East when L.E. Jeffries, vice president and general counsel of the Southern Railroad, suffered a heart attack and died on returning to his seat after testifying.

The survey of the book trade carried on by O.H. Cheney is described as "the most exhaustive" analysis of book publishing ever made, and the National Association of Book Publishers is called upon to take the next step in considering Mr. Cheney's recommendations as a basis for improving the book business in an article to appear in The Retail Bookseller on Jan. 15.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 6 -- Army outskated Colgate today to win the opening game of the local hockey season, 6 to 4. The ice in the new skating arena was fast, but the game, played in a heavy fog, was slowed up because of the poor visibility.

GENEVA, Jan. 6 (AP) -- In advance of a formal announcement, authoritative information indicated today that the international commission to investigate the Manchurian problem under the auspices of the League of Nations would be headed by Lord Lytton.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 -- Preliminary reports indicate the probable deportation during the next twelve months of 20,000 aliens, an increase of 1,858 over the number deported last year, according to 'William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Sir Harry Gloster Armstrong, former British Consul General in New York, in a letter to appear in The London Times tomorrow advances a suggestion that Great Britain be allowed to pay the principal of her war debts to the United States in goods.

The use of misleading testimonials by screen stars in the national advertising of products that the celebrites frequently know little aboutswill be discouraged by the Associated Motion Picture Advertisers, Inc. The organization, which met at a luncheon at Sardi's,yesterday next Thursday will draw up resolutions condemning the practice.

The Coast Guard cutter Tiger rescued two fishermen about twelve miles southeast of the Ambrose Lightship last night as a strong northeast gale was carrying their disabled 27-foot motor launch out to sea. According, to a wireless message received at Stapleton, S.I., from the Tiger, the men had been taken aboard the cutter, the launch was in tow and the rescue party was expected to dock at its base early this morning.

The new Matson liner Mariposa will leave the Fore River yard of the Bethlehem Shipbuilding Corporation on Saturday for New York, where she will be open for inspection by the public and be prepared for her maiden sailing to California on Jan. 16.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 6 (AP) -- New Orleans society folk turned out en masse tonight as the Twelfth Night Revelers, masked, received at a fairyland fete opening the 1932 carnival season.

LONDON, Jan. 6 -- Sterling exchange generally was a little weaker today, but the tendency was steadier. The New York rate at $3.36 was slightly lower than that of yesterday. A report that French banks were launching an attack on the pound by withdrawing balances here was denied in authoritative financial circles.

Ray Ruddy, brilliant New York A.C. swimming star, led all other Winged Foot athletes by a 2-1 margin in both the number of first places won and number of total points scored in open competition during 1931, it was revealed yesterday in the sixty-third annual report of the board of governors of the club which will be made at the annual meeting next Tuesday.

BEFORE the Montreal Maroons trooped heavily out of town, bearing their wounded on stretchers, Trainer Bill O'Brien was engaged in a conversation about hockey players and hockey teams in general. He was telling how Normie Smith, the regular Maroon goalie, was hurt in a game with the Canadiens.

BERLIN, Jan. 6 (AP) -- Alien Wardwell, New York attorney, who is believed to be representing a protective committee organized by American holders of long-term German bonds, arrived here today, but it could not be ascertained what part he would take in the international conference of bankers which has been going on here for several weeks.

Conventions and Psychology. The chief business before the Democratic National Committee, meeting tomorrow at Washington, is not what has been mostly in the press in advance. With Chairman RASKOB'S home-rule prohibition amendment it has nothing to do, and will not be asked to do anything, that being the function of the national convention.

The decision of Chairman Raskob not to press for a vote on the wet and dry issue at the meeting of the national committee in Washington on Saturday was interpreted here yesterday by James A. Farley, Democratic State chairman, as evidence that Mr. Raskob had become convinced of the impropriety of such action.

The Union Electric Light and Power Company of Missouri, the operating subsidiary of the North American Edison Company that serves St. Louis and surrounding territory with electricity and steam, is seeking authority from the Public Service Commission of Missouri to own 25 per cent of the voting trust certificates for common stock of the Laclede Power and Light Company, with which it is in Competition in St. Louis.

The Annual Exhibition of work by painter and sculptor members of the National Arts Club was opened last night with a reception and private view. The medal for painting was given to Cullen Yates for "Chinoiserie"; the medal for sculpture to Chester Beach for "Crying."

Politicians were so agog over Governor ROOSEVELT'S message to the Legislature, and were so convinced in advance that he would attack President HOOVER, that they find what they want, whether it exists or not. The Governor explicitly refuses to hold any individual or group or party solely responsible for our present condition.

An increase of $5,590,000 in the amount of gold earmarked for foreign account, reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, attracted interest as being contrary to the usual course of earmarkings in January. Last month's large increase in earmarkings was set down to the normal year-end window-dressing of foreign central banks, but usually January witnesses the release of most of the gold so segregated.
